sloka: cinmayasyādvitīyasya niṣkalasyāśarīriṇaḥ | upāsakānāṃ kāryārthe brahmaṇo rūpakalpanā ||
translation: Of the matchless, uniquely pure consciousness and the indivisible, bodiless one, envisioning the material form is the designated duty of Buddhist lay worshippers for a specific purpose related to the possession of sacred knowledge by the class of men who are its repositories and communicators.

sloka: devebhyaḥ svāhākāra ā kāṣṭhāt
translation: Derived from the very essence of divine beings and indicating supreme excellence, (we know) the exclamation "svāhā" (to be coming) from a tree.

sloka: tasmādapaḥ sambharati tasmāddhiraṇyaṃ sambharati taddyāvāpṛthivyo rasena samardhayati tasmādūṣāntsambharati tasmādākhukarīṣaṃ sambharati
translation: Consequently, it (Agni) enriches many glorious waters through the sacrificial act; similarly, it enhances the earth with its sap or juice. Furthermore, it causes the extremities to be nourished and is also responsible for nourishing the plants, specifically the grass Lipeocercis Serrata, that grow from the earth.

sloka: kṛttikāsu rohiṇyāṃ mṛgaśirasi phalgunīṣu viśākhayoruttarayoḥ proṣṭhapadayoḥ ||
translation: At Rohini's location, on Mriga's district, under Phalguni's birthstar, at Uttara's latter part's heads, and Viśākhā's location, respectively.

sloka: kṛttikāsu brāhmaṇa ādadhīta mukhyo brahmavarcasī bhavati gṛhāṃstasyāgnirdāhuko bhavati ||
translation: If in the Krittikas constellation a brahmin undertakes to study the preeminent knowledge of the Brahman, he becomes revered and his household becomes a site for sacrificial fires.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are equally referred to as spring, summer, and the rains falling in some places during Śrāvaṇa and Bhādra, while autumn and winter are known as the cool or dewy season and the cold season respectively; they are called the fatherly ones.

sloka: rātriṃ jāgaraṇadhāraṇe śakalairvā
translation: "In the nighttime, (through) maintaining wakefulness, with all (people), potentially even (including doing so) through the skull?"

sloka: śamīgarbhādagniṃ manthati | eṣā vā agneryajñiyā tanūḥ |
translation: The core of Prosopis Spicigera or Mimosa Suma is being ignited by rapid friction. Indeed, these are the forms belonging to the sacrificial fire.

sloka: sa bhūrbhuva ityetaistribhirakṣarairgārhapatyamādadhāti dve pariśinaṣṭyayātayāmatāyai
translation: Brahma, with the sacrificial fire symbolized by the three syllables "bhūrbhuva," nurtures and endows the household fire, ensuring its continuous functioning. Causing two entities to approach and move away, he does so with great care and attention, even soliciting the presence of the divine entity named Matāyai.

sloka: yo aśvatthaḥ śamīgarbha āruroha tvesacā | taṃ tvāharāmi brahmaṇā yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saheti pūrṇāhutyantamagnyādheyaṃ
translation: I now offer the holy ashvattha tree, which arose from a shami tree's seed and resides in the adytum, to Brahma through complete oblations and red apparitions, praying "may it be unto you."

sloka: punarādheyamādhānā'pratijñātasya rājyayaśaskāmasya vā trirātrāvaramagnīnutsṛjya sadyo vā punarvasvoḥ varṣāsu madhyandine vā kuśairādhānam vrīhyapūpamarkapalāśayoḥ pakvaṃ gārhapatyasthāne nidadhātyevamāhamanīyasya yāvaṃ sadyaścet
translation: Once more, for one who hasn't previously pledged but intends to prepare for rulership, if they were to abandon the irresistible fires after three nights and days, or immediately during the monsoon season, and establish ripened offerings of barley and rice on sacred grass in the householders' fire - this is what I will do for such a deserving one.

sloka: nānāhitāgnirnāyajvā vipro nāpyasahasradaḥ |
translation: "Aren't some fires impelled by mankind beneficial, learned one, and will those that give a thousand streams not fall short of being able to satisfy?"

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: "Indeed, this denotes an individual who is irreligious, having not performed sacred rites, or one who disregards his wife."

sloka: etadvai jarāmaryaṃ satraṃ yadagnihotraṃ jarayā vā hyevāsmānmucyate mṛtyunā vā payasā nityahomaḥ
translation: Indeed, this is the great Soma sacrifice, known as Agnihotra, that liberates us from becoming old, whether due to natural aging or through death, by means of the constant oblation of semen virile (a metaphor for a sacred fluid) and ghee.

sloka: yavāgūrodano dadhi samigrāmakāmānnādyakāmendriyakāmatejaskāmānāṃ
translation: The tears of the individual who has recently consumed rice-gruel are directed toward the curd pot.

sloka: dhūmāyantyām grāma kāmasya juhuyāt | jvalantyām brahma varcasa kāmasya | aṅgāreṣu paśu kāmasya |
translation: In the final moments of the hamlet, one should offer oblations to the rising smoke; desiring the brilliance of the Brahman, should attend to it in living beings.

sloka: jātaṃ vātsapreṇābhimṛśyottareṇa yajuṣopastha ādhāyottarābhyāmābhimantraṇaṃ mūrdhanyavaghrāṇaṃ dakṣiṇe karṇe jāpaḥ sarṣapānphalīkaraṇamiśrānañjalinottaraistristripratisvāhākāraṃ hutvā saṃśāsti praviṣṭe praviṣṭa eva tūṣṇīmagnāvāvapateti
translation: Once brought into existence, touch (the newborn) with the upper part of a cow's tail, reciting the yajuṣ mantras over it. Placing it on the infant's head, make him/her silent by chanting the japa mantra in the right ear. After performing these rituals, become still and silently observe the entry of the new soul into this world.

sloka: athaināmuttarayā dakṣiṇe haste gṛhītvāgnimabhyānīyāpareṇāgnimudagagraṃ kaṭamāstīrya tasminnupaviśata uttaro varaḥ agnerupasamādhānādyājyabhāgānte'thaināmādito dvābhyāmabhimantrayeta
translation: After taking the firewood in the right hand, making the southern part of the altar and setting the turf thereon with its top facing east, kindling the fire, and completing the final oblations, one should then cause the recitation of the Savitri formula twice, using "svaha" and "idam" respectively.

sloka: sāyaṃsāyaṃ gṛhapatirno agniḥ prātaḥprātaḥ saumanasasya dātā | vasorvasorvasudāna edhi vayaṃ tvendhānāstanvaṃ puṣema || prātaḥprātargṛhapatirno agniḥ sāyaṃsāyaṃ saumanasasya dātā | vasorvasorvasudāna edhīndhānāstvā śataṃhimā ṛdhema ||
translation: At daybreak, the householder, offering oblations to the fire, personifying the morning, becomes the giver of wealth. Similarly, at evening, the householder, as the benefactor of cheerfulness, tends to the fire. We both, fulfilling our respective duties, should nurture this mutual prosperity. Let us both, being diligent and fervent in our tasks, bring about a hundredfold increase.

sloka: sa yatsāyamastamite dve'āhutī juhoti | tadetābhyāṃ pūrvābhyāṃ padbhyāmetasminmṛtyau pratitiṣṭhattyatha yatprātaranudite dve'āhutī juhoti tadetābhyāmaparābhyāṃ padbhyāmetasminmṛtyau pratitiṣṭhati sa'enameṣa'udyannevā''dāyodeti tadetaṃ mṛtyumatimucyate
translation: The one who, at daybreak and at the close of day, offers the two oblations, does so with these initial two steps during the transition to the afterlife. Likewise, the one who performs the two oblations in the morning and afternoon remains steadfast during this transition. This practice is referred to as the awakening, through which liberation from the bondage of impending death is achieved.

sloka: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaiv~ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti ||
translation: The one, knowing this completely, causes the fuel of attachment to be consumed in the fire of discrimination and thereby makes all sinful tendencies vanish. Such a learned person performs the agnihotra sacrifice.

sloka: vasanti prāṇino yatra |
translation: In that location where living beings abide/continue to reside.

sloka: karṇaśrave'nile rātrau divā pāṃsusamūhane | etau varṣāsvanadhyāyāvadhyāyajñāḥ pracakṣate
translation: During the stillness of night and by day, as the pollen gathers during the rains of Śrāvaṇa and Bhādra, these two - the non-recitation and study - are indicated to be performed excessively in the future as those that are to be carried out in the rainy season.

sloka: vidyutstanitavarṣeṣu maholkānāṃ ca saṃplave | ākālikam anadhyām eteṣu manurabravīt etāṃstvabhyuditānvidyādyadā prāduṣkṛtāgniṣu | tadā vidyādanadhyāyam anṛtau cābhradarśane
translation: "During the occurrence of lightning storms and meteor showers, Manu proclaimed that these ancient sciences should be studied uninterruptedly. He declared that they must be continuously cultivated, even during the extinction of fires in eclipses, as well as in the periods devoid of rainfall and clear skies, at the presence of thunder-clouds."

sloka: nirghāte bhūmicalane jyotiṣāṃ copasarjane | etānākālikānvidyādanadhyāyānṛtāvapi prāduṣkṛteṣvagniṣu tu vidyutstanitaniḥsvane | sajyotiḥ syādanadhyāyaḥ śeṣe rātrau yathā divā
translation: During ground-clearing and celestial body management activities, even when stars associated with Scorpio in the zodiac appear, a knowledgeable teacher will spark flames in fires neglected during the daytime, albeit less intensely than during the day. This should be so at the end of the night, similar to how light is present during the day. The reference to periphrastic knowledge and the appearance of stars may suggest astrological or astronomical teachings, with the teacher igniting fires as a metaphor for imparting this specialized knowledge.

sloka: nīhāre bāṇaśabde ca saṃdhyayoreva cobhayoḥ | amāvāsyācaturdaśyoḥ paurṇamāsyaṣṭakāsu ca amāvāsyā guruṃ hanti śiṣyaṃ hanti caturdaśī | brahmāṣṭakapaurṇamāsyau tasmāttāḥ parivarjayet
translation: In the locative case of "mist" and "sacred syllable Om," as well as in both "twilights," you both have recited perfectly. If you wish to recite during the fourteenth phase of the new moon and the eighth day of the bright fortnight, beware! You will strike down (the asterism) Jupiter during the new moon and the fourteenth phase. Therefore, one should refrain from reciting during both new moon and full moon.

sloka: pāṃsuvarṣe diśāṃ dāhe gomāyuvirute tathā | śvakharoṣṭre ca ruvati paṅktau ca na paṭheddvijaḥ
translation: During the rains and in the scorching of the directions, in the case of pus from wounds on cattle and in a camel's dung, the twice-born does not recite (the sacred texts) on the ground or even at the bank of a river.

sloka: pratigṛhya dvijo vidvānekoddiṣṭasya ketanam | tryahaṃ na kīrtayedbrahma rājño rāhośca sūtake yāvadekānudiṣṭasya gandho lepaśca tiṣṭhati | viprasya viduṣo dehe tāvadbrahma na kīrtayet prāṇi vā yadi vāprāṇi yatkiṃ cicchrāddhikaṃ bhavet | tadālabhyāpyanadhyāyaḥ pāṇyāsyo hi dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ
translation: Upon receiving the teachings from a domestically established, dual-born scholar versed in sacred knowledge, one should not publicly declare the scholar's selection in the presence of a ruler or robber. The fragrance and symbol of the chosen one endure as long as the Brahman resides within the scholar's body. Should an animal or even breath be given more than what is prescribed, it may lead to a transgression. Only when diligently studied does the twice-born individual become eligible for such offerings.

sloka: dvāveva varjayennityaṃ anadhyāyau prayatnataḥ | svādhyāyabhūmiṃ cāśuddhaṃ ātmānaṃ cāśuciṃ dvijaḥ
translation: A twice-born person should consistently make an effort to exclusively exclude two matters from daily study: the impure self and the impure scriptural text, with uninterrupted exertion.

sloka: nādhīyītāśvaṃ ārūḍho na vṛkṣaṃ na ca hastinam | na nāvaṃ na kharaṃ noṣṭraṃ neriṇastho na yānagaḥ śayānaḥ prauḍhapādaśca kṛtvā caivāvasakthikām | nādhīyītāmiṣaṃ jagdhvā sūtakānnādyaṃ eva ca
translation: Instead of riding a horse with outstretched arms or seeking stimulation from a tree, or riding an elephant, sailing in a boat, or mounting a donkey or camel, or lying down on the ground with thickly grown legs, one should rather get up and make an effort. Likewise, instead of partaking in prey, consuming alcohol, or creating obstacles, one should refrain from such acts.

sloka: corairupadrute grāme saṃbhrame cāgnikārite | ākālikaṃ anadhyāyaṃ vidyātsarvādbhuteṣu ca
translation: In a village, during a delusion caused by fire and the sudden onset of a calamity, one should abandon for the time being the study of knowledge, personified as Durgā, using the sword's hilt in extraordinary circumstances, and interrupting the plagiarist's intermittent learning.

sloka: upākarmaṇi cotsarge trirātraṃ kṣepaṇaṃ smṛtam | aṣṭakāsu tvahorātraṃ ṛtvantāsu ca rātriṣu
translation: During the commencement of the three-day festival of Upakarma, the act of setting aside (certain) items is to be remembered; conversely, during the eighth day and night of the changing seasons, the practice is to lay out (those items).

sloka: na vivāde na kalahe na senāyāṃ na saṃgare | na bhuktamātre nājīrṇe na vamitvā na śuktake atithiṃ cānanujñāpya mārute vāti vā bhṛśam | rudhire ca srute gātrācchastreṇa ca parikṣate
translation: In the absence of quarrels, strife, armament deployment, or gatherings, when food is being tasted or left over, nor through pretense or boasting, a host should not neglect to welcome a guest. The wind blows violently, and one's worth is assessed based on praise, hearing, and physical contact, as well as bloodshed.

sloka: sāmadhvanāvṛgyajuṣī nādhīyīta kadā cana | vedasyādhītya vāpyantaṃ āraṇyakaṃ adhītya ca
translation: "Under no circumstances should the two, 'sāmadhvana' (of the son of Vasu Āpa) and 'ṛk-yajuṣī' ever be neglected; whether or not one has mastered the Vedas, they should also study the āraṇyaka."

sloka: vibhāvasubharadrājau parjanyairāvatau tathā | viśvācīsenajitsaṃjñau kārttike cādhikāriṇāḥ ||
translation: In the rainy season, are you, Vasubharat and Airavata, the ones abundantly endowed with lustrous splendor as the son of Vatsara and Bharat, named Viśvācī and Senajit, who excel in Kārttike? (Using your inherent qualities like a rain-cloud, shining brightly in the two rainy months.)

sloka: śeṣaḥ prathamato jāto vāsukistadanantaram| airāvatastakṣakaśca karkoṭakadhanañjayau||
translation: The celebrated serpent Shesha originated first, followed by Vāsuki, then came Airāvata and Takṣaka, and ultimately Karkoṭaka and Dhananjayau, the serpent-demons.

sloka: daśa krodhavaśā rāma vijajñe api ātmasaṃbhavāḥ | mṛgīm ca mṛgamaṃdām ca harīm bhadramadām api ||
translation: To Rama, the one possessing the true essence, revealed himself, born of the ten furies; even the celestial being in the form of a doe and the shining one, as well as the auspicious servant of Shiva, he subdued.

sloka: tato jajñe mahākāyaścaturdanto mahāgajaḥ| kapilā kāmavṛkṣaśca kaustubhaścāpsarogaṇaḥ|
translation: Then arose the immense one, Mahakaya, the four-tusked elephant known as Mahagaja, along with the desire-fulfilling tree Kapila, the Kaustubha gem, and the assembly of Apsaras. (Referring to four-tusked elephant, tree, jewel, and celestial beings produced during the churning of the ocean.)

sloka: pitṛṇāṃ dharmarājaṃ taṃ yamaṃ rājye'bhyaṣecayat | airāvataṃ gajendrāṇām aśeṣāṇāṃ patiṃ dadau ||
translation: The sovereign of the Kaśmīra king's lineage, Yama, was ceremoniously anointed as the future princely ruler by the forefathers, and he endowed Airavata, the lord of all elephants, with the honor of being their possessor.

sloka: śeṣantu nāgarājānaṃ mṛgāṇāṃ siṃhamīśvaram | vanaspatīnāṃ rājānaṃ plakṣamevābhyaṣecayat ||
translation: Let the serpent king named Shesha be reverently invoked, and the lord lion hailed as the sovereign of creatures. Similarly, may Plaksha, the sacred tree, be installed as the king of plants.

sloka: yo māmajamanādiṃ ca vetti lokamaheśvaram | asaṃmūḍhaḥ sa martyeṣu sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate ||
translation: The one who recognizes me, the eternal origin of all, including myself, and the lord of the world, becomes mentally clear-headed in this mortal world and is released from all sins.

sloka: maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavastathā | madbhāvā mānasā jātā yeṣāṃ loka imāḥ prajāḥ ||
translation: The seven revered seers and four human Manus, born of my intellect, are those who, in this world, have taken on various forms as the mental powers that gave rise to mankind and all other inhabitants.

sloka: etāṃ vibhūtiṃ yogaṃ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ | so'vikampena yogena yujyate nātra saṃśayaḥ ||
translation: The one who truly comprehends the manifestation of my might and my yoga system in essence, he, endowed with a protector free from tremors, joins seamlessly; there is no doubt about this.

sloka: arjuna uvāca
translation: Arjuna said aloud/read out loud.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam ||
translation: I, the imperishable one, have created the four social classes, distinguished by their inherent properties and actions. Consider me as the cause behind it, yet know me as beyond actions, immutable.

sloka: eṣāmutpattyādiryathā yadā bhagavān puruṣarūpeṇa sṛṣṭiṃ kṛtavān tadāsyaśarīrāt catvāro varṇā utpannāḥ mukhato brāhmaṇāḥ bāhutaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ūruto vaiśyāḥ pādataḥ śūdrā jātāḥ
translation: Upon the creation of the world by the lord in the form of Purusha, at that time, from His very being arose the initial quantities of a progression of four varnas (social classes) in the following order, as delineated by their origins: from the mouth, Brahmanas; from the arms, Kshatriyas; from the thighs, Vaishyas; and from the feet, Shudras.

sloka: yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | yasmāttrayo'pyāśramiṇo jñānenānnena cānvaham | gṛhasthenaiva dhāryante tasmājjyeṣṭhāśramo gṛhī |
translation: Just as all creatures depend on the life-giving wind, similarly all the stages of life exist depending on the householder. Indeed, the knowledge and insights of the first three asramis are upheld by the householder alone. Therefore, the preeminent stage is that of the grihasta (householder).

sloka: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo'dhyemi yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitrya~rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajñavidyāmetadbhagavo'dhyemi
translation: I meditate on the  Ridgeveda, hailed be you, and Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvana, the fourth; the historical account (itihasa) and Puranas are the fifth; the treasure of sacred tradition (nidhi) in speech (vak), knowledge of devas, brahma, and elements (bhutavidya), kshatra-vidya, nakshatra-vidya, sarpadeva-jna-vidya - all these I meditate upon.

sloka: ahaṃ tṛtīya ityatristasmādatriḥ sa kīrtyate ||
translation: I am referred to as the third one, designated Tritiya, while Brahma, descendant of Atri, is known by that name due to me.

sloka: atrivaṃśasamutpanno brahmayoniḥ sanātanaḥ| prācīnabahirbhagavāṃstasmātprācetaso daśa||
translation: Born from the immortal branch of the Atri lineage, associated with the ancient and venerable Brahma, he is the supreme being located on the outside. As a result, he possesses the ten qualities of Prācetas, the seer related to Varuṇa.

sloka: daśānāṃ tanayastveko dakṣo nāma prajāpatiḥ| tasya dve nāmanī loke dakṣaḥ ka iti cocyate||
translation: Of the descendants of ten, one being known as Dakshana, skilled is; of him, in this world, the two names 'Dakshana' and 'Prajapati' are used; who is referred to as 'Dakshana'?

sloka: vāgevātrirvācā hyannamadyate'ttirha vai nāmaitadyadatririti | sarvasyāttā bhavati sarvamasyānnambhavati | ya evaṃ veda |
translation: In the realm of speech, the threefold *vāc* is manifest in designations such as "anna" (food) and "mati" (thought), etc. The individual self of all becomes intertwined with everything, and everything transforms into the self of each. One who understands this profound truth knows it through experience.

sloka: svāminaḥ sevanaṃ dṛṣṭvā śivasya ca parātmanaḥ || sādhvi dharmaṃ ca te dṛṣṭvā sthitāsmi tava sannidhau ||
translation: Having witnessed the adoration of the revered Lord Shiva and his own Self, I have observed your compliance with righteousness as a virtuous woman. I stand in your presence, for I abide by your visibility, being the highest personal principle of life, as a learned Brāhman would.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā nātiprabhaṃ somaṃ tathā sūryaṃ ca pārthiva| prakāśamakarodatristapasā svena saṃyuge| jagadvitimiraṃ cāpi pradīptamakarottadā||
translation: Upon beholding the exceptionally radiant moon and Sun, Atri, the lord of earth, cause them to gleam more brightly in his very own battle, employing his tapas. You two as well vanquished the cosmic darkness, causing it to be illuminated at that moment.

sloka: sarvaṃ hīdaṃ prāṇenā''vṛtam iti | so'yamākāśaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdhastadyathā'yamākāśaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdha | evaṃ sarvāṇi bhūtāni āpipīlikābhyaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdhānītyevaṃ vidyāt iti ||
translation: Everything known in this world is enveloped by the life-breath; similarly, this free space is expansive due to that powerful life-breath. Likewise, understand that all beings, from ants to the largest, are pervaded by that same life-breath, expanded in them. This is the knowledge one should have.

sloka: āyuḥ prāṇaḥ prāṇo vā āyuḥ prāṇa evācāmṛtam | yāvaddhyasmiñcharīre prāṇo vasati tāvadāyuḥ |
translation: "Is life (prāṇaḥ), merely the same as breath (āyuḥ), or is breath a means to immortality (amṛtam)? Assuredly, for as long as breath abides within this body, one has vital power up to that point."

sloka: prāṇena sṛṣṭāvantarikṣaṃ ca vāyuśca | antarikṣaṃ vā anucaranti antarikṣamanuśṛṇvanti | vāyurasmai puṇyaṃ gandhamāvahati | evametau prāṇaṃ pitaraṃ paricarato'ntarikṣaṃ ca vāyuśca |
translation: "Oh life-force (Prāṇa), just as the air (vāyu) and the atmosphere (antarikṣam) conduct themselves and are called to be heard in the atmosphere, similarly they carry auspicious scents for it. In such a manner, the atmosphere and wind serve the life-force, being its regents."

sloka: taṃ devāḥ prāṇayanta sa praṇītaḥ prātāyata prātāyītī~ tatprātarabhavatsamāgāditī~ tatsāyamabhavadahareva prāṇo rātrirapānaḥ iti |
translation: The gods started to reinvigorate him at that dawn; he was reestablished at daybreak, fully alive; then breath, day, and night resumed immediately.

sloka: vāgagniścakṣurasāvādityaścandramā mano diśaḥ śrotraṃ sa eṣa prahitāṃ saṃyogo'dhyātmamimā devatā ada u āviradhidaivatamityetattaduktaṃ bhavati iti |
translation: This is identified as the union of speech, personified as Agni, along with the radiant sun, likened to a Soma libation (Sāva), and Āditya as the moon; the mind as Man, the directions as hearing, and all these collectively constitute the inner divinity (adhyātmam), as previously declared.

sloka: pūrvajanma kṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyādhi rūpeṇa bādhate | tata śāṃtiroṣadhedāneṃ mantra japa homa surāracaneṃ ||
translation: The evil deeds (pāpa) of one's previous birth (pūrvajanma), manifest (bādhate) in the form of ailments (vyādhi-rūpeṇa). To alleviate this, oh calm one (tata śāntira), engage in recitation of mantras, perform homas and fire rituals (mantra-japa-homa), and offer libations during sacrifices to the gods (surāracaneṃ).

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: May they always live nourished by righteousness and immortality, or by deceit and mortality. One should never maintain life through false subsistence. The pure form of truth is to be known as immortal. On the other hand, deceitful commerce is considered transient. By these very means, one sustains life. Service, referred to as mundane livelihood, is to be avoided.

sloka: ato'nyatamayā vṛttyā jīvaṃstu snātako dvijaḥ | svargāyuṣyayaśasyāni vratāṇīmāni dhārayet
translation: Henceforth, a thrice-born man who has completed his purification ritual should maintain these two observances - increasing lifespan (svarga-ayushya-shasyani) and upholding vows (vratani) - in a restrained manner (anyatamaya vrttya), as permitted for a Brahman. Indeed, let him cause them to be held (dhārayet).

sloka: vedam evābhyasennityaṃ yathākām atandritaḥ | taṃ hyasyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo'nya ucyate
translation: One should constantly and tirelessly rehearse the Veda according to one's desire, for it is stated that this is his foremost duty (param dharma). Everything else is referred to as a departure from duty (upadharma).

sloka: klptakeśanakhaśmaśrurdāntaḥ śuklāmbaraḥ śuciḥ | svādhyāye caiva yuktaḥ syānnityaṃ ātmahiteṣu ca
translation: With properly groomed hair and pure at its ends, dressed in white apparel and in a state of purity, constantly engaged in studying the Vedas and being fit for one's own highest personal benefit, should be one's constant practice.

sloka: sarvānparityajedarthānsvādhyāyasya virodhinaḥ | yathā tathādhyāpayaṃstu sā hyasya kṛtakṛtyatā
translation: He should abandon all studies that conflict with his (Krishna's) own reflection on religion, for it is assuredly his obligatory duty to fully discharge any duty or realize any object in accordance with what is right and in whatever manner taught.

sloka: buddhivṛddhikarāṇyāśu dhanyāni ca hitāni ca | nityaṃ śāstrāṇyavekṣeta nigamāṃścaiva vaidikān | yathā yathā hi puruṣaḥ śāstraṃ samadhigacchati | tathā tathā vijānāti vijñānaṃ cāsya rocate
translation:
Indeed, one should constantly examine those means to increase knowledge and auspicious actions (dhanyāni hitāni ca), whether they relate to the Vaiśyas in Krauñca-dvīpa or not (āśu). Moreover, one should pay constant attention to the scriptures (nityam śāstrāṇi) and Vedic texts (nigamāṃścaiva vaidikān), just as a follower of the Sāṃkhya Philosophy does.
As one consumes knowledge through scriptures (puruṣaḥ śāstram samadhigacchati), they come to understand and appreciate that knowledge in their own unique way (tathā vijānāti). The delight found in such worldly or profane knowledge is what characterizes the individual (vijñānam āsya rocate).

sloka: vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca | adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm paurvikīṃ saṃsmaranjātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ | brahmābhyāsena cājasraṃ anantaṃ sukhaṃ aśnute
translation: By constantly studying the Vedas, maintaining integrity, and performing religious austerities, you as a lord, should remember the true states of sense objects. By practicing Brahma-knowledge repeatedly, one attains constant, immense bliss willingly.

sloka: ṛṣiyajñaṃ devayajñaṃ bhūtayajñaṃ ca sarvadā | nṛyajñaṃ pitṛyajñaṃ ca yathāśakti na hāpayet
translation: One should continually offer the ṛṣi-yajña, deva-yajña, bhūta-yajña, and, according to one's ability, naively perform nṛ-yajña and pitr-yajña.

sloka: etāneke mahāyajñānyajñaśāstravido janāḥ | anīhamānāḥ satataṃ indriyeṣveva juhvati vācyeke juhvati prāṇaṃ prāṇe vācaṃ ca sarvadā | vāci prāṇe ca paśyanto yajñanirvṛttiṃ akṣayām
translation: Scholars of the great sacrifices' scriptures, who are truly sincere, consistently offer their powers of perception as acts of worship, sometimes dedicating their speech and breath of life. They constantly behold the unending fulfillment achieved through sacrifice, being ever mindful of this in their speech and breath.

sloka: jñānenaivāpare viprā yajantyetairmakhaiḥ sadā | jñānamūlāṃ kriyāṃ eṣāṃ paśyanto jñānacakṣuṣā
translation: With sacred knowledge as their sole approach in prayer, Brahmins consistently worship through such false ritualistic acts. Perceiving the origin of actions, they are the knowing seers, observing with the eye of wisdom.

sloka: agnihotraṃ ca juhuyādādyante dyuniśoḥ sadā | darśena cārdhamāsānte paurṇāmāsena caiva hi
translation: Indeed, may an offering to Agni be made, perpetually at the start and end of daylight hours, as well as during the new moon day with its half phase and the full moon day, with the intention of honoring and serving.

sloka: sāvitrāñ śāntihomāṃśca kuryātparvasu nityaśaḥ | pitṝṃścaivāṣṭakāsvarcennityaṃ anvaṣṭakāsu ca
translation: One should regularly chant the Savitri verse during specific times and offer oblations in the fires as a daily ritual. Similarly, one should constantly honor their ancestors with reverence during the eighth phase of the moon.

sloka: rājato dhanam anvicchetsaṃsīdansnātakaḥ kṣudhā | yājyāntevāsinorvāpi na tvanyata iti sthitiḥ
translation: A person should seek any valued object only from a Yaksha, being one who has bathed or performed ablutions and is named "kṣudhā." The state of being settled near the fire altar or the dwelling of the officiating priest, whether as a sacrifice or not, should be adopted with devotion and regarded as separate from any other motive.

sloka: na sīdetsnātako vipraḥ kṣudhā śaktaḥ kathaṃ cana | na jīrṇamalavadvāsā bhavecca vibhave sati
translation: How could a domestic priest, who has bathed and purified himself, succumb to despondency even from hunger, much less when he is not destitute? And how could one, whose clothes are not decayed and tattered, ever become so, as long as he possesses means?

sloka: daśa sūṇāsahasrāṇi yo vāhayati saunikaḥ | tena tulyaḥ smṛto rājā ghorastasya pratigrahaḥ yo rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇāti lubdhasyocchāstravartinaḥ | sa paryāyeṇa yātīmānnarakānekaviṃśatim etadvidanto vidvāṃso brāhmaṇā brahmavādinaḥ | na rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇanti pretya śreyo'bhikāṅkṣiṇaḥ
translation: The ruler capable of mobilizing ten thousand chariots is considered equivalent in power to Saunika. The one who accepts such a king's tribute is equated with one who, despite being unversed in scriptures, is greedy. This is similar to one who, for the sake of greater good, does not accept the king's tribute after his death. Scholars, proficient in the Vedas, understand this.

sloka: vayasaḥ karmaṇo'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca | veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyaṃ ācaranvicarediha śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅnibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu | dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāraṃ atandritaḥ ācārāllabhate hyāyurācārādīpsitāḥ prajāḥ | ācārāddhanaṃ akṣayyaṃ ācāro hantyalakṣaṇam
translation: Investigate the purpose of actions, lineage, hearing, and scriptural traditions; aspire to conform to the example set by those who have realized the unity of speech, intellect, and conduct. Rigorously adhere to the established codes of conduct in your own actions, being steadfast at all times. Indeed, one gains longevity, cherished offspring, and undying wealth through virtuous conduct; moreover, it is conduct that determines what is worthy and unworthy.

sloka: sarvalakṣaṇahīno'pi yaḥ sadācāravānnaraḥ | śraddadhāno'nasūyaśca śataṃ varṣāṇi jīvati durācāro hi puruṣo loke bhavati ninditaḥ | duḥkhabhāgī ca satataṃ vyādhito'lpāyureva ca
translation: Even if one, bereft of all distinguishing marks, may be a person of great character and righteous behavior, they live for a hundred years, dispelling doubts and free from ill-will or envy. However, a man in this world who engages in bad behavior is reviled, constantly suffering, often sickly, and has a short lifespan.

sloka: na pāṇipādacapalo na netracapalo'nṛjuḥ | na syādvākcapalaścaiva na paradrohakarmadhīḥ yenāsya pitaro yātā yena yātāḥ pitāmahāḥ | tena yāyātsatāṃ mārgaṃ tena gacchanna riṣyati vairiṇaṃ nopaseveta sahāyaṃ caiva vairiṇaḥ | adhārmikaṃ taskaraṃ ca parasyaiva ca yoṣitam | na hīdṛśaṃ anāyuṣyaṃ loke kiṃ cana vidyate | yādṛśaṃ puruṣasyeha paradāropasevanam |
translation: One who is not ill-mannered in the use of hands and feet, nor deceitful in his gaze and speech, not prone to causing harm through actions or instigating enmity; for whom his ancestors have followed this path of righteousness, as have his great-grandfathers. He should adopt that very path, for it will lead him to his destination. He must avoid companionship with and service to the unrighteous thief and another's wife. Such behavior is seldom found in the world, let alone engaged in by someone possessing discernment and self-restraint.

sloka: maṅgalācārayuktānāṃ nityaṃ ca prayatātmanām | japatāṃ juhvatāṃ caiva vinipāto na vidyate
translation: For those who consistently follow the established rules of auspicious conduct and are deeply introspective, as well as those who regularly engage in recitations and offerings, there is no fear of a great fall.

sloka: dṛḍhakārī mṛdurdāntaḥ krūrācārairasaṃvasan | ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayetsvargaṃ tathāvrataḥ
translation: One who is intensely steadfast, tamed, and situated in supreme peacefulness, avoids association with cruel behavior, remains harmless, exercises self-restraint, and gives charitably, will surely attain the heavenly realm.

sloka: anena vipro vṛttena vartayanvedaśāstravit | vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate
translation: Through this virtuous conduct, a Brāhman, versed in Vedic teachings and cleansed of all stains, continually attains exaltation among the inhabitants of the world, becoming joyous in Brahma's abode.

sloka: sākṣāt mokṣasādhanāni imāni ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyo mantavyo nididhyāsitavyaḥ | bṛhadāraṇyakopaniṣat
translation: These very means to emancipation should be personally experienced, listened to, pondered over, and diligently meditated upon; they are to be comprehended and intellectually discerned in the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad.

sloka: kaṇādena tu saṃproktaṃ śāstraṃ vaiśeṣikaṃ mahat | gautamena tathā nyāyaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ tu kapilena vai ||
translation: Kaṇāda, I now address you regarding the distinguished Vaiśeshika śāstra. Similarly, Gautama has expounded upon Nyāya philosophy, and Kapila has elucidated Sāṃkhya doctrine.

sloka: prajāvatā vacasā vahnirāsā ca huve ni ca satsīha devaiḥ | veṣi hotramuta potraṃ yajatra bodhi prayantarjanitarvasūnām ||
translation: By procreation-granting speech, the fire god, together with his wife (the goddess of speech), assumes the role of a burnt offering priest at sacrifices for the gods, exhorting as protector of offspring, worthy of worship, and inspiring insight in all beings.

sloka: yo adhvareṣu śaṃtama ṛtāvā hotā tamū namobhirā kṛṇudhvam | agniryadvermartāya devānsa cā bodhāti manasā yajāti ||
translation: The one who is eminent among those engaged in sacrificial rites, you all should honor him with reverential salutations. For, he indeed awakens the gods in the mind of the performer during the fire-ritual known as 'Agni Marta'.

sloka: abhi tvā gotamā girā jātavedo vicarṣaṇe dayumnairabhi para ṇonumaḥ jātavedase sunavā masomamarātīyato ni dahāti vedaḥ sa naḥ parṣadati durgāṇi viśvā nāveva sindhuṃ duritātyagniḥ agnirasmi janmanā jātavedā ghartaṃ me cakṣuramṛtaṃ ma āsana arkastridhātū rajaso vimānoajasro gharmo havirasmi nāma
translation: Drawing near to you, Gotama, with laudatory speech, Jatavedas, I exhort you to recite the Vedic hymns, to ignite the fire that eliminates all adversities for us. You are the fire born of creation, Jatavedas, my eye, ever-existing and radiant, signifying life force in all beings, the oblation; I recognize you by name. (Approaching you, Gotama, with kind words, Jatavedas, I urge you to recite the Vedic hymns, to ignite the fire currently illuminating and dispelling all unrighteousness for us. You are the fire brought into existence by creation, Jatavedas, my eye, ever-existing and radiant, signifying living force in all beings, the oblation; I recognize you by name.)

sloka: hotāraṃ viśvavedasaṃ saṃ hi tvā viśa indhate | sa ā vaha puruhūta pracetaso 'gne devā~ iha dravat ||
translation: The Hotr, specifically of the universal Veda, indeed, invokes on your behalf, Indra, Agni, the radiant and insightful god; here, the gods attentive to this call, hasten forth.

sloka: jarābodha tadviviḍḍhi viśeviśe yajñiyāya stomaṃ rudrāya dṛśikam
translation: "Awakening one who recognizes the transient nature, serve diligently in relation to that (Rudra's) doctrine through a ritual hymn dedicated to the revered and powerful Rudra, worthy of worship."

sloka: tvamagnerudro asuro maho divastvaṃ śardho mārutaṃ pṛkṣa īśiṣe
translation: You, the consort of an Asura, identified as Agni's enemy, reside in the divine realm, holding immense power, and possessing a significant portion of the wind.

sloka: sa eva puruṣaḥ prajāpatirabhavat sa yaḥ sa puruṣaḥ prajāpatirabhavat ayameva saḥ yo'yamagniścīyate kāṇḍikā
translation: Indeed, it was Brahma, the son of Manu Cākshusha, known as Savitṛi, who came into being. He is the one who has now become manifest as this very Agni, named Kandika.

sloka: tataḥ yaḥ jātagarbhaḥ saḥ agniḥ asṛjyata tasmāt sarvasya sthūlaprapañcasya agram ādau sṛṣṭatvāt agnirityucyate tam agrim idānīntanā agnināmnā vyavahāraṃ kurvanti kāṇḍikā
translation: After that, the one who was born (jātagarbhaḥ) from the womb, namely Brahma, gave rise to (asṛjyata) the fire (agniḥ). This fire is known as Agni because it was the first (ādau) to create (sṛṣṭatvāt) the gross physical world (sthūlaprapañcasya). They now conduct their interactions (vyavahāraṃ kurvanti) using the appellation "Agni" for this fire, as referred to in the Kāṇḍikā text.

sloka: vāyuranilamamṛtamathedaṃ bhasmāntam śarīram | oṃ krato smara kṛtam smara krato smara kṛtam smara ||
translation: "Surely, as Vāyu, haven't you pervaded this transient body with the divine immortal essence, Anilam? Oh Krato, remember, I urge you, the deeds accomplished by the son of Vasudeva."

sloka: agne naya supathā rāye asmānviśvāni deva vayunāni vidvān | yuyodhyasmajjuhurāṇameno bhūyiṣṭhāṃ te nama uktiṃ vidhema ||
translation: "Agni, possessing prudence, having good roads, be our guide for success. You, as a godly image, know all the worlds' wisdom. May we, overcoming obstacles, gain the most abundant fortune. To you, our reverential speech of worship."

sloka: te'gnimabruvan jātaveda etadvijānīhi kimetadyakṣamiti tatheti ||
translation: Addressing the fire-god, Agni, they ask: "Reveal the exact nature of this mysterious entity." He responds: "I will accurately disclose it to you." (Referring to the offering being made to the fire)

sloka: tadabhyadravattamabhyavadat ko'sītyagnirvā ahamasmītyabravījjātavedā vā ahamasmīti ||
translation: Approaching that one, he inquired, "Who are you?" In response, Agni revealed his identity, saying, "I am indeed he," while the other, now manifest, declared, "I am the Vedas."

sloka: tasmiṃstvayi kiṃ vīryamityapīdaṃ sarvaṃ daheyaṃ yadidaṃ pṛthivyāmiti ||
translation: In you, what is this manliness or prowess being measured? I must offer/submit everything related to Krishna here in this world. This is my resolve.

sloka: tasmai tṛṇaṃ nidadhāvetaddaheti tadupapreyāya sarvajavena tanna śaśāka dagdhum | sa tata evanivavṛte naitadaśakaṃ vijñātuṃ yadetadyakṣamiti ||
translation: To that very fortune, they should offer the grass; "Burn this!" they command, as a fitting tribute. Yet, even he, that powerful being, could not be consumed by it. Thus, he enveloped (the fire) there itself, unable to comprehend that it was merely of ten finger-widths.

sloka: pra te bravīmi tadu me nibodha svargyamagniṃ naciketaḥ prajānan | anantalokāptimatho pratiṣṭhāṃ viddhi tvametaṃ nihitaṃ guhāyām || ||
translation: To you, I speak of this that you should understand, Naciketa. The fire (agnim), leading to the heavenly world (svargya), learn that is established (pratiṣṭhām) through endless procreation (ananta-prajā). Indeed, it is placed (nihitam) in the hidden (guhāyām).

sloka: lokādimagniṃ tamuvāca tasmai yā iṣṭakā yāvatīrvā yathā vā | sa cāpi tatpratyavadadyathoktaṃ athāsya mṛtyuḥ punarevāha tuṣṭaḥ ||
translation: The foremost among the inhabitants of the world, addressing that third part of the Sāman (agni), spoke these words to him: "Whatever offerings you desire, as many as they may be, presented in whatever way" - he responded in a like manner. Thereupon, his death satisfied, it came again repeatedly.

sloka: sa etaṃ devayānaṃ panthānamāpadyāgnilokamāgacchatisa vāyulokaṃ sa ādityalokaṃ
translation: He makes his way to that very path, the sect of the divine way known as "Agni's domain," while she, identified with the wind and the sun, does the same.

sloka: yasyāgnihotramadarśamapaurṇamāsamacāturmāsyamanāgrayaṇamatithivarjitaṃ ca ahutamavaiśvadevamavidhinā hutamāsasaptamāṃ stasya lokānhinasti
translation: Of the one whose new and full moon fire rituals, the start of each season's sacrifices, and the bi-monthly sacrifices, excluding the occasional animal sacrifice conducted with proper rites, are absent, their worlds (i.e., the realms of righteous living beings) cease to exist.

sloka: agnimīl̤e purohitaṃ yajñasya devamṛtvijam | hotāraṃ ratnadhātamam ||
translation: As the priest officiating at the sacrifice, the fire-god is the divinity revered with oblations, the supreme sacrificer, and the generous bestower of wealth.

sloka: śākalyaseya śataṃ śiṣyā naiṣṭhikabrahmacāriṇaḥ pañca teṣāṃ gṛhasthāste dharmaniṣṭhāśca kuṭumbinaḥ śiśiro vāṣkalo sāṃkhyo vātsyaścaivāśvalāyanaḥ pañcaite śākalāḥ śiṣyāḥ śākhābhedapravarttakāḥ
translation: The five disciples of Śākalyaseya, namely Śiśira, Vātsya, and Āśvalāyana (who is also known as the initiator of branch divisions), will in the future become a hundred devoted students. They will steadfastly adhere to their respective duties as householders and heads of families. These five disciples are the leaders of those branches.

sloka: ādityānīmāni śuklāni yajūṃṣi vājasaneyena yājñavalkyenākhyāyante
translation: The bright hymns of the Yajurveda, known as the Vājasaneya and belonging to the school of Yājñavalkya, are being recited in this world at present by Āditya.

sloka: tallakṣaṇamāha jaiminiḥ gīteṣusāmākhyā iti gīyamāneṣu mantreṣu sāmasaṃjñetyarthaḥ iti
translation: Jaimini, after referring to the Ardea Sibirica's characteristic, declares that in the sacred songs being sung, it is acknowledged as "sama," a type of Vedic hymn. This is the personified meaning of "sañjñā" (identification).

sloka: sā cāmaśceti tatsāmnaḥ sāmatvam |
translation: She, together with what is indicated by āma, embodies equanimity.

sloka: sahastravartmā sāmavedaḥ
translation: The track of the Sama Veda's wheel of wealth.

sloka: ‘karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: "Brāhmaṇa's actions serve as promoters of spiritual advancement."

sloka: araṇye'dhīyūrān
translation: Those two who have assumed the role of protectors in the wilderness.

sloka: kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti || mṛtyave tvā dadāmīti ||
translation: To whom should I offer myself, or to the god of death should I give you?

sloka: svāntaḥprāṇākṣivāṇīprabhṛti ca viṣayābhāsakaṃ yasya yogād yanna prāpnoti caitadviditaṃ yadbhavennātmarūpam| indrādyā devamukhyā api kila na viduryasya śaktiṃ nigūḍhāṃ tadbuddhaṃ yena so'sau bhavati naravaro'nantasaukhyapratiṣṭhaḥ ||
translation: The individual who has mastered self-control over the life-forces (prāṇa) and attained the manifestation of sensual elegance (viṣaya-ābhāsa), as stated in the second person plural perfect indicative active tense, such a one, through their own experience (yoga), does not achieve this understanding. This true form of oneself remains undiscovered by great beings like Indra and other leading deities, who are considered intelligent. The fully enlightened one's hidden power (nigūḍhā śakti) is incomprehensible to them. Becoming the source of limitless happiness for humans, this individual stands firmly as the eternal spirit pervading the universe (ananta-saukhya-pratiṣṭhaḥ nara-varaḥ).

sloka: vaiśvānaraḥ praviśati atithirbrāhmaṇo gṛhān | tasyaitā~ śāntiṃ kurvanti hara vaivasvatodakam ||
translation: The universally pervasive fire (Agni), in the role of a guest, enters the brahmin's residence. They appease him with tranquility by offering the water oblation from Vaivasvat's (the sun's) share.

sloka: ki~svidyamasya kartavyaṃ yanmayā'dya kariṣyati ||
translation: What indeed is the duty that I should be carrying out today as my priority?

sloka: tamabravītprīyamāṇo mahātmā varaṃ tavehādya dadāmi bhūyaḥ | tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa ||
translation: The great-souled one, highly pleased, addressed him, "I bestow upon you an unprecedented reward today. You will abundantly be known by my very name and become famous. Take this form of multiple aspects for yourself. Embrace it."

sloka: yeyaṃ prete vicikitsā manuṣye astītyeke nāyamastīti caike | etadvidyāmanuśiṣṭastvayā'haṃ varāṇāmeṣa varastṛtīyaḥ ||
translation: Of the conflicting views among people about a deceased individual's existence or non-existence, one who has mastered this knowledge gains certainty. Here, having acquired such wisdom, I stand as the third desirable alternative.

sloka: yasminnidaṃ vicikitsanti mṛtyo yatsāmparāye mahati brūhi nastat | yo'yaṃ varo gūḍhamanupraviṣṭo nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte ||
translation: In which is this being doubted as death approaches during the great crisis of the 12th day in the light half of Bhādrapada; tell us that very fortune which this excellence, secretly entered, is. Therefore, let Naciketā not choose any other but that very fortune.

sloka: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā | astīti bruvato'nyatra kathaṃ tadupalabhyate ||
translation: It cannot be attained through mere speech, mind, or sight, as some assert; but how can it be experienced otherwise?

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū | brahmajajñaṃ devamīḍyaṃ viditvā nicāyya mā~ śāntimatyantameti ||
translation: After comprehending the deity Brahmajajña, identified as īḍya, and contemplating the three acts that Triṇāciketa carries out using the three fires, one transcends the cycle of birth and death. Having fully grasped this knowledge, I have attained ultimate peace; do not disturb it.

sloka: triṇāciketastrayametadviditvā ya evaṃ vidvā~ ścinute nāciketam | sa mṛtyupāśānpurataḥ praṇodya śokātigo modate svargaloke ||
translation: After comprehending the three-footed fire and recognizing the significance of the 'Atharvaveda, Nahkayaniya section, Naciketopakhyana' (the story of Naciketa), if one truly learns and recites it, they will experience unbounded joy in the heavenly world, liberated from the clutches of proximity to death and sorrow.

sloka: nehetārthānprasaṅgena na viruddhena karmaṇā | na vidyamāneṣvartheṣu nārtyāṃ api yatastataḥ indriyārtheṣu sarveṣu na prasajyeta kāmataḥ | atiprasaktiṃ caiteṣāṃ manasā saṃnivartayet
translation: Let not one, possessed of discernment, engage in actions at odds with or contrary to the pursuit of these objectives. Nor should he lose control over his senses when partaking in diverse activities. Instead, he should exercise restraint over his own mind, preventing it from becoming overly devoted (to such pursuits) and veering into excess.

sloka: pratigrahasamartho'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet | pratigraheṇa hyasyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati naitādṛśaḥ paro dharmo nṛṇāṃ saddharmamicchatām nyāso daṇḍasya bhūteṣu manovākkāyajasya yaḥ
translation: Although capable of accepting gifts, one should refrain from unnecessary entanglements there. For, such acceptance diminishes the Brahmin's spiritual power and isn't in line with the righteous path for those seeking the ultimate virtue. This refers to the assignment of punishment to beings based on their actions through mind, speech, and body - it is what he is.

sloka: parasya daṇḍaṃ nodyacchetkruddho nainaṃ nipātayet | anyatra putrācchiṣyādvā śiṣṭyarthaṃ tāḍayettu tau brāhmaṇāyāvaguryaiva dvijātirvadhakāmyayā | śataṃ varṣāṇi tāmisre narake parivartate tāḍayitvā tṛṇenāpi saṃrambhānmatipūrvakam | ekaviṃśatīṃ ājātīḥ pāpayoniṣu jāyate
translation: The Brahmin, intent on meting out punishment, should not wield another's rod of authority in wrath or strike him. Instead, he should encourage a son to study for the sake of discipline or gently admonish others respectfully. If he punishes with a rod, even slightly, he will revolve in the foul hell called Tamisra for a hundred years. After striking and killing 216 beings born from sinful wombs, he himself becomes subject to being struck.

sloka: ayudhyamānasyotpādya brāhmaṇasyāsṛgaṅgataḥ | duḥkhaṃ sumahadāpnoti pretyāprājñatayā naraḥ śoṇitaṃ yāvataḥ pāṃsūnsaṃgṛhṇāti mahītalāt | tāvato'bdānamutrānyaiḥ śoṇitotpādako'dyate na kadā ciddvije tasmādvidvānavaguredapi | na tāḍayettṛṇenāpi na gātrātsrāvayedasṛk
translation: While preparing the sacrificial fire for a Brahmin engaged in his duties, a person does not undergo significant suffering after death due to ignorance. The person only collects as much soil as contained in a pāṃsūna (a handful) until their end, and an equivalent amount of sinful reactions are generated. However, one should never strike with any gramineous plant or cause bodily effusion, even in the case of one born or produced in or at pure thought, what to speak of others.

sloka: satyadharmāryavṛtteṣu śauce caivārametsadā | śiṣyāṃśca śiṣyāddharmeṇa vāgbāhūdarasaṃyataḥ parityajedarthakāmau yau syātāṃ dharmavarjitau | dharmaṃ cāpyasukhodarkaṃ lokasaṃkruṣṭaṃ eva ca
translation: In the dedicated pursuit of sincerity (truth) and Āryan behavior, as well as righteousness, if one becomes pure in conduct, integrates speech, the actions of a prince, and inner resolve, and voluntarily lets go of material desires, even if they forsake religion itself - which is delightful, distressing to the world, and associated with happiness (and sorrow) - such a person is completely surrendered.

sloka: na sīdannapi dharmeṇa mano'dharme niveśayet | adhārmikānāṃ pāpānāṃ āśu paśyanviparyayam
translation: Out of fear that it may succumb to despondency or soften, one should not force the mind to adhere to the ethical precepts of Buddhism against its will. Upon observing the immoral quickly change their purpose or conduct, one should recognize and acknowledge their sins.

sloka: bhadraṃ bhadraṃ iti brūyādbhadraṃ ityeva vā vadet | śuṣkavairaṃ vivādaṃ ca na kuryātkena citsaha
translation: Speak auspiciousness, proclaim it indeed; or merely express it as well. One should avoid engaging in a mere quarrel, what to say of a petty feud. Together with awareness, one shouldn't reduce anything to such trivial disputes.

sloka: yadyatparavaśaṃ karma tattadyatnena varjayet | yadyadātmavaśaṃ tu syāttattatseveta yatnataḥ yatkarma kurvato'sya syātparitoṣo'ntarātmanaḥ | tatprayatnena kurvīta viparītaṃ tu varjayet
translation: Perform the religious acts that you are merely submissive to with deliberate effort, and abandon those that can be avoided. Seek to practice or employ your highest personal principle in all ways possible; this brings inner satisfaction. Diligently do what needs to be done, and reject with caution anything that should not be done. Additionally, reduce anything to continuous exertion and intensify ideas with caution.

sloka: śraddhayeṣṭaṃ ca pūrtaṃ ca nityaṃ kuryādatandritaḥ | śraddhākṛte hyakṣaye te bhavataḥ svāgatairdhanaiḥ dānadharmaṃ niṣeveta nityaṃ aiṣṭikapaurtikam | parituṣṭena bhāvena pātraṃ āsādya śaktitaḥ
translation: The devout individual should consistently make an effort to attain and accomplish (their) duties with unwavering dedication. Indeed, the fortune amassed from such dutiful actions fosters the growth of faith. With a content heart, one should regularly engage in charity, adhering to the scriptural path of both Aishṭika and Paurtika. Upon encountering a worthy recipient, one should establish (the charity) with power and ability.

sloka: yatkiṃ cidapi dātavyaṃ yācitenānasūyayā | utpatsyate hi tatpātraṃ yattārayati sarvataḥ sarveṣāṃ eva dānānāṃ brahmadānaṃ viśiṣyate | vāryannagomahīvāsas tilakāñcanasarpiṣām
translation: Whatever there is to be given, whether it's an object or intangible (like knowledge), when respectfully requested without arrogance, its recipient is the one who wholeheartedly accepts it from every direction. Among all gifts, the gift of sacred knowledge stands out as the most excellent. Similarly, a person esteemed by all, pure in character, clothed in white, and adorned with sandalwood and gold marks is truly distinguished.

sloka: yena yena tu bhāvena yadyaddānaṃ prayacchati | tattattenaiva bhāvena prāpnoti pratipūjitaḥ yo'rcitaṃ pratigṛhṇāti dadātyarcitaṃ eva vā | tāvubhau gacchataḥ svargaṃ narakaṃ tu viparyaye
translation: By whatever mental disposition one offers something, be it through a reverential state of mind or with the intention to take away, honor, or sell, by that same disposition they will attain respect and acceptance. Those two (the giver and receiver) will reach their respective fates - the bright sky or place of torment - based on whether their actions are carried out in the right or wrong way.

sloka: yajño'nṛtena kṣarati tapaḥ kṣarati vismayāt | āyurviprāpavādena dānaṃ ca parikīrtanāt
translation: The sacrifice thrives through righteous agriculture, while religious austerity does so through the dispelling of arrogance. Vital power, associated with the sacred fig tree, is increased through renowned generosity, which is highly praised and widely circulated.

sloka: dharmarājaḥ pitṛpatiḥ samavartī paretarāṭ kṛtānto yamunābhrātā śamano yamarāḍ yamaḥ kālo daṇḍadharaḥ śrādhdadevo vaivasvatontakaḥ
translation: The upholder of dharma, the lord of ancestors, associated with the Yamunā's brother, the tamer of the wild, the one who has fulfilled duties, the god Shraddhadeva, and Vaivasvatontaka are all names of Yama. This deity of death, as the controller of time, carries the staff, signifying his role as enforcer of justice (daṇḍadharaḥ).

sloka: yacchati upa ramayati jivitam sarvam bhuta graman iti yamaha
translation: The one who gives everything, including life, making all beings delight, is referred to as the killer (of death), Yama.

sloka: yathā candraśca rohiṇyāmurmilāyāṃ dhaneśvaraḥ|| yatra rājā vaivasvato yatrāvarodhanaṃ divaḥ yatrāmūryahvatīrāpastatra māmamṛtaṃ kṛdhīndrāyendo pari srava
translation:
In the manner that the moon, the most excellent among lights, merges with Rohini,
and the lord of wealth gleams; where Yudhishthira, the king, is,
where the division between day and night lies, where dawn and sunset occur,
make me immortal there, O Indra, in your abundant flow along with your world of immortality.

sloka: naciketamupākhyānaṃ mṛtyuproktaṃ sanātanam
translation: The story of Nachiketa, referred to as eternal, has been recounted by the god of disease, Death.

sloka: ati drava sārameyau śvānau caturakṣau śabalau sādhunā pathā athā pitṝntsuvidatrānupehi yamena ye sadhamādaṃ madanti
translation: With a sincere heart, cause the two swift and sturdy dogs, adorned with collars, to eagerly follow the virtuous path of religious observance. Together with the offerings, let them partake in the enjoyment that comes from these two, assisted by Yama.

sloka: dharati lokān dhriyate puṇyātmabhiriti vā |
translation: The world(s) are upheld by the virtuous through their dutiful actions, borne by the sun, and so forth, or possibly in another manner.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ |
translation: The supreme duty is established rule of conduct.

sloka: maitraṃ prasādhanaṃ snānaṃ dantadhāvanaṃ añjanam | pūrvāhṇa eva kurvīta devatānāṃ ca pūjanam dūrādāvasathānmūtraṃ dūrātpādāvasecanam | ucchiṣṭānnaniṣekaṃ ca dūrādeva samācaret udvartanaṃ apasnānaṃ viṇmūtre raktaṃ eva ca | śleśmaniṣṭhyūtavāntāni nādhitiṣṭhettu kāmataḥ
translation: At dawn, one should offer prayers to Mitra, take a bath, clean the teeth, and apply a magic ointment. Worship the deities in a secluded place and attend to natural calls there. Perform the rites of sipping water and cleaning the mouth, and consume food that has not been offered in worship. Massage the body with fragrant unguents, bathe in red-colored water, and continue to perform or undertake actions that promote good health. Refrain from being lazy about undergoing treatments for optimal health.

sloka: nānnaṃ adyādekavāsā na nagnaḥ snānaṃ ācaret | na mūtraṃ pathi kurvīta na bhasmani na govraje nāpsu mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ vā ṣṭhīvanaṃ vā samutsṛjet | amedhyaliptaṃ anyadvā lohitaṃ vā viṣāṇi vā
translation: For fear that today, one may not: eat food alone, take up the abode of a solitary mendicant, bathe in sacred waters, clean their nails, or relieve themselves near a path, on ashes, in a cattle pen, in water, or by spitting. Also, they must avoid consuming by burning, anointing with, or coming into contact with impure substances, reddish substances, or anything actively pernicious that emits fumes.

sloka: na pādau dhāvayetkāṃsye kadā cidapi bhājane | na bhinnabhāṇḍe bhuñjīta na bhāvapratidūṣite upānahau ca vāsaśca dhṛtaṃ anyairna dhārayet | upavītaṃ alaṅkāraṃ srajaṃ karakaṃ eva ca
translation: For fear that one may stumble, never should one swiftly step on discarded footwear at any time or place, nor consume food from a damaged container; nor wear soiled or another's garments. Always uphold the sacred thread, an upper cloth, and maintain the tuft of hair and sacred thread neatly tied, as these are the distinctive marks of a respectable individual.

sloka: na saṃhatābhyāṃ pāṇibhyāṃ kaṇḍūyedātmanaḥ śiraḥ | na spṛśeccaitaducchiṣṭo na ca snāyādvinā tataḥ nadīṣu devakhāteṣu taḍāgeṣu saraḥsu ca | snānaṃ samācarennityaṃ gartaprasravaṇeṣu ca
translation: For fear that he may scratch his own head with hands joined in respect, or touch this impure (person), and lest he bathe in rivers and ponds unconsecrated, instead, let him perform his daily ablutions in a well or spring, secluded or dug for the purpose; and not in sacred waters or as part of some ceremonial rite.

sloka: adhastānnopadadhyācca na cainaṃ abhilaṅghayet | na cainaṃ pādataḥ kuryānna prāṇābādhaṃ ācaret na vārayedgāṃ dhayantīṃ na cācakṣīta kasya cit || gavāṃ ca yānaṃ pṛṣṭhena sarvathaiva vigarhitam
translation: "One should not, as if to a thirsty deer, make him lie down or kill him, nor touch him. One should not obstruct his breathing or prevent the milking of the cow. One should not gaze at or reveal the one being cared for by someone. Who among the wise would allow such actions as hindering this being's path on the back of a cow in every respect?"

sloka: hīnāṅgānatiriktāṅgānvidyāhīnānvayo'dhikān | rūpadraviṇahīnāṃśca jātihīnāṃśca nākṣipet abhivādayedvṛddhāṃśca dadyāccaivāsanaṃ svakam | kṛtāñjalirupāsīta gacchataḥ pṛṣṭhato'nviyāt
translation: Pray, do not set at naught, bring near, or pay homage to those deprived of robust health, learning, virtuous behavior, riches, or caste. Instead, show them respect and offer them their rightful place. Having first paid obeisance, one should then depart, following behind and leaving them in front.

sloka: ṛtvikpurohitācāryairmātulātithisaṃśritaiḥ | bālavṛddhāturairvaidyairjñātisaṃbandhibāndhavaiḥ ākāśeśāstu vijñeyā bālavṛddhakṛśāturāḥ | bhrātā jyeṣṭhaḥ samaḥ pitrā bhāryā putraḥ svakā tanuḥ chāyā svo dāsavargaśca duhitā kṛpaṇaṃ param | tasmādetairadhikṣiptaḥ sahetāsaṃjvaraḥ sadā
translation: By priests, teachers, elderly relatives, family friends, and physicians of all ages who are present here as revered guests, you shall always be identified in the atmosphere as the one possessing balance and equilibrium. You are the eldest brother, equal to the father, wife, son, personal self, shadow, servants, and also the daughter. Hence, with such constantly preoccupying thoughts, direct yourself perpetually.

sloka: ācāryaṃ ca pravaktāraṃ pitaraṃ mātaraṃ gurum | na hiṃsyādbrāhmaṇāngāśca sarvāṃścaiva tapasvinaḥ na kurvīta vṛthāceṣṭāṃ na vāryañjalinā pibet | notsaṅge bhakṣayedbhakṣyānna jātu syātkutūhalī |
translation: Show reverence for the teacher who imparted this knowledge, along with your father, mother, and spiritual guide. Refrain from causing harm to Brahmins and ascetics, and avoid any pointless actions. Do not drink water with your hands folded in respect without offering it to others as well. Never consume food by yourself; always share it with others. Also, never let over-eagerness or curiosity get the better of you.

sloka: nākṣairdīvyetkadā cittu svayaṃ nopānahau haret | śayanastho na bhuñjīta na pāṇisthaṃ na cāsane | ārdrapādastu bhuñjīta nārdrapādastu saṃviśet | ārdrapādastu bhuñjāno dīrghaṃ āyuravāpnuyāt |
translation: Let him not be illuminated by stars at any time, when will he ever shine spontaneously? Let him not wish to gain time with women, let him lie down and not consume while existing in a sitting position or among hoofs. Let him, existing among wet feet, consume to enjoy and make use of them, and let him enter the waters only when his feet are succulent. Let him, consuming while his feet are wet, obtain long life and humming for a living being.

sloka: na snānaṃ ācaredbhuktvā nāturo na mahāniśi | na vāsobhiḥ sahājasraṃ nāvijñāte jalāśaye mattakruddhāturāṇāṃ ca na bhuñjīta kadā cana | keśakīṭāvapannaṃ ca padā spṛṣṭaṃ ca kāmataḥ
translation: Out of fear, one should never conduct a ritual bath having been afflicted, partake in grand feasts at night with company or consume meat from animals drowned in water or killed in rage, nor should one deliberately touch a dog or bird of their own free will. This is essential to avoid.

sloka: nekṣetodyantaṃ ādityaṃ nāstaṃ yāntaṃ kadā cana | nopasṛṣṭaṃ na vāristhaṃ na madhyaṃ nabhaso gatam na laṅghayedvatsatantrīṃ na pradhāvecca varṣati | na codake nirīkṣeta svarūpaṃ iti dhāraṇā
translation: Never can the sun's movement in its course, ending or beginning be observed like a thirsty deer seeking the farthest ocean. It neither has deviated, been surpassed, touched the sky's middle, nor caused rainfall. It doesn't look at its own reflection in water during the rainy season. This belief stands firm during the 8th to the 11th day in the light half of Jyaishṭha.

sloka: nādharmike vasedgrāme na vyādhibahule bhṛśam | naikaḥ prapadyetādhvānaṃ na ciraṃ parvate vaset bālātapaḥ pretadhūmo varjyaṃ bhinnaṃ tathāsanam | na chindyānnakharomāṇi dantairnotpāṭayennakhān
translation: In an unrighteous settlement, one should not remain or continue to abide or keep on in any condition for long, especially amidst tormenting ailments or vexatious people; nor should a sincere person resort to the roadway for an extended period. Similarly, one must not dwell on a knotty mountain during the heat causing pain or affliction, not even for a while. Smoke, the product of fire, is to be avoided, as are breaking sandals and cutting nails with teeth or hands.

sloka: na mṛlloṣṭhaṃ ca mṛdnīyānna chindyātkarajaistṛṇam | na karma niṣphalaṃ kuryānnāyatyāṃ asukhodayam advāreṇa ca nātīyādgrāmaṃ vā veśma vāvṛtam | rātrau ca vṛkṣamūlāni dūrataḥ parivarjayet
translation: As a thirsty deer avoids touching a salty patch of earth, so should one abstain from lightly touching the earth or cutting it with a plow and causing damage to any gramineous plant. One should not engage in pointless actions or religious rituals that bear no fruit. In the late afternoon, one should avoid stepping over a village or house, entering an enclosed space too closely, or even approaching it from a distance. By night, one must keep away from tree roots and their immediate neighborhood, maintaining a safe distance.

sloka: acakṣurviṣayaṃ durgaṃ na prapadyeta karhi cit | na viṇmūtraṃ udīkṣeta na bāhubhyāṃ nadīṃ taret adhitiṣṭhenna keśāṃstu na bhasmāsthikapālikāḥ | na kārpāsāsthi na tuṣāndīrghaṃ āyurjijīviṣuḥ
translation: Never should one seek to behold a forbidden object or engage in religious meditation on something pernicious, fearing that it may contaminate one's pure thoughts at any time. Likewise, never gaze at another's excreta or urine, nor cross a river using arms or float on it with the limbs of a bow. One should not remain in the presence of another's hair or hold even a particle of ash or bone from another's funeral pyre. Furthermore, one should not desire to live a long life consuming the five sense objects through greed.

sloka: keśagrahānprahārāṃśca śirasyetānvivarjayet | śiraḥsnātaśca tailena nāṅgaṃ kiṃ cidapi spṛśet devatānāṃ guro rājñaḥ snātakācāryayostathā | nākrāmetkāmataśchāyāṃ babhruṇo dīkṣitasya ca
translation: The officiant, having bathed and anointed his locks and these (offerings) with oil, should avoid striking their tops; let him not touch any part of his body before worshiping the deities, the teacher, the king, and the initiated priest. Moreover, he should not move about at will in the shadow of the sacrificial fire or a brown-skinned consecrated person's shade during the ritual.

sloka: kṣatriyaṃ caiva sarpaṃ ca brāhmaṇaṃ ca bahuśrutam | nāvamanyeta vai bhūṣṇuḥ kṛśānapi kadā cana nātmānaṃ avamanyeta purvābhirasamṛddhibhiḥ | ā mṛtyoḥ śriyaṃ anvicchennaināṃ manyeta durlabhām
translation: Treat a ruler, serpent-demon, and a highly learned brahmin with respect and esteem. Never, even when physically weakened, underestimate oneself. Even past prosperous ancestors should not disregard this prosperity. Seek royal dignity approaching death, considering it something hard to obtain.

sloka: dharmaṃ śanaiḥ saṃcinuyādvalmīkaṃ iva puttikāḥ | paralokasahāyārthaṃ sarvabhūtānyapīḍayan dṛḍhakārī mṛdurdāntaḥ krūrācārairasaṃvasan | ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayetsvargaṃ tathāvrataḥ
translation: Let him cultivate dharma step by step, much like a plant grows over time. Just as one nurtures friendships for future mutual benefit, so too should he treat all beings, causing them no distress, with a firm disposition, mild and self-restrained, shunning cruel behavior. Through harmlessness and self-control, he shall attain to the bright sky (i.e., heaven).

sloka: maṅgalācārayuktaḥ syātprayatātmā jitendriyaḥ | japecca juhuyāccaiva nityaṃ agniṃ atandritaḥ vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca | adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm paurvikīṃ saṃsmaranjātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ | brahmābhyāsena cājasraṃ anantaṃ sukhaṃ aśnute
translation: Let one be endowed with auspicious conduct and resolute in their mind, while having mastery over their senses. They should recite and make offerings to the fire continuously, being ever steadfast in the daily practice of studying the scriptures, cleanliness, and austerities. Ever mindful of the true nature of all beings, they constantly deepen their meditation on it. By perpetually engaging in the ceaseless practice of understanding Brahman, one experiences infinite bliss.

sloka: anena vipro vṛttena vartayanvedaśāstravit | vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate
translation: By following this virtuous path, the brāhmin, proficient in Vedic lore and rid of all blemishes, continually gains preeminence amongst the inhabitants of the heavenly abode of Brahmā.

sloka: ye vai brāhmaṇāḥ śuśruvāṃso'nūcānāste viprāstānevaitadabhyāha
translation: "Indeed, O brahmins who have learned earlier, if you (singular) are to be instructed by them (dual) in an orderly manner, as they read out and recite (what has been taught), then assuredly this (teaching) will also approach you (as a devout act)."

sloka: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñānagniṣṭomādikānmakhān | yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvigihocyate ||
translation: The one who carries out the agnyādheya and other fire rituals like pākayajñas, agniṣṭomas, etc., is regarded as the priest of the one whose (rituals) are carefully protected by him.

sloka: iha hi dravyaṃ pañcamahābhūtātmakam |
translation: Indeed, here the referenced elementary substance is composed of the fifth primary element.

sloka: ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī |
translation: Starting with the sky or atmosphere, we have the emergence of wind, then from wind comes fire, followed by the appearance of water obtained from fire, and ultimately the earth or wide world arises from the intermediate region.

sloka: tatra gandhavatī pṛthivī | sā dvividhā nityā'nityā ca | nityā paramāṇurūpā | anityā kāryarūpā | punastrividhā śarīrendriyaviṣayabhedāt |
translation: In that place, the earth is endowed with a dual fragrance: one is eternally constituted by atoms, while the other is transient and formless, pertaining to actions. Moreover, it is threefold in nature, based on the distinction between body, senses, and their objects.

sloka: madhukaiṭabhayormedaḥ saṃyogānmedinī smṛtā | dhāraṇācca dharā proktā pṛthvī vistārayogataḥ || mahī cāpi mahīyas |
translation: The alliance formed by Madhu's race and Kaitabha, referred to as fertile or fatty, is called 'saṃyogān.' This name originates from the act of establishing it, similar to how Dharā, the father of Padmaprabha, derived his name from spreading out the earth. Similarly, Mahī, a divine being, is distinguished by her greatness. Additionally, it is said that this 'dhāraṇā,' associated with Medinī (another name for Earth), was spoken of by Prajāpati and is remembered as such.

sloka: athāgamya mahārājannamaskṛtyi ca kaśyapam | pṛthavī kāśyapī jajñe sutā tasya mahātmanaḥ ||
translation: Upon approaching and paying homage to the illustrious King Kaśyapa, the earth then brought forth his greatly revered offspring.

sloka: prathate vistāraṃ yātīti pṛthivī | pṛthvī sthūlatvaguṇayuktā | pṛthorduhitṛtvasvīkārādetannāma |
translation: The earth becomes widely apparent, known as "Prithivi," as it develops with the quality of solidity and derives its name from being the daughter of Prithu.

sloka: duhitṛtvaṅgatā yasmāt pṛthaurdharmmavato mahī| tadānurāgayogācca pṛthivī viśrutā budhaiḥ||
translation: The earth, known as a distinct element, celebrated among learned men, has inherent primal qualities derived from pious affection stemming from its birth as a "daughter" from him (the sky).

sloka: gataprāṇau tadā jātau dānavau madhukaiṭabhau | sāgaraḥ sakalo vyāptastadā vai medasā tayoḥ || medinīti tato jātaṃ nāma pṛthvyāḥ samantataḥ |
translation: At that moment, the two demoniac beings, Madhu and Kaitabha, having been divested of their vital breaths (gataprāṇau), lay lifeless (jātau) among the Jasminugrandiflorum. The entire ocean, then, became suffused (sakalaḥ vyāptaḥ) with their fat-like substance (medasā tayoḥ). What followed was the emergence and naming (jātam nāma iti) of the earth (pṛthvyāḥ samantataḥ medinī) after this occurrence.

sloka: evaṃ sarvaṃ kṛtrimaṃ ca bāhyābhyantarameva ca ||tadvināśe vināśaśca sarveṣāmeva nārada | jalabud‌budavatsarvaṃ viśvasaṃghamanityakam ||
translation: "Surely, when that is destroyed, everything, wholly perishable, both external and internal, faces annihilation as well, just as Narada points out. It's akin to water bubbles, being unsteady and transient."

sloka: dyaurme pitā janitā nābhiratra bandhurme mātā pṛthivī mahīyam |
translation: The sky is considered my father, the one who gives birth and nurtures; the navel of the earth, a symbol of sovereignty, is my mother; the universe is my relative or friend; such is my view of the earth.

sloka: viśvaṃbharā vasudhānī pratiṣṭhā hiraṇyavakṣā jagato niveśanī | vaiśvānaraṃ bibhratī bhūmiragnimindraṛṣabhā draviṇe no dadhātu ||
translation: Universal sustainers, containing earthly treasures and providing firm support, may you who wear the golden attribute and are known as Vaiśvānara, establish for us treasured forms of bhūmi, agni, indra, and ṛṣabha.

sloka: yatte bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipraṃ tadapi rohatu | mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayamarpipam ||
translation: "O soil, may what I quickly excavate soon regenerate, and let not your concealed secrets be uncovered by him. May his heart not become tainted."

sloka: na vā araṇyānirhantyanyaścennābhigacchati |
translation: "Nor do those who have not conquered the forest, either approach or even come near."

sloka: iyaṃ pṛthivī sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ madhu | asyai pṛthivyai sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu |
translation: This very earth, the nectar of all Kṛishṇa's living beings, is poured out for this earth; the nectar of all living beings is poured into this earth.

sloka: saktuprasthena vo nāyaṃ yajñastulyo narādhipāḥ| uñchavṛttervadānyasya kurukṣetranivāsinaḥ||
translation: With sacrificial offerings consisting of coarsely ground meal, measured out in a specific weight, they will not be equivalent to even a single munificent king, in their generosity towards those residing in the Kuru kingdom's fertile soil. This is because the kings of Kaśmīra and the princess of the Kuru race, along with their followers, are characterized by their gathering of grains and strict means of subsistence.

sloka: dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre dharmajñairbahubhirvṛte| uñchavṛttirdvijaḥ kaścitkāpotirabhavattadā||
translation: In the religious field of the Kuru dynasty, some learned twice-born person was endowed with the provision of gathering grains (through agricultural pursuit) and procuring water by a cow (as an allegory for nourishment and life) that had manifested before.

sloka: athāgacchaddvijaḥ kaścidatithirbhuñjatāṃ tadā|| te taṃ dṛṣṭvātithiṃ prāptaṃ prahṛṣṭamanaso'bhavan| te'bhivādya sukhapraśnaṃ pṛṣṭvā tamatithiṃ tadā||
translation: Then a certain twice-born, including the cowherds, arrived. At that time, some of them, on seeing the guest who had just then arrived, became joyful. After respectfully causing him to greet them and, after willingly engaging in conversation with him and inquiring about his well-being, they spent that day with him.

sloka: ityuktā sā tataḥ prāha dharmārthau nau samau dvija|| saktuprasthacaturbhāgaṃ gṛhāṇemaṃ prasīda me| satyaṃ ratiśca dharmaśca svargaśca guṇanirjitaḥ||
translation: Having been addressed in this manner, she replied, "O twice-born one, righteousness and prosperity are indeed identical. Accept this fourfold inheritance of the sacrifice, I urge. Truth, fondness, and righteousness, as well as Indra's paradise, are all vanquished by virtue."

sloka: apatyamasmi te puṃsastrāṇātputra iti smṛtaḥ| ātmā putraḥ smṛtastasmāttrāhyātmānamihātmanā||
translation: I am the protector of your two sons, as is recalled. Hence, one should regard the self as a son.

sloka: tava prasādānnirvṛttā mama lokāḥ kilākṣayāḥ| putreṇa tānavāpnoti yatra gatvā na śocati|| dharmādyo hi yathā tretā vahnitretā tathaiva ca| tathaiva putrapautrāṇāṃ svargastretā kilākṣayaḥ|| pitṝnṛṇāttārayati putra ityanuśuśruma| putrapautraiśca niyataṃ sādhulokānupāśnute||
translation: Through your kindness, my worlds have been made immune to decay. A son, attaining there, never laments when departing. Just as dharma and other virtues were secure during the Treta age, so too are the realms of sons and grandsons secure from decay. It has been heard that a son rescues ancestors from their karmic debt. A grandson, through his honorable lineage, partakes in the merits accrued in this world in a steady manner.

sloka: baṭ śrat satrā addhā itthā ṛtam iti satyasya
translation: Affirming this very truth in a straightforward manner, regarding sincerity, such is the nature of what is real.

sloka: ṛtasya hi śurudhaḥ santi pūrvīrṛtasya dhītirvṛjināni hanti | ṛtasya śloko badhirā tatarda karṇā budhānaḥ śucamāna āyoḥ || ṛtasya dṛl̤hā dharuṇāni santi purūṇi candrā vapuṣe vapūṃṣi | ṛtena dīrghamiṣaṇanta pṛkṣa ṛtena gāva ṛtamāviveśuḥ || ṛtaṃ yemāna ṛtamidvanotyṛtasya śuṣmasturayā u gavyuḥ | ṛtāya pṛthvī bahule gabhīre ṛtāya dhenū parame duhāte ||
translation: The ancestral seers, firmly established in righteousness, indeed exist as offspring of righteousness, warding off evils. A proverb holds no power against one unwavering in truth; the wise ones pay no heed to it. Ample firm roots of righteousness exist, dispersed on the moon's visage. Cattle and living beings have merged into the enduring and infinite righteousness. "O earth, you encompass and nurture the essence of righteousness within your expansive depths."

sloka: indriyam indraliṃgam indradṛṣṭamindraṛṣṭamindrauṣṭamindrāttaṃ iti vā |
translation: A companion of Indra, namely the eternal procreative generative organ, or as something called by that name, or indicating additional attributes - this is what is referred to as Indra-liṅgam.

sloka: indro yātūnāmabhavatparāśaro havirmathīnāmabhyā vivāsatām abhīdu śakraḥ paraśuryathā vanaṃ pātreva bhindantsata eti rakṣasaḥ
translation: Indra, like Parashara among the yatu demons, served as their chief; just as Shakra did with those offering sacrifices. Wielding an axe-like weapon, he cuts through the forest (of his enemies) and approaches (to protect), similar to how a blade slices through a vessel. Such is how he treats the rakshasas.

sloka: akṛtvā pādayo: śaucaṃ diti: śayanamāviśat nidrāṃ cāhārayāmāsa tasyā: kukṣiṃ praviśya sa: vajrapāṇirmahāgarbhaṃ cicchedātha sa saptadhā sampīḍyamāno vajreṇa sa rurodātidāruṇam mā rodīriti taṃ śakra: puna:punarabhāṣata so'bhavatsaptadhā garbhastamiṃdra: kupita: puna: maruto nāma devāste babhūvurativeginaḥ | yaduktaṃ vai maghavatā tenaiva maruto'bhavan | devā ekonapañcāsat sahāyā vajrapāṇinaḥ ||
translation: Without first observing proper foot cleansing rituals, Indra entered the sleep of Diti, causing her to lie down and become pregnant. Once enclosed within her seven-fold womb, Indra split it open using his thunderbolt. As he was being squeezed by the thunderbolt, Indra cried out in distress. He then addressed the embryo, saying "Do not cry!" Becoming seven within the womb himself, Indra gave rise to the Maruts, named after the wind, as previously spoken by Maghavat (Indra). Fifty divine allies of Vajrapani (Indra) also came into existence.

sloka: yaḥ pṛthavīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatāna prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who, at times of turmoil, brings tranquility to the agitated earth, pacifies the wrathful mountains, reinstates balance in the disrupted atmosphere, and extends compassion towards all beings is truly the Indra among humans.

sloka: sa vajrabhṛd dasyuhā bhīma ugraḥ sahasracetāḥ śatanītha ṛbhvā camrīṣo na śavasā pāñcajanyo marutvān no bhavatvindra ūtī
translation: May the thunderbolt-wielding and formidable enemy leader, who is extremely brave, has a hundred minds leading others, is accompanied by the ṛbhvās, and possesses the name Pāñcajanya, not be equated with Indra.

sloka: yo hatvāhimariṇāta sapta sindhūn yo gā udājadapadhā valasya yo aśmanorantaragniṃ jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who vanquished the seven rivers, as well as the earth, a descendant of Aja giving sustenance, born from the fire within the two precious stones (i.e., the polar mountains), is indeed Indra - the very fortuity that Nārāyaṇa is, having become the dust of the people's enhancer.

sloka: indrasyāṅagirasāṃ ceṣṭau vidat saramā tanayāya dhāsim bṛhaspatirbhinadadriṃ vidad gāḥ samusriyābhirvāvaśanta naraḥ evaṃ purā svānapi sodarān sa garbhasthitānujjarituṃ bhayārtaḥ| bibheda vajreṇa tataḥ sa gotrabhit khyāto
translation: In the past, Indra exerted himself at Aṅagiras' abode, causing it to crack open for Saramā's son. Likewise, Bṛhaspati made the cows withdraw from the mountain using his abilities. A man, stricken by calamity, also managed to break open the barrier protecting his own tribesmen. Later, Indra gained wide recognition as one who shatters clan enclosures, wielding his thunderbolt.

sloka: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetāṃ nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who was first brought into existence as a most excellent being among men of conscience and adorned the gods with his remarkable deeds, from whom the governance of the two worlds emerged. May he, the nourisher, along with people, protect us; indeed, he is Indra, the husband of Sachi.

sloka: prajāpatirindra masṛjatānujāvaraṃ devānām | taṃ prāhiṇot | parehi | eteṣāṃ devānāmadhipatiredhīti | taṃ devā abruvan | kastvamasi | vayaṃ vai tvacchreyā~ saḥ sma iti | so'bravīt | kastvamasi vayaṃ vai tvacchreyā~ saḥ sma iti mā devā avocanniti | ko ha vai nāma prajāpatiḥ | ya evaṃ veda vidurenaṃ nāmnā | tadasmai rukmaṃ kṛtvā pratyamuñcat | tato vā indro devānāmadhipatirabhavat | ya evaṃ veda |
translation: Prajāpati, the progenitor, fathered the offspring of Ila. This authority he bestowed upon Indra among the gods. He then inquired, "Who are you? We are indeed your subordinates."
