To this, Indra responded, "Who are you? We are indeed your subordinates." At that point, a question arose in their minds, "What is the name of this Prajāpati?" The one who knows the answer by the name 'Vidura' bestows gold and attains lordly wealth. Thus, Indra became the lord of the gods.

sloka: yaḥ parthivīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatān prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who brings tranquility to the troubled Earth, pacifies the furious mountains, stirs the atmosphere, and pours down mercy is revered as Indra among people.

sloka: pūrvaṃ kṛtayuge tāta parvatāḥ pakṣiṇo'bhavan te hi jagmurdiśaḥ sarvā garuḍānilaveginaḥ
translation: In the first age of the world, father, the mountains transformed into swift-flying birds moving towards all cardinal directions; indeed, they departed for those (designated regions).

sloka: na nūnamasti no śvaḥ kastad veda yadadbhutam anyasya cittamabhi saṃcareṇyamutādhītaṃ vi naśyati
translation: Indeed, how could there be now or in the future someone in this world who truly understands another's extraordinary consciousness, since it tends to be destroyed once disclosed or made known.

sloka: kiṃ na indra jighāṃsasi bhrātaro marutastava tebhiḥ kalpasva sādhuyā mā naḥ samaraṇe vadhīḥ
translation: What, Indra, is your desire to wound and touch your brother(s) from the lineage of Marut? May enmity not arise for us in the battlefield, as we abandon disrespectful behavior towards those of honorable descent.

sloka: kiṃ no bhrātaragastya sakhā sannati manyase vidmā hi te yathā mano'smabhyaminna ditsasi
translation: What, dear friend Gastya, do you currently consider us - as mere acquaintances or as siblings? We genuinely wish to understand your true feelings towards us, as one who is about to perform the Śrāddha ceremony for us.

sloka: araṃ karṇvantu vediṃ samagnimindhatāṃ puraḥ tatrāmṛtasya cetanaṃ yajñaṃ te tanavāvahai
translation: Let the spokes of the altar, symbolizing the ears, ascend towards the sacrificial ground of the Vedas and Agni, and similarly direct your attention to that conscious elixir of life, the life-sustaining sacrifice. You two, invigorate and prepare to propagate that very divine essence of life and knowledge.

sloka: tavamīśiṣe vasupate vasūnāṃ tavaṃ mitrāṇāṃ mitrapate dheṣṭhaḥ indra tvaṃ marudbhiḥ saṃ vadasvādha prāśāna ṛtuthā havīṃṣi
translation: You, reigning over the sons of Vatsara, are the most excellent; you, being the ally of allies, are also the leader among friends, O Indra. Speak in unison with the Maruts and offer up the oblations at the appropriate time!

sloka: svāyaṃbhuvo manuḥ pūrvaṃ paraḥ svārociṣastathā | uttamastāmasaścaiva raivataścākṣuṣastathā ||
translation: The primordial Manu, the progenitor and the paragon of men, was the first [to establish order]. Just as he assigned names [to all things], so too were Raivata and Akshusha, other illustrious Manus, present during that time.

sloka: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetāṃ nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who was brought into existence as the very first and is supremely conscious among the gods, who richly adorned the other gods with his deeds, whose authority from the sun determines the boundaries of the worlds – such an Indra has this self become.

sloka: yaḥ parthivīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatān prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who brings solace to the afflicted earth, pacifies the wrathful mountains, stirs the usually unmoving atmosphere, and showers beneficent rain is like Indra to the masses.

sloka: yo hatvāhimariṇāta sapta sindhūn yo gā udājadapadhā valasya yo aśmanorantaragniṃ jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who vanquished the seven rivers, the earth described as a descendant of Aja, and the fiery source within the two precious stones (i.e., the polar mountains), giving birth to Brahmā or Bṛihas-pati, the demon Valasya's enemy; and becoming the very fortune that is Nārāyaṇa's protection for people - that one is Indra.

sloka: caturāśītisāhasramutsedhena prakīrtitaḥ|| praviṣṭaḥ ṣoḍaśādhastādviṃstṛtaḥ ṣoḍaśaiva tu|| ||
translation: You, the glorious one, hailed for swiftly conquering eighty thousand; upon entering, become divided into sixteen parts yourself, just as those sixteen parts were entered before.

sloka: mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava |
translation: Revere the divine mothers and fathers, honor the teacher, and show respect to the worthy guest.

sloka: ekarātraṃ tu nivasannatithirbrāhmaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ | anityaṃ hi sthito yasmāttasmādatithirucyate | | | | na brāhmaṇasya tvatithirgṛhe rājanya ucyate | vaiśyaśūdrau sakhā caiva jñātayo gurureva ca | | | | yadi tvatithidharmeṇa kṣatriyo gṛhaṃ āvrajet | bhuktavatsu ca vipreṣu kāmaṃ taṃ api bhojayet | | | | itarānapi sakhyādīnsamprītyā gṛhaṃ āgatān | prakṛtyānnaṃ yathāśakti bhojayetsaha bhāryayā | | | |
translation: A person who stays for just one night is called an 'atithi' (guest), while someone who resides for a longer period is referred to as 'sthita' (resident). Thus, an 'atithi' refers to a temporary resident. However, a 'brāhmaṇa' is not considered an 'atithi' when staying in another's home. Instead, a 'rājanya', 'vaiśya', 'śūdra', companion, relative, or guru is regarded as an 'atithi'. If a 'kṣatriya' enters a household due to following the 'atithi dharma' (guest ritual), then even a 'vipra' who has partaken of food in that household should offer him food as well. Similarly, one should also offer food to any other guests who may have come out of friendship or goodwill, according to their needs and with the help of their spouse.

sloka: rājartviksnātakagurūnpriyaśvaśuramātulān | arhayenmadhuparkeṇa parisaṃvatsarātpunaḥ | | | | saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: The newly initiated priest in royal service should honor his respected teachers, parents-in-law, and maternal uncles by offering them a feast with sweetened beverages annually. At the appropriate time of their arrival, he must respectfully provide a seat and water. Furthermore, he should serve food according to his ability and resources, following proper procedures and expressing admiration for the guest.

sloka: apraṇodyo'tithiḥ sāyaṃ sūryoḍho gṛhamedhinā | kāle prāptastvakāle vā nāsyānaśnangṛhe vaset | | | | vaiśvadeve tu nirvṛtte yadyanyo'tithirāvrajet | tasyāpyannaṃ yathāśakti pradadyānna baliṃ haret | | | |
translation: "The householder, after completing the evening rite personified as the setting and descent of the solar god, should either remain at home during mealtime or depart from it to another's residence. If another ritual day overtakes him during Vaiśvadeva, he may partake of food according to his capacity, offering a portion as tribute, whether it is appropriate or not."

sloka: suvāsinīḥ kumārīśca rogiṇo garbhiṇīḥ striyaḥ | atithibhyo'gra evaitānbhojayedavicārayan | | | | bhuktavatsvatha vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi | bhuñjīyātāṃ tataḥ paścādavaśiṣṭaṃ tu dampatī | | | |
translation: Show hospitality to the young unmarried women, girls, the ailing, and pregnant women. These guests are to be served first, after due consideration. In the past, we used to share our meals with our teachers and personal servants. Now, the couple should also partake of the remaining food.

sloka: na vai svayaṃ tadaśnīyādatithiṃ yanna bhojayet | dhanyaṃ yaśasyaṃ āyuṣyaṃ svargyaṃ vātithipūjanam | | | | śilānapyuñchato nityaṃ pañcāgnīnapi juhvataḥ | sarvaṃ sukṛtaṃ ādatte brāhmaṇo'narcito vasan | | | |
translation: Indeed, it is as if one does not spontaneously partake in or enjoy a guest's meal nor make arrangements for his feeding at that time. Yet, the host, by providing alms, acquires wealth, fame, long life, and heavenly pleasure. Even by offering a handful of grass daily to the five fires, a Brahmin, who is revered and unsullied, gains all meritorious deeds.

sloka: ya evaṃ vetti puruṣaṃ prakṛtiṃ ca guṇaiḥ saha | sarvathā vartamāno'pi na sa bhūyo'bhijāyate || puruṣaḥ prakṛtistho hi bhuṅ‌kte prakṛtijānguṇān | kāraṇaṃ guṇasaṅgo'sya sadasadyonijanmasu ||
translation: The one who recognizes the individual being and primal nature, along with their respective qualities, as thus; even while constantly engaged, does not take birth again in such a manner. The embodied soul, stationed in primal nature, enjoys the products of nature, being bound by the bondage of qualities stemming from the interaction of nature's gunas (constituents) in creation, maintenance, and dissolution.

sloka: paraṃ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṃ jñānamuttamam | yajjñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṃ siddhimito gatāḥ ||
translation: I will reveal to you, in even greater detail, the foremost knowledge amongst all forms of knowledge. Upon gaining insight into this, all sages have indeed achieved supreme accomplishment.

sloka: idaṃ jñānamupāśritya mama sādharmyamāgatāḥ | sarge'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca ||
translation: Taking refuge in this very knowledge, they have attained resemblance to me. Neither in the creation nor in the dissolution are they repeatedly born, or do they experience any distress or disquiet.

sloka: mama yonirmahadbrahma tasmingarbhaṃ dadhāmyaham | saṃbhavaḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ tato bhavati bhārata ||
translation: As the great intellectual principle and Brāhmaṇa portion of the Veda, I, the source of self and attention, bring or fix the seed there in my station of existence. From this origin, O descendant of Bharata, arises the being produced and born of all creatures.

sloka: sarvayoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ saṃbhavanti yāḥ | tāsāṃ brahma mahadyonirahaṃ bījapradaḥ pitā ||
translation: Kaunteya, I am the cause of the emergence of all forms appearing in different wombs. Among them, I am the source of the seed, the great progenitor, as the impersonal universal Spirit (Brahman) and as the personal Creator Brahmā for those ancestors (Pitṛis).

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation: The three qualities, namely sattva, rajas, and tamas, which arise from nature, restrain the unchanging self, endowed with a body, within the manifestation, O mighty-armed one. Here, sattva refers to the quality of truth, pure consciousness, and knowledge; rajas signifies activity, desire, and passion; and tamas indicates inertia, darkness, and ignorance.

sloka: tatra sattvaṃ nirmalatvātprakāśakamanāmayam | sukhasaṅgena badhnāti jñānasaṅgena cānagha ||
translation: In that place, pure sattva, due to its stainlessness, illuminates; through attachment to happiness and devotion to higher knowledge, it binds together without causing any blemish, O anagha (an epithet of Śiva).

sloka: rajo rāgātmakaṃ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam | tannibadhnāti kaunteya karmasaṅgena dehinam ||
translation: Kaunteya, recognize that the affection, characterized by passion and rāga, having its nature, arises from the avidity and saṅgas. It, through devotion to actions, binds the embodied spirit.

sloka: tamastvajñānajaṃ viddhi mohanaṃ sarvadehinām | pramādālasyanidrābhistannibadhnāti bhārata ||
translation: Consider, O Bharata, spiritual ignorance, originating from mental darkness, as the depriver of consciousness in all beings with bodies. It ensnares them through madness, idleness, and sleep.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: The quality of purity/goodness takes root in joy, O Bhārata, while the affections do so in action. Knowledge, being a Śakti of the sun, finds enjoyment in love when it becomes delimited. When knowledge is covered by delusion and becomes revived, it is either through correct understanding or by some other means.

sloka: rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṃ tamaścaiva tamaḥ sattvaṃ rajastathā ||
translation: Through conquering rajas and tamas, sattva prevails, oh Bharata; conversely, with sattva's preeminence, both rajas and tamas wane.

sloka: sarvadvāreṣu dehe'sminprakāśa upajāyate | jñānaṃ yadā tadā vidyādvivṛddhaṃ sattvamityuta ||
translation: In this manifestation, light arises at every door of the body; when accurate knowledge and learning in the field of philosophy increase, it signifies the enhancement of one's true essence.

sloka: lobhaḥ pravṛttirārambhaḥ karmaṇāmaśamaḥ spṛhā | rajasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha || aprakāśo'pravṛttiśca pramādo moha eva ca | tamasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe kurunandana ||
translation: Greed, the urge to start something, and the initiative are all generated by action, while longing and the rajasic state manifest as these qualities grow. Similarly, inertia, indistinctness, delusion, and desire arise from the tamasic state when it intensifies, O delight of the Kurus.

sloka: nānyaṃ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṃ yadā draṣṭānupaśyati | guṇebhyaśca paraṃ vetti madbhāvaṃ so'dhigacchati ||
translation: Only when one perceives the agent who acts, as distinct from all organs of sense and their associated qualities, do they truly come to know my essential nature.

sloka: guṇānetānatītya trīndehī dehasamudbhavān | janmamṛtyujarāduḥkhairvimukto'mṛtamaśnute ||
translation: Exceeding these very qualities that manifest in bodily form, once free from the afflictions of birth, death, aging, and distress, one experiences liberation and immortality.

sloka: kairliṅgaistrīnguṇānetānatīto bhavati prabho | kimācāraḥ kathaṃ caitāṃstrīnguṇānativartate ||
translation: Through what signs, oh lord, capable of doing so, can one transcend these three genders and excellences that exist currently? What is the established rule of conduct and how does one surpass these qualities?

sloka: prakāśaṃ ca pravṛttiṃ ca mohameva ca pāṇḍava | na dveṣṭi saṃpravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati || udāsīnavadāsīno guṇairyo na vicālyate | guṇā vartanta ityeva yo'vatiṣṭhati neṅgate || samaduḥkhasukhaḥ svasthaḥ samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ | tulyapriyāpriyo dhīrastulyanindātmasaṃstutiḥ || mānāpamānayostulyastulyo mitrāripakṣayoḥ | sarvārambhaparityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa ucyate ||
translation: Pāṇḍava, one who remains impartial, steadfast, and unmoved by transient qualities, who does not resent the arisen or departed actions, nor desires; who, like a post, maintains equanimity towards pleasure and pain, honor and dishonor, joy and sorrow, friend and foe, praise and criticism; one who is unwavering in engaging with or renouncing endeavors, transcends qualities, and is established in the self - such an individual is referred to as guṇātīta.

sloka: māṃ ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇānsamatītyaitānbrahmabhūyāya kalpate || brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāhamamṛtasyāvyayasya ca | śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca ||
translation: The one who serves me with unwavering devotion through the means of bhakti, transcends these qualities and becomes fit for becoming Brahman. Indeed, I am the foundation of Brahman, the imperishable nectar, eternal dharma, and supreme happiness. (The one who serves me with faith and love, completing the destruction of these qualities, becomes eligible for becoming the self-existent Spirit through bhakti yoga.) I am the basis of Brahman, the essential nature of the imperishable nectar, eternal religion, and absolute bliss.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣeyaḥ yonāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñāātaṃ vijñātamiti kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti
translation: How can such a thing, unperceived, unheard-of, yet to be determined and acknowledged, ever become truly known, accurately understood, or decreed as an order, even when it has been heard and recognized?

sloka: hovācānanuśiṣya vāva kila mā bhagavānabravīdanutvā'śiṣamiti
translation: "Upon being asked, the teacher then said, 'Let's instruct him in a proper manner as well,' having already commanded him earlier, 'Do not neglect (me or the teaching).'"

sloka: sa hovāca tavaiva rājanmānuṣaṃ vittaṃ yāmeva kumārasyānte vācamabhāṣathāstāmeva me brūhiti sa ha kṛcchrī babhūva
translation: The king addressed (you) as a member of the royal tribe or military caste, asking, "Was it you who, at the end, spoke to the human-like heir-apparent about his fortune, causing that very fortune to befall your mind with difficulty?"

sloka: sūryaḥ dyusthānaḥ | vāyuḥ vā indraḥ vā antarikṣasthānaḥ | agniḥ pṛthivīsthānaḥ |
translation: The sun is in its celestial posture, or perhaps it's the wind in the atmospheric position, or maybe it's Indra, or potentially fire in its terrestrial posture.

sloka: baḍavāyāḥ samudrasthitāyāḥ ghoṭakyā mukhastho'gniḥ | samudrasthāgniḥ |
translation: Of the Badava clan, a fire, established on the ground at the mouth of the ocean sister (a name for a river), also known as the Samudra.

sloka: jaṭharasthito'gniḥ | kaukṣeye annādipācake vahnau “annarasojaṭharāgninā pacyamānoraktatāṃ pratipadyate”|
translation: The fire residing in the stomach, specifically in the lower abdominal area, is known as the "digestive fire." It is through this fire that nourishment, once cooked, assumes the form of a transformed essence.

sloka: agnirvaiśvānaro vahnirvītihotro dhanaṃjayaḥ | kṛpīṭayonirjvalano jātavedāstanūnapāt || barhiḥ śuṣmā kṛṣṇavartmā śociṣkeśa uṣarbudhaḥ | āśayāśo bṛhdabhānuḥ kṛśānuḥ pāvakonalaḥ || rohitāśvo vāyusakhaḥ śikhāvānāśuśukṣaṇiḥ | hiraṇyaretā hutabhugdahano havyavāhanaḥ || saptārcirdamunāḥ śukraścitrabhānurvibhāvasuḥ | śucirappittamaurvastu vāḍavo vaḍavānalaḥ || vahnerdvayorjvālakilāvarcirhetiḥ śikhā striyām | triṣu sphuliṅgognikaṇaḥ saṃtāpaḥ saṃjvaraḥ samau
translation: Fire, specifically Vaisvanara, is the invoker, Dhananjaya, teeming with life, born of sacrifice. It has the forms of heat and the sacrificial fire. The fuel for this fire is barhis. Its path is black, subtle, and splendid. Aspiration, expansive light, lean and burning, swift and keen-edged, golden-rayed sun, carrier of oblations, are the seven flaming tongues of this fire. Clear, unchanging, effulgent, and swift, all-consuming and blazing brightly, such is its nature. Fire's two flames possess a radiant splendor upon women, while its sparks appear in three places, causing both feverish warmth and burning heat.

sloka: haviḥ prakṣepādhikaraṇeṣu gārhapatyāhavanīyadakṣiṇāgnisabhyāvasathyaupāsanākhyeṣu ṣaḍgniṣu |
translation: In the six fire-altars – Garhapatya, Dakshina, Aagneyi, Ahavaniya, Sabhya, Avasathya, and Upaasana, what are the oblations offered as havis?

sloka: prajāpatirha vā idamagra eka evāsa | sa aikṣata kathaṃ nu prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata so'gnimeva mukhājjanayāṃcakre tadyadenaṃ mukhādajanayata tasmādannādo'gniḥ
translation: In the beginning, the sovereign Prajapati existed alone here. Contemplating, "How might I engender progeny?" he reflected and performed intense austerities. From his mouth, he then brought forth fire. Hence, that which originated from it is known as Agni (fire).

sloka: agnimūrdhā cakṣuṣī candrasūryau diśa: śrotre vāgvivṛtāśca vedā: vāyu: prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhayāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā sthālīsthānaṃ gato'śvatthaṃ śamīgarbhaṃ vilakṣya saḥ | tena dve araṇī kṛtvā urvaśīlokakāmyayā || ||
translation: The one with a forehead resembling the fire's crest, moon-like and sun-like eyes, ears akin to the Vedas, breath analogous to wind, life force residing in the heart, and as the inner self of all beings has, upon recognizing it, split open the ashvattha tree and śamī's garbha. With this, he created two arani pieces using that.

sloka: ityuktvā niḥsṛto'śvatthādagnirvāraṇasūcitaḥ| praviveśa śamīgarbhamatha vahniḥ suṣupsayā||
translation: After saying "thus," he emerged from the Ashvattha tree, having contemplated the fire residing in the śamī's seedpod. Then, the fire wished to enter it.

sloka: kravyādamagniṃ pra hiṇomi dūraṃ yamarājño gacchatu ripravāhaḥ | ihaivāyamitaro jātavedā devebhyo havyaṃ vahatu prajānan ||
translation: I properly move the raw flesh offering away from Yama's agni, let the distinct entity approach the gods. Indeed, here is another Jatvedas, the Vedic figure; let it, being in the present, carry the oblation to the gods.

sloka: jātavedase sunavāma somamarātīyato nidahāti vedaḥ | sa naḥ parṣadati durgāṇi viśvā nāveva sindhuṃ duritātyagniḥ ||
translation: We recite the hymns to Jatavedas as prescribed. May he make known to us the obstacles, just as water does not overcome the banks. Indeed, the fire is not overwhelmed by difficulties, like the moon's particular appearance cannot be overpowered by specific evil spirits.

sloka: purā kalpe mahākāle prapanne lokaviśrute āyudhyetāṃ mahātmānau brahmaviṣṇū parasparam tayormānaṃ nirākartuṃ tanmadhye parameśvaraḥ niṣkalastaṃbharūpeṇa svarūpaṃ samadarśayat tataḥ svaliṃgacihnatvātstaṃbhato niṣkalaṃ śivaḥ svaliṃgaṃ darśayāmāsa jagatāṃ hitakāmyayā
translation: In a bygone era, during the grand cycle known as mahākāle in a specific abode of deities (kalpe), when the world was being celebrated and praised (lokaviśrute āyudhyetāṃ), two great souls, Brahma and Vishnu, engaged in a struggle to determine their superiority. Then, Parameshvara, the supreme lord, revealed his true, indivisible form (nirākartuM tayoH mānaM niṣkalastaMBharūpeṇa svarūpaM samadarśayat) in their presence, right between them. Subsequently, as Shiva, he made his distinct personal form visible (tataḥ svaliṃgaM darśayāmāsa), desiring to benefit all the worlds.

sloka: yatra jāto mahātejāḥ kārtikeyo agni saṃbhavaḥ
translation: In the place where Mahateja, possessing great vigor and power, known as Kartikeya, had his origin, associated with Agni, the fire deity, and the third Arhat of the present Avasarpiṇī.

sloka: vā॒yurani̭lama॒mṛta॒mathe॒daṃ bhasmā̭nta॒ śarī̭ram | oṃ krato॒ smara̭ kṛ॒ta sma̭ra॒ krato॒ smara̭ kṛ॒ta sma̭ra ||
translation: "O wind, the imperishable one, recall, for you have turned this body into ash. O Krato, recall, just as you've done in the past."

sloka: pratiṣṭhāpanaṃ savidhikotsarjanamityarthaḥ |
translation: The performer of the ceremony, namely Artha, signifies the meaning of "the establishment (pratiṣṭhā) is the abandonment (utsarjana) according to proper procedure (sa-vidhi)".

sloka: prapāstaḍāgāni ca paropakārāya na dharmāyetyevāvagamyate tathā ca darśanam dhanvanniva prapā asīti tathā sthalayodakaṃ parigṛhṇantīti ca || pra te yakṣi pra ta iyarmi manma bhuvo yathā vandyo no haveṣu | dhanvanniva prapā asi tvamagna iyakṣave pūrave pratna rājan ||
translation: Indeed, it is acknowledged that one should allocate resources like streams and ponds not for religious gain but for the benefit of others, and just as an archer pulls his bowstring, you ought to draw water from the earth. In this vein, Iyarmi, a female muni, much like my reputation extending even to children, you too are worthy of adoration in the city of Pūrā. O Pratna, O king!

sloka: bhojāyāśvaṃ saṃ mṛjantyāśuṃ bhojāyāste kanyā śumbhamānā | bhojasyedaṃ puṣkariṇīva veśma pariṣkṛtaṃ devamāneva citram ||
translation: They (masculine plural) are grooming horses and the demon Śumbha for the cowherd's feast, while also adorning this elegant abode, like a pond embellished for a festival. Moreover, they two (neuter dual) seem to have set their sights on the female gender (kanyā), filled with jealousy and indignation, as if for the god Indra, richly expressed in this astrological house, like a Gandharva's (citram) magnificent mansion.

sloka: iṣṭāpūrtau smṛtau dharmau śrutau tau śiṣṭasaṃmatau | bhuktimuktipradaṃ pūrtamiṣṭaṃ bhogārthasādhanam ||
translation: The ethical precepts of Buddhism (dharmau), regarded as the reward (pūrtau) of fulfillment and desired by all (iṣṭau), remembered through sacred tradition (smṛtau) and orally transmitted by Brahmans from generation to generation (śrutau) are considered to grant liberation (muktipradaṃ) and enjoyment (bhuktimuktipradaṃ). They are the means (sādhanam) of attaining fulfillment (pūrtam), desire (iṣṭam), and enjoyment (bhoga) that has become free (mukti) and is accepted by the worthy (śiṣṭasaṃmatau).

sloka: devā manuṣyagandharvāḥ pitaroragarākṣasāḥ| sthāvarāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃśrayanti jalāśayam||
translation: Devas, ancestors along with humanlike beings, Gandharvas, evil demons, and stationary creatures seek shelter in the life-sustaining water reservoir.

sloka: triṣu lokeṣu sarvatra pūjanīyastaḍāgavān|| dharmasyārthasya kāmasya phalamāhurmanīṣiṇaḥ| taḍāgasukṛtaṃ deśe kṣetramekaṃ mahāśrayam||
translation: In the three realms, everywhere, the seers regard as the fruition of dharma (righteousness), artha (material prosperity), and kama (desire) those who are worthy of honor and have accomplished virtuous deeds. Such a great asylum, the soil of merit, is found in this very place, where pious acts are offered.

sloka: devā manuṣyagandharvāḥ pitaroragarākṣasāḥ| sthāvarāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃśrayanti jalāśayam||
translation: The gods, human ancestors, Gandharvas, Pitrs, Rakshasas, and even immobile beings like the sthavara find protection in the repositories of water such as rivers and ponds.

sloka: prāvṛṭkāle tu pānīyaṃ taḍāge yasya tiṣṭhati || ||agniṣṭomaphalaṃ tasya puruṣasya prakīrtitam |
translation: During the occasion of the ritual, for the one to whom cherished offerings are consistently directed, the result of the Agniṣṭoma sacrifice is celebrated as belonging to that very individual.

sloka: śakralokamavāpnoti taḍāgakaraṇātpathi | marau taḍāge pānīyaṃ yasya tiṣṭhati vai dvijāḥ ||vimānenārkavarṇena brahmalokaṃ sa gacchati |
translation: By traversing the path of ritual actions prescribed by the Śiva-darśana, a man attains the mundane world (sakraloka). Indeed, for him, the two waters (pānīyaṃ) refer to the desirable and cherished rewards in the afterlife. Those who are regarded as dvijas, belonging to the first three varnas, possess this privilege. With his resplendent form, akin to Indra (arkavarṇena), and adhering to brahmanical rituals (vimānenārkavarṇena), he proceeds towards Brahmaloka.

sloka: atha kūpakartustatpravṛtte pānīye duṣkṛtasyārdhaṃ vinaśyati || || taḍāgakṛnnityatṛpto vāruṇaṃ lokaṃ aśnute || || jalapradaḥ sadā tṛpto bhavati || ||
translation: Upon the initiation of malevolent action's bearing fruit, half of it gets destroyed. The one who constantly takes pleasure in creating water bodies partakes in the watery world in complete satisfaction. Perpetually fulfilled, he who provides water becomes.

sloka: devāyatanakārī yasya devasyāyatanaṃ karoti tasyaiva lokaṃ āpnoti || || sudhāsiktaṃ kṛtvā yaśasā virājate || ||vicitraṃ kṛtvā gandharvalokaṃ āpnoti || ||
translation: The one who serves as the artificer of the god's altar, indeed attains that very world of that god. Having made pure with the divine beverage, one shines brightly with fame. By creating something extraordinary and adorned, one reaches the realm of Gandharvas.

sloka: puṣpapradānena śrīmānbhavati || || anulepanapradānena kīrtimān || ||dīpapradānena cakṣuṣmānsarvatrojjvalaśca || ||annapradānena balavān || ||
translation: Through the presentation of blooming flowers, one acquires pleasantness; through the application of an oily substance, one becomes renowned; through kindling a light, one gains sharpness of sight and illuminates all around; through bestowing food in a mystical sense, one becomes stout and strong.

sloka: devanirmālyāpanayanātgodānaphalaṃ āpnoti || ||devagṛhamārjanāttadupalepanātbrāhmaṇocchiṣṭamārjanātpādaśaucādakalyaparicaraṇācca || || kūpārāmataḍāgeṣu devatāyataneṣu ca | punaḥ saṃskārakartā ca labhate maulikaṃ phalam || ||
translation: Through offering garlands to the gods in the ritual, one attains the reward of giving to a brahmin. By cleansing the abode of the divine and removing blemishes, as well as purifying a brahmin's leftovers and one's feet, and by regularly attending to and caring for sacred precincts and deity shrines, one becomes eligible for special rewards. This includes becoming a digger or vendor of roots (maulika), as indicated by the term saṃskāra-kartā.

sloka: dvārībandhiṣu kartavyamutsargaṃ gopradānikam | gosahasraṃ śubhaṃ deyaṃ mahīṃ hemañca dakṣiṇām ||
translation: In the matter of securing the doorkeepers, making arrangements for distributing as donation a thousand gifts in the form of cows, along with golden ornaments and land, is obligatory.

sloka: sadā jalaṃ pavitraṃ syādapavitramasaṃskṛtam | kuśāgreṇāpi rājendra spraṣṭagyamasaṃskṛtam || vāpīkūpataḍāgadau yajjalaṃ syādasaṃskṛtam | apeyaṃ tadbhavetsarve pītvā cāndrāyaṇaṃ caret ||
translation: Always regard water as pure, unsullied, and purifying. Even when touched by a blade of kusha grass, O King, it remains pure. However, water in a well, tank, or pond is considered impure. Thus, one should avoid using such water. If, unknowingly, one does consume it, then one should perform the lunar observance (Andrayanam).

sloka: puṣpaiḥ suragaṇān vṛkṣāḥ phalaiścāpi tathā pitṝn | chāyayā cātithiṃ tāta pūjayanti mahīruhaḥ ||
translation: Trees, venerated one, pay homage to the celestial beings with leaves, to their parents with fruits, and to entitled guests with soothing shade. Similarly, they honor the earth with blossoms.

sloka: vṛkṣāropayiturvṛkṣāḥ paraloke putrā bhavanti || ||vṛkṣaprado vṛkṣaprasūnairdevānprīṇayati || ||phalaiścātithīn || ||chāyayā cābhyāgatān || || deve varṣatyudakena pitṝn || || setukṛtsvargaṃ āpnoti || ||
translation: Through planting trees, such trees become offspring in another realm. The tree planter, through the blossoming of trees, gratifies the gods. With fruits and by granting shade, they please guests and those who draw near. Through rainfall, the tree planter nourishes his ancestors in that world. By constructing a bridge (of merit), one ascends to heaven.

sloka: sthāvarāṇāṃ ca bhūtānāṃ jātayaḥ ṣaṭ prakīrtitāḥ | vṛkṣagulmalatāvallyastvaksārāstṛṇajātayaḥ||
translation: Of stationary objects, the six kinds of genus that are cited as born, that is, trees, shrubs, creeping or winding plants, twining tendrils, cinnamon trees, and plants similar to grass.

sloka: athodyāne pravakṣyāmi praśastānpādapāndvija | ariṣṭāśokapunnāgaśirīṣāmrapriyaṅgavaḥ || || panasāśokadacalījambūlakucadāḍimāḥ | māṅgalyāḥ pūrvamārāme ropaṇīyā gṛheṣu vā || || śālmaliṃ kovidāraṃ ca varjayitvā vibhītakam || || asanaṃ devadāruṃ ca palāśaṃ puṣkaraṃ tathā | na vivarjyastathā kaściddevodyāneṣu jānatā || ||
translation: In the royal gardens, I will reveal to you the commendable species of trees, oh member of the twice-born tribe. The Aristaka, Ashvakarna, Punnaga, Shirisha, and Priyangu trees are said to be auspicious and should be planted in front of houses or any other locations. The Salmali, Kovidara, and Palasa trees, as well as the Pushkara tree, must not be excluded from gardens known to those who are learned.

sloka: āmrāśca siktāḥ pitaraśca prīṇitāḥ ||
translation: The mango trees and the forefathers have been honored and are being kept satisfied, respectively.

sloka: naiyagrodha audumbara āśvatthaḥ plākṣa itīdhmo bhavatyete vai gandharvāpsarasāṃ gṛhāḥ ||
translation: These, revered as the residences of the gandharvas and apsarasas, are famously referred to as nyagrodha, audumbara, asvattha, plaksa, and idhma, among others.

sloka: evameṣu purāṇeṣu taḍāga vidhirucyate|| || kūpavāpīṣu sarvāsu tathā puṣkariṇīṣu ca| eṣa eva vidhirdṛṣṭaḥ pratiṣṭhāsu tathaiva ca|| || mantratastu viśeṣaḥ syāt prasādodyānabhūmiṣu|
translation: According to ancient texts, it is declared: "O tank!" The prescription for creating ponds and lakes is also found to be similar in this regard. Similarly, in all wells and ponds, the arrangements are observed to be the same. However, there may be a distinct feature when it comes to the layout of pleasure gardens and grounds, which is related to mantras or mystical verses.

sloka: vṛkṣāgrātpatitasyāpi ārohātpatitasya ca| maraṇe vāsthibhaṅge vā kartā pāpairna lipyate ||||
translation: Even one who descends from a tree or has fallen, as well as a tree that has been cut down or uprooted, does not incur sin at the time of death or destruction; it is the actor who, due to wrong actions, becomes smeared with demerit.

sloka: jayaṃtyāḥ somavṛkṣasya tathā somavaṭasya ca | panasasya kadaṃbasya niṃbasya dvijasattamāḥ || || pāṭalā kanakasyaiva śālmalīniṃbakasya ca| biṃbāśokavaṭasyaiva pratiṣṭhāṃ naiva kārayet || || bhadrakasya śamīkoṇacaṃḍātakabakasya ca | khadirasyaiva kartavyaṃ karṇavedhaṃ na kārayet ||||
translation: Of the descendants who tend to the somavṛkṣa's trunk and vaṭa tree, as well as to panasas, kadambas, nimbaka, and the most virtuous dvijasattamās; one should not establish the foundation of pāṭalā, kanakasya, śālmalīnimbaka, biṃbāśoka trees, nor perform karṇavedha on bhadrakas, śamīkoṇacaṇḍātakabakas, and khadiras.

sloka: kārayitvā dṛḍhastaṃbhaṃ śubhapakveṣṭakāmayam | śubhaṃ kamaṭhapṛṣṭhābhaṃ bhābhāsitadigaṃtaram || pratiśraye tu vistīrṇe kārite sajale ghane || || dīnānāthajalārthāya kṛtaṃ kiṃ na kṛtaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Having established a firm structure, adorned with auspicious qualities and an attractive back, what purpose does it serve to seek refuge in it when expanded, after concocting a mixture of water and mud? What could not have been done for the benefit of the wretched and helpless, in need of water or any fluid?

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {siddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The conclusive determination (siddhanta) is the acceptance of the governing topic (tantradhikarana) as a Siddha (perfected being), established in the context (abhyupagama) of the treatise, signifying the ultimate accomplishment or perfection in this context.

sloka: saḥ caturvidhaḥ sarvatantrapratitantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthityarthāntarabhāvāt|| {tantrabhedauddeśasūtram}
translation: Being of four kinds, he is established as the inherent meaning of both the dependent and independent factors in all matters related to both Tantra and non-Tantra, due to his distinct inner existence.

sloka: tantrārthasaṃsthitiḥ tantrasaṃsthitiḥ tantramitaretarābhisaṃbaddhasyārthasamūhasyopadeśaḥ śāstram | adhikaraṇānuṣaṅārthā saṃsthitiradhikaraṇasaṃsthitiḥ abhyupagamasaṃsthitiranavadhāritārthaparigrahaḥ tadviśeṣaparīkṣaṇāyābhyupagamasiddhāntaḥ | tantrabhedāttu khalu sa caturvidhaḥ |
translation:
The term "tantra" refers to four categories (caturvidha): 
1. adhikaranasansthiti, the settled practice concerning the locus of an activity,
2. adhikarananushangartha, the relation to the meaning of a locus,
3. abhyupagamasamsthiti, the established understanding of accepted meanings, and 
4. tantrabheda, division in the class of works teaching magical and mystical formularies.

sloka: sarvatantrāviruddhaḥ tantre adhikṛtaḥ arthaḥ sarvatantrasiddhāntaḥ|| {sarvatantrasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The meaning or purpose, personified as the son of Dharma and Buddhi, that is in accord with all doctrines and established as authoritative in later mythology, has been laid down in this treatise.

sloka: yathā dhrāṇādīnīndriyāṇi gandhādaya indriyārthāḥ pṛthivyādī bhūtāni pramāṇairarthasya grahaṇamiti|
translation: Just as the sensation of smells and other objects of sense perception, like touch, relate to their respective senses, and similarly, earth and other elements connect with living beings through correct cognitive faculties.

sloka: samānatantrāsiddhaḥ paratantrāsiddhaḥ pratitantrasiddhāntaḥ||{pratitantrasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: Designated as consistently effective through its own means and established through external means, as well as signifying a reversion to an original state – such are the distinct meanings of 'pratitantra-siddha'.

sloka: yatsiddhau anyaprakaraṇasiddhiḥ saḥ adhikaraṇasiddhāntaḥ|| {adhikaraṇasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: That which is the established rule regarding the accomplishment in a separate subject area, i.e., it is the criterion for establishing the successful achievement of that goal.

sloka: yasyārthasya sidhdāvanye'rthā yadadhiṣṭhānāḥ so'dhikaraṇasiddhāntaḥ | yathā dehendriyavyatirikte jñātā darśanasparśanābhyāmekārthagrahaṇādibhiḥ| atrānuṣaṅgiṇo'rthā indriyanānātvaṃ niyataviṣayāṇīndriyāṇi svaviṣayagrahaṇaliṅgāni jñāturjñānasādhanāni gandhādiguṇavyatiriktāṃ dravyaṃ guṇādhikaraṇamaniyataviṣayāścetanā iti pūrvārthasidhdāvete'rthāḥ sidhyanti na tairvinā so 'rthaḥ saṃbhavatīti|
translation: The one who has achieved mastery over the means to realize the purpose (of sensory organs) is he who has established other purposes, as the self is the location where the senses, known through visual and tactile perception among others, reside. In this context, the objects of the senses are not the means to acquire knowledge; rather, the senses themselves serve as indicators of the knower's knowledge. The instruments to establish the aforementioned purpose are the senses, which have specific objects and distinct qualities from substances. Thus, these objects of the senses cannot independently establish that purpose without the senses; it is impossible for that purpose to emerge without them.

sloka: aparīkṣitābhyupagamāttadviśeṣaparīkṣaṇaṃ abhyupagamasiddhāntaḥ|| {abhyupagamasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: Having previously assented to something without proper analysis, you ought now to examine it, specifically that assumption, which has been admitted as true.

sloka: adhaḥ svidāsīt upari svidāsīt bhīriva vindantī |
translation: Is it beneath or is it above that one finds something to be frightful? (Or: Is it in the lower regions or the upper that one discovers something as frightening?)

sloka: pravṛttaṃ ca nivṛttaṃ ca dvividhaṃ karma vaidikam āvartate pravṛttena nivṛttenāśnute'mṛtam
translation: The Vedic action, of two types - performed and not performed, brings about immortality when both performed and restrained from.

sloka: hiṃsraṃ dravyamayaṃ kāmyamagnihotrādyaśāntidam darśaśca pūrṇamāsaśca cāturmāsyaṃ paśuḥ sutaḥ etadiṣṭaṃ pravṛttākhyaṃ hutaṃ prahutameva ca pūrtaṃ surālayārāma kūpā jīvyādilakṣaṇam
translation: The object of the sacrifice is a substance that is harmful and deeply desired, characterized by the calmness of agnihotra and other rituals such as serving or honoring. The new moon and full moon are offerings, as is the animal sacrifice in the four-month sacrificial session. These have been established as the completed rites, symbolizing life's marks including wells and the navel, also signifying extinction of a living being, possibly referring to the soul's journey after death. The third part in the 7-partite Sāman is the sexual organ, characterized by the dust of Deva-gandharva and an act of pious liberality.

sloka: naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṃ tava || ||
translation: Having regained my memory, thanks to your grace, and freed from ignorance, I stand firm, my doubts dispelled. I will carry out your imperishable command, O one who is beyond destruction.

sloka: saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau | tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate || ||
translation: Both renunciation and karma-yoga lead to the ultimate goal of liberation; however, in the matter of relinquishing actions, karma-yoga is superior.

sloka: tapasvibhyo'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo'pi mato'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna || ||
translation: Surpassing the ascetics, even the one endowed with knowledge is considered inferior to the yogi; the yogi also excels those performing religious actions. Thus, Arjuna, strive to be that yogi.

sloka: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṃ tatam || ||
translation: The supreme Purusha, O Partha, is exclusively attainable through unwavering devotion and not through any other means. This Being resides within all living beings and pervades everything in this world completely.

sloka: tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara | asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ || ||
translation: "Hence, a man who is constantly devoted should always perform his obligatory duties without attachment, for it is such a detached individual who will achieve the supreme goal."

sloka: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā || ||
translation: The man who, dedicating actions to the class of men who are repositories and communicators of sacred knowledge, having abandoned devotion to attachment, treats or deals with them, is not smeared by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not tainted by water's fulfillment.

sloka: oṃ brahmavādino vadanti | kiṃ kāraṇaṃ brahma kutaḥ sma jātā jīvāma kena kva ca sampratiṣṭhā | adhiṣṭhitāḥ kena sukhetareṣu vartāmahe brahmavido vyavasthām || ||
translation: "Those who expound on Brahman say, 'What is the cause behind Brahman's existence, persistence, and establishment? In what pleasant abode are we established, empowered by what inner strength? O Jiva, where and in what manner have you firmly established yourself, having been born from what source?' The knowers of Brahman discuss this matter."

sloka: kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīti || ||
translation: "O Śiva, only by understanding you does one come to know everything about Kṛishṇa. Such is the power of your divine insight."

sloka: dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe | mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca | sthitaṃ ca yacca | sacca tyaṃ ca || bṛha ||
translation: You two, in your forms as both the absolute and the manifested, discern the unconscious (mūrtam) and formless (amūrtam), the transient (martyaṃ) and immortal (amṛtam), the stationary (sthitam) and ever-existing (sat), and that which is and will be (tyam); behold (bṛha) the imperishable.

sloka: ātmetyevopāsītātra hyete sarva ekaṃ bhavanti |
translation: When these are considered as the individual selves (ātman), they indeed become unified as one entity.

sloka: saṃyuktametatkṣaramakṣaraṃ ca vyaktāvyaktaṃ bharate viśvamīśaḥ | anīśaścātmā badhyate bhoktṛbhāvājjñātvā devaṃ mucyate sarvapāśaiḥ || ||
translation: The ruler, who unites and pervades the tangible (kshara) and intangible (akshara) realms of existence in this world, becomes bound as an ātman when taking on the role of experiencer. However, upon recognizing the divine image (deva), one attains liberation from all worldly fetters, gaining enjoyment through knowing the deity Jñā. The Lord who is Kṛishṇa and Āditya, as well as a Sāman, reigns over this manifest and unmanifest universe.

sloka: mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ| manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati||||
translation: I, as an eternal portion of the living being, am flowing in this world; that immortal inheritance is striving to control the six senses (mind, eye, ear, nose, tongue, and skin) that are in their natural state within the physical body.

sloka: na puṇyapāpe mama nāsti nāśo na janma dehendriyabuddhirasti | na bhūmirāpo na ca vahnirasti na cānilo me'sti na cāmbaraṃ ca || || evaṃ viditvā paramātmarūpaṃ guhāśayaṃ niṣkalamadvitīyam | samastasākṣiṃ sadasadvihīnaṃ prayāti śuddhaṃ paramātmarūpam || ||
translation: For fear that my religious merit or demerit may not be annihilated, that birth, physical manifestation, the power of forming and retaining conceptions, soil, water to be obtained, a son of Kṛishṇa, belonging to Vāyu or Anila, the atmosphere do not exist for me. I am above all this. By understanding the highest personal principle of life as an indestructible, singular, all-witnessing consciousness that is beyond being and non-being, one attains purity of spirit.

sloka: manorhairaṇyagarbhasya ye marīcyādayaḥ sutāḥ | teṣāṃ ṛṣīṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ putrāḥ pitṛgaṇāḥ smṛtāḥ ṛṣibhyaḥ pitaro jātāḥ pitṛbhyo devamānavāḥ | devebhyastu jagatsarvaṃ caraṃ sthāṇvanupūrvaśaḥ
translation: Of Marici and others, the progeny of Manorhairaṇyagarbha, who are known as the offspring of the devas, all those sons of sages are considered to have been born from the devas. They are remembered as the fathers of humanity, for they are the origin of this moving and stationary world that came into existence beforehand, including Krsna's plants and the small shell Cypraea moneta.

sloka: vasūnvadanti tu pitṝnrudrāṃścaiva pitāmahān | prapitāmahāṃstathādityānśrutireṣā sanātanī
translation: The Vasus, indeed, speak of the fathers, and so do the Rudras, as well as the paternal grandfathers and great-grandfathers; this tradition, always to be fed during Śrāddhas, is heard.

sloka: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ somapāstu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ | pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ
translation: The ones named somapā serve as oblations for the brahmins and kshatriyas, while those called ājyapā function as such for vaisyas and sukālinah for shudras. Descendants of Angira, known for generous sacrificial offerings and named haviṣmanta, are the somapās. Likewise, Pulastyas's and Vasiṣṭhas's sons are referred to as ājyapās.

sloka: tasmādapaḥ sambharati tasmāddhiraṇyaṃ sambharati taddyāvāpṛthivyo rasena samardhayati tasmādūṣāntsambharati tasmādākhukarīṣaṃ sambharati
translation: Hence, it (Agni) is nourished from that spot, similarly enriches the earth with its sap, and makes the heaven and earth combine. Moreover, it gathers the Lipeocercis Serrata grass and dry cow-dung from there.

sloka: kṛttikāsu rohiṇyāṃ mṛgaśirasi phalgunīṣu viśākhayoruttarayoḥ proṣṭhapadayoḥ ||
translation: During the month of Phalguna, at the beginning of Krittikas, Rohini, Mriga Shirish, and under the constellations Viśākhā's later parts, as well as at the start of Uttara-Phalgunis, and in the localities named Proṣṭha-pada.

sloka: kṛttikāsu brāhmaṇa ādadhīta mukhyo brahmavarcasī bhavati || gṛhāṃstasyāgnirdāhuko bhavati ||
translation: In the Krittikas constellation, a Brahmin who makes it a regular practice to study (this) becomes endowed with the chief brilliance of sacred knowledge; for him, the house transforms into a sacrificial fire.

sloka: kṛttikāsvagnī ādadhīta | etyāhuretadhda vā agnernakṣatraṃ
translation: In the constellation of Kṛttikās, two fires are established, as per the tradition; this is referred to as the asterism known as Agnier.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The two seasons are Vasanta (spring) and Grishma (summer), followed by Varsha (monsoon); then come Sharat (autumn) and Hemant (pre-winter), culminating in the cool season, Shishir. These are the seasons recognized by Brahma and considered as the regents of the Nakshatras Maghā and Mūla.

sloka: rātriṃ jāgaraṇadhāraṇe śakalairvā
translation: Should one stay awake, enduring through the night, along with all (other beings), or what is suggested?

sloka: śamīgarbhādagniṃ manthati | eṣā vā agneryajñiyā tanūḥ |
translation: This is the manifestation of Agni, generated from the rough coat of Prosopis Spicigera or Mimosa Suma's fruit, that gets ignited. Indeed, these (manifestations) are the sacrificial offerings for Ficus Glomerata.

sloka: sa bhūrbhuva ityetaistribhirakṣarairgārhapatyamādadhāti dve pariśinaṣṭyayātayāmatāyai
translation: With the three syllables "bhūrbhuva," Brahma establishes the sacrificial offering, the householders fire. Two (entities) are maintained through successive actions, while you all (plural) are invited to approach for any purpose, and she becomes bound (subjugated).

sloka: yo aśvatthaḥ śamīgarbha āruroha tvesacā | taṃ tvāharāmi brahmaṇā yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saheti pūrṇāhutyantamagnyādheyaṃ
translation: The holy fig tree, which has sprouted from the Prosopis Spicigera or Mimosa Suma's seed and represents the fire, I now offer to you through the sacred syllable Om, using sacrificial implements and accompaniments, along with this declaration in a complete fire ritual.

sloka: punarādheyamādhānā'pratijñātasya rājyayaśaskāmasya vā trirātrāvaramagnīnutsṛjya sadyo vā punarvasvoḥ varṣāsu madhyandine vā kuśairādhānam vrīhyapūpamarkapalāśayoḥ pakvaṃ gārhapatyasthāne nidadhātyevamāhamanīyasya yāvaṃ sadyaścet
translation: Again, if one who has not made a prior commitment to perform the task, either eager for kingship or personal pleasure, were to abandon the sacred fires after three nights, and prepare in the middle of the day, using rice, barley, and ripe fruits, an offering on the consecrated grounds; I will do the same. This is my solemn pledge: I will offer immediately and without reservation whatever is mine.

sloka: viṣṇuranyā devatāsītso'bravīdviṣṇavehīdamā hariṣyāvo yenāyamidamiti sa viṣṇustredhātmānaṃ vi nyadhatta pṛthivyāṃ tṛtīyamantarikṣe tṛtīyaṃ divi tṛtīyamabhiparyāvartāddhyabibhedyatpṛthivyāṃ tṛtīyamāsīttenendro vajramudayacchadviṣṇvanusthitaḥ so'bravītanmā me pra hārasti vā idaṃ
translation: In response, the sage among the gods, Viṣṇu, declared, "I will distribute my own self, encompassing three parts on earth, two parts in the intermediate space, and three parts in heaven. I have already established myself thus. Just as Indra has emerged, equipped with his thunderbolt, so too have I established myself. What then do you seek to take from me or from here?"

sloka: mayi vīryaṃ tatte pra dāsyāmīti tadasmai prāyacchattatpratyagṛhṇādadhā meti tadviṣṇaveti prāyacchattadviṣṇuḥ pratyagṛhṇādasmāsvindra indriyaṃ dadhātviti yadantarikṣe tṛtī̭yamāsīttenendro vajramudayacchadviṣṇvanusthitaḥ so'bravīnmā me pra hārasti vā idaṃ
translation: He vowed to bestow his vigor upon whoever pledged, "I will grant this vigor to that Viṣṇu who receives it back from Indra, and who then makes it his own." And so, Indra, concealed in the atmosphere, wielded the thunderbolt. Then he, Viṣṇu, said, "Bestow this radiant weapon upon me." Is it for this purpose that you have arrived, or are there other intentions at play?

sloka: saptadhā tu kṛte garbhe ditiḥ parama duḥkhitā sahasrākṣam durādharṣam vākyam sa anunayā abravīt
translation: In the womb, divided into seven parts, Diti, deeply anguished, addressed Sahasraksha, the invincible one, with respectful and affectionate speech.

sloka: vāta skaṃdhā ime sapta carantu divi putraka mārutā iti vikhyātā divyarūpā mama ātmajāḥ
translation: May these five sense objects, referred to as the seven breezes, O dear son, conduct themselves in the celestial realm. They are the divine and handsome self-originated sons, well-known as the wind gods. Thus, they roam in the sky, as revealed.

sloka: yadacarastanvā vāvṛdhāno balānīndra prabruvāṇo janeṣu | māyetsā te yāni yuddhānyāhurnādya śatruṃ nanu purā vivitse ||
translation: When, acting as an example and continually gaining strength, you (masc. sg.) proclaim to people the might of others' forces, as Indra does, may those battles not arise anew for you. Indeed, haven't you already conquered your enemy in the past?

sloka: śateṣu jāyate śūraḥ sahasreṣu ca paṇḍitaḥ | vaktā śatasahasreṣu dātā bhavati vā na vā ||
translation: In twenty units, a valiant man arises, among thousands a scholar is born; in hundreds, one becomes a speaker, or possibly not, and a giver as well.

sloka: kuṭumbabharaṇāddravyaṃ yatkiṃcidatiricyate | taddeyaṃ upahṛtyānyaddadaddoṣaṃ avāpnuyāt | | | |
translation: Whoever acquires any material object beyond what is needed to maintain the household, if they consider it as meant for giving away, they will not incur a fault.

sloka: śaktaḥ parajane dātā svajane duḥkhajīvini | madhvāpāto viṣāsvādaḥ sa dharmapratirūpakaḥ | |
translation: Readily giving to those in foreign lands, yet living meagerly in their own, partaking in poison while relishing sweets – such an individual, embodying this paradoxical behavior, is characteristic of dharmic principles.

sloka: tatra guṇānsamīkṣya yathāśakti deyam
translation: In that situation, after examining the excellences, one should give (in charity) according to one's capacity, indeed.

sloka: indriyaprītyarthasya tu bhikṣaṇamanimittam | na tadādriyeta ::: yoktā ca dharmayukteṣu dravyaparigraheṣu ca ::: pratipādayitā ca tīrthe :::
translation: The pursuit of alms for the satisfaction of the senses is merely a means, not an end in itself. One must not develop an attachment to it. Furthermore, one who is established in dharmic principles should donate wealth during sacred observances, both in terms of spiritual teachings and material resources.

sloka: yantā cātīrthe yato na bhayaṃ syāt ::: saṃgrahītā ca manuṣyān :::
translation: At a sacred river, where one can journey without fear and amass people (or supporters).

sloka: deśataḥ kālataḥ śaucataḥ samyak pratigrahītṛta iti dānāni pratipādayati :::
translation: He instructs that gifts should be offered, taking into account the appropriate time, place, and cleanliness, as well as being fully prepared and capable of receiving (pratigrahītṛta iti) them.

sloka: yadyasya vihitaṃ carma yat sūtraṃ yā ca mekhalā | yo daṇḍo yacca vasanaṃ tattadasya vrateṣvapi || sevetemāṃstu niyamān brahmacārī gurau vasan | sanniyamyendriyagrāmaṃ tapovṛddhyarthamātmanaḥ ||
translation: If one is ordained to wear the leather strap, sacred thread, and she the belt, he the staff, and those the garments, then they should observe this discipline as a brahmachari under their guru. Restraining the powers of their senses, they should don these for spiritual advancement and religious austerity.

sloka: mekhalādhāraṇabhaikṣacaryadaṇḍasamidādhānopasparśanaprātarabhivādā nityam
translation: Practicing every day, respectfully greeting and touching the ascetic’s staff, after putting on the bark cloth and alms bowl, is my unwavering routine.

sloka: brahma vedastadadhyayanārthaṃ yadvrataṃ tadapi brahmataccaratīti brahmacārī |
translation: A person dedicated to Brahma-veda study should commit to that vow, which aims at understanding the Brāhmaṇa portion of the Veda. Such a practicing individual is known as a brahmacārī.

sloka: mekhalājinavāsāṃsi jaṭādaṇḍakamaṇḍalūn | bibhṛyādupavītaṃ ca darbhapāṇiryathoditam || ||
translation: Should one let grow the sword-belt (i.e., wear a sacred thread), the clothing or feathers of an arrow, and the knotted hair and staff of a Rakshas, all adorned with marks of asceticism? The hands, holding a tuft or bunch of darbha grass, should also be carried in such a way.

sloka: daṇḍājinopavītāni mekhalāṃ caiva dhārayet |
translation: He shall have him wear the sacred thread and sword-belt, truly fulfilling his duty to observe and practice self-control. (Note: 'Ājina' here means a place for running, which is used metaphorically to refer to a sacred thread.)

sloka: muñjānāṃ valkalānāntu kramānmaujjyāḥ prakīrtitāḥ || mārgavaiyādhravāstāni carmāṇi vratacāriṇāṃ | parṇapippalavilvānāṃ kramāddaṇḍāḥ prakīrtitāḥ ||
translation: The use of kusa grass and bark garments, praised for being traditional, are well-known. For those who adhere to austere practices, the rules sanctioned by tradition dictate that they carry staffs made from trees described in sequence.

sloka: kārṣṇarauravabāstāni carmāṇi brahmacāriṇaḥ | vasīrannānupūrvyeṇa śāṇakṣaumāvikāni ca | | | |
translation: "Celibate students should traditionally don leather garments, as well as those made of bark and sheepskin, entering upon (these rituals) in succession."

sloka: aiṇeyamajinamuttarīyaṃ brāhmaṇasya rauravaṃ rājanyasya ājaṃ gavyaṃ vā vaiśyasya sarveṣāṃ vā gavyamasati pradhānatvāt
translation: The pursuit of a Brahmin is his debt-free state, symbolized as the tiger's joyous, transporting skin, and that of a king is ruling a kingdom. Among these, for a cow or any property holds great significance, be it for a vassal or even Kṛishṇa himself.

sloka: avakrāḥ satvacaḥ sarve nāvipluṣṭāstu daṇḍakāḥ ||
translation: Indeed, all the trees in the Dandaka forest stand upright and have not been disturbed.

sloka: kauśaṃ sautraṃ vā tristrivṛd yajñopavītam || ā nābheḥ ||
translation: A sacred thread, whether it is made of Kuśa grass or composed of threads, becomes threefold when ritually tied around the waist.

sloka: kārpāsaṃ upavītaṃ syādviprasyordhvavṛtaṃ trivṛt | śaṇasūtramayaṃ rājño vaiśyasyāvikasautrikam | | | | vāsopavīte kārpāsakṣaumorṇānāṃ yathākramaṃ |
translation: The cotton cloth should be made into a sacred thread, perhaps it is expressed as worn by the domestic priest with its upper fold un twisted and composed of three folds. Likewise, for the merchant, his untwisted sacred thread should consist of two silk threads, named after the Asura Maya, arranged in proper order, woven like a woolen thread.

sloka: mekhalāṃ ajinaṃ daṇḍaṃ upavītaṃ kamaṇḍalum | apsu prāsya vinaṣṭāni gṛhṇītānyāni mantravat | | | |
translation: With mantra-infused consciousness, one ought to make familiar or acquainted with oneself the worn-out garments, tiger hide, staff, sacred thread, and water pot, as if breathing new life into them or perceiving them anew.

sloka: upanīya guruḥ śiṣyaṃ sikṣayecchaucamāditaḥ | ācāramagnikāryaṃ ca sandhyopāsanameva ca ||
translation: After undertaking the approach, the teacher should instruct the disciple, who is to be taught, being eager to learn, on proper conduct, practicable duties, and sandhyUpāsanam.

sloka: snānaṃ abdaivatairmantrairmārjanaṃ prāṇasaṃyamaḥ | sūryasya cāpyupasthānaṃ gāyatryāḥ pratyahaṃ japaḥ | | | |
translation: The ritual bathing in sacred waters, the daily observance of purification with divine mantras, control of the life-energy through discipline, paying respects to the Sun, and the daily repetition of Gayatri every morning.

sloka: nityaṃ snātvā śuciḥ kuryāddevarṣipitṛtarpaṇam | devatābhyarcanaṃ caiva samidādhānaṃ eva ca | | | |
translation: Constantly bathing and maintaining purity, one should perform the tarpaṇa ceremony for the devarṣi-pitṛs, offer worship to the divinities, and carry out the samidādhana rite.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātarupāsīta gurvagnyarkasurottamān | ubhe sandhye ca yatavāgjapan brahma samāhitaḥ || ||
translation: At dawn and dusk, one should pay respect to the foremost among gurus, fire deities, sun gods, and surgeons; established in concentration, they should recite the sacred syllable "brahma" while engaged in muttering or invoking it in a low voice.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātaśca juhuyānnāmedhyaṃ vyastahastakaṃ | dūrādāhṛtya samidhaḥ sannidadhyādvihāyasi | sāyaṃḥ prātaśca juhuyāttābhiragniṃ atandritaḥ | | | |
translation: In the evening and in the morning, you should offer oblations, having arranged the fire altar's components and fetched the firewood from afar. With a steady mind, approach, kindle, and meditate on the undeterred fire in the early morning and also in the evening.

sloka: chandāṃsyadhīyīta gurorāhūtaścetsuyantritaḥ | upakrame'vasāne ca caraṇau śirasā namet || ||
translation: One invited by the teacher, well-restrained, and rarely in reversed order at the beginning and end of a particular ceremony preparatory to reading the Veds, should learn by heart the hymns, with feet reaching down to the knees, and head bending down in reverence.

sloka: codito guruṇā nityaṃ apracodita eva vā | kuryādadhyayane yatnaṃ ācāryasya hiteṣu ca | | | |
translation: Even if informed by the wife of the teacher or left alone, should one (the student) consistently make an effort in studying and serving the teacher's interests as well.

sloka: yajñānāṃ tapasāṃ caiva śubhānāṃ caiva karmaṇām | veda eva dvijātīnāṃ niḥśreyasakaraḥ paraḥ | | | |
translation: Of all sacrificial rituals, austerities, and virtuous actions, the knowledge of the Vedas is unquestionably the leading cause of the highest good for the twice-born.

sloka: vedaṃ eva sadābhyasyettapastapsyandvijottamaḥ | vedābhyāso hi viprasya tapaḥ paraṃ ihocyate | | | |
translation: The highly qualified twice-born person should practice reciting the Vedas daily, as the persistent effort (abhyasa) in studying the Vedas is considered the utmost religious austerity (tapah) for a brahmin (viprasya).

sloka: madhunā payasā caiva sa devāṃstarpayeddvijaḥ | pitṝnmadhughṛtābhyāṃ ca ṛco'dhīte ca yo'nvaham | | | | yajūṃṣi śaktito'dhīte yo'nvahaṃ sa ghṛtāmṛtaiḥ | prīṇāti devānājyena madhunā ca pitṝṃstathā | | | | sa tu somaghṛtairdevāṃstarpayedyo'nvahaṃ paṭhet | sāmāni tṛptiṃ kuryācca pitṝṇāṃ madhusarpiṣā | | | | medasā tarpayeddevānatharvāṅgirasaḥ paṭhan | pitṝṃśca madhusarpirbhyāṃ anvahaṃ śaktito dvijaḥ | | | | vākovākyaṃ purāṇaṃ ca nārāśaṃsīśca gāthikāḥ | itihāsāṃstathā vidyāḥ śaktyādhīte hi yo'nvaham | | | | māṃsakṣīraudanamadhu tarpaṇaṃ sa divaukasām | karoti tṛptiṃ kuryācca pitṝṇāṃ madhusarpiṣā | | | |
translation: A twice-born individual, desiring to please the deities with ghee and milk, and their forefathers with offerings prepared from ghee and honey, is capable of performing rites during the recitation of Ṛk hymns. The one who, daily, delights the gods with the Soma ritual using ghee, gratifies his ancestors with a mixture of honey and curds, and nourishes the gods with an offering from animal fat and curds. One who is capable should perform the rites prescribed in the Ātharvaṇa texts for satisfying the ancestors with offerings of honey and curds. One should please the gods and ancestors with oblations of ghee, milk, and curds as well as with the recitation of ancient aphorisms and gāthikī verses. One who is capable should perform the rites for satisfying the gods and ancestors using oblations made from meat, rice porridge, and curds.

sloka: yaṃ yaṃ kratuṃ adhīte ca tasya tasyāpnuyātphalam | | | |
translation: Whichever sacrificial rite he undertakes to study, he will attain its respective fruit (reward or punishment).

sloka: trirvittapūrṇapṛthivī dānasya phalaṃ aśnute | tapasaśca parasyeha nityaṃ svādhyāyavāndvijaḥ | | | |
translation: Thrice endowed with wealth and completely perfected, the land experiences the result of giving; in the same way, a Brāhman, constantly engaged in the recitation or perusal of sacred texts, reaps the reward of religious austerity.

sloka: bhaikṣeṇa vartayennityaṃ naikānnādī bhavedvratī | bhaikṣeṇa vratino vṛttirupavāsasamā smṛtā | | | |
translation: Should one constantly adopt begging as a behavior or tend to it? In that case, such an individual observing this vow of mendicancy is equated with intermittent fasting.

sloka: brāhmaṇeṣu caredbhaikṣaṃ anindyeṣvātmavṛttaye | | | |
translation: A Brahmin should continuously undertake to accept a multitude of alms from those who are pure, uncondemned, and self-controlled, maintaining an upright nature.

sloka: prathamaṃ tatra bhhikṣeta yatra bhikṣā dhruvaṃ bhavet |
translation: In that place, he should first beg for the foremost kind of alms that is surely available.

sloka: mātaraṃ vā svasāraṃ vā māturvā bhaginīṃ nijām | bhikṣeta bhikṣāṃ prathamaṃ yā cainaṃ nāvamānayet | | | |
translation: He should first approach his mother or sister, or a maternal relative, to beg alms from her, respecting her as a guru-like figure - whoever she may be - and must not disrespect her.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātaścaredbhaikṣaṃ gurave tannivedayet | bhuñjīta yadyanujñāto no cedupavasetkvacit || ||
translation: At dusk and at daybreak, may he continue to beg for alms and communicate this to his wife, the teacher's companion. May he partake of what has been approved; but if not granted permission, let him not undertake eating at any time.

sloka: vratavaddevadaivatye pitrye karmaṇyatha rṣivat | kāmaṃ abhyarthito'śnīyādvrataṃ asya na lupyate | | | | brāhmaṇasyaiva karmaitadupadiṣṭaṃ manīṣibhiḥ | rājanyavaiśyayostvevaṃ naitatkarma vidhīyate | | | |
translation: Just as the sage performs religious rites in worship of the Pitṛis according to scriptural injunctions, and does not break his vow to a deity, so should one similarly partake of food if requested by others, without breaking one's own vow. This duty has been specifically ordained for the brāhmaṇa by learned men, and not for the rājanya or vaiśya. Indeed, it is enjoined as a religious act or ceremony for him alone.

sloka: vedayajñairahīnānāṃ praśastānāṃ svakarmasu | brahmacāryāharedbhaikṣaṃ gṛhebhyaḥ prayato'nvaham | | | | guroḥ kule na bhikṣeta na jñātikulabandhuṣu | alābhe tvanyagehānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ vivarjayet | | | | sarvaṃ vāpi caredgrāmaṃ pūrvoktānāṃ asaṃbhave | niyamya prayato vācaṃ abhiśastāṃstu varjayet | | | |
translation: O virtuous one, should a student of sacred knowledge, practicing their own duties, partake alms from the household of their teacher or relatives? If not available there, then they should first reject the option of other households. They should meticulously follow all prescribed duties in the village. If not possible, they should even avoid the entire village. Having regulated their speech, they should refrain from uttering harsh words.

sloka: akṛtvā bhaikṣacaraṇaṃ asamidhya ca pāvakam | anāturaḥ saptarātraṃ avakīrṇivrataṃ caret | | | |
translation: Without embracing the life of a mendicant and overlooking the sacred fire, a truthful individual ought to wander as an ascetic during the seven mystical nights, abiding by their vow, and not letting their chastity be violated or consumed by any burning desire.

sloka: brahmacārī vratī nityaṃ nityaṃ dīkṣāparo vaśī | gurucchāyānugo nityamadhīyānaḥ suyantritaḥ | avicālyavratopetaṃ kṛtyaṃ kurvanvasetsadā ||
translation: The one who is perpetually practicing brahmacharya, steadfast in observing his vow, constantly dedicated to the initiation process, holding others in magical submission, well-restrained, a devoted student of the guru's teachings, and firmly committed to an unwavering resolve, should always carry out this duty with constant dedication.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca || ||
translation: Maintaining self-control, having enjoyed sensual pleasures, demonstrating expertise while being a lover, steadfast in faith, and having conquered his senses, he should engage with women and those who have been similarly subdued, for as long as it is required to fulfill the objective.

sloka: vasanneko japannekaḥ sarvānvedānyudhiṣṭhira | ekasminneva cācārye śuśrūṣurmalapaṅkavān ||
translation: Yudhishthira, being uniquely dedicated to reciting and studying all the Vedas, should serve a solitary preeminent teacher attentively and eagerly, even if it implies being smeared with moral impurity.

sloka: guruṃ caivāpyupāsīta svādhyāyārthaṃ samāhitaḥ | | | |
translation: One should also revere the guru, who is the author of a Mantra, being fully absorbed and focused, as applicable for self-study.

sloka: brahmacārī gurukule vasan dānto gurorhitam | ācaran dāsavannīco gurau sudṛḍhasauhṛdaḥ || || āhūtaścāpyadhīyīta labdhaṃ cāsmai nivedayet | hitaṃ tasyācarennityaṃ manovākkāyakarmabhiḥ | | | |
translation: Practicing brahmacarya, residing in the guru's household, restraining senses, obedient to the guru's instructions, serving like a devoted servant, having intense fondness for the guru – such a self-disciplined student, when summoned and instructed, shall pay attention and communicate those teachings, consistently applying them in thought, word, and action for the teacher's wellbeing.

sloka: śayyāsane'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet | śayyāsanasthaścaivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet | | | | ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hyutkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati | pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punastānpratipadyate | | | |
translation: In the location of repose, one should not become fully engaged in anything other than beneficial pursuits; having risen from the seat, one must greet him. Indeed, with the act of standing up and greeting, the vital breaths of both the youthful and the elderly are rejuvenated.

sloka: śreyaḥsu guruvadvṛttiṃ nityaṃ eva samācaret | guruputreṣu cāryeṣu guroścaiva svabandhuṣu | | | | bālaḥ samānajanmā vā śiṣyo vā yajñakarmaṇi | adhyāpayangurusuto guruvanmānaṃ arhati | | | | yathā khanankhanitreṇa naro vāryadhigacchati | tathā gurugatāṃ vidyāṃ śuśrūṣuradhigacchati | | | |
translation: "O revered one, constantly adopt the conduct of a guide. In disciples, sons of a guru, and in relatives, treat them as you would yourself. A child or a student, while engaged in a yajña, should have others perform it. Through servitude to the guru, perfection is attained. Just as a man purifies himself by washing off impurities with water, similarly, by serving and learning from the guru, spiritual enlightenment is achieved."

sloka: teṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ śuśrūṣā paramaṃ tapa ucyate | | | | triṣveteṣvitikṛtyaṃ hi puruṣasya samāpyate | | | | tayornityaṃ priyaṃ kuryādācāryasya ca sarvadā | teṣveva triṣu tuṣṭeṣu tapaḥ sarvaṃ samāpyate | | | |
translation: Of the three types, serving is held as the utmost religious austerity; indeed, through performing duties in all three fields of study, a person is perfected. One should constantly make what is dear to the teacher into practice; by pleasing the teacher through these three means, one fulfills all austerities. Specifically, when fulfilling these three duties and pleasing the teacher, one achieves satisfaction and completion in every aspect.

sloka: sarve tasyādṛtā dharmā yasyaite traya ādṛtāḥ | anādṛtāstu yasyaite sarvāstasyāphalāḥ kriyāḥ | | | |
translation: For Kṛishṇa, all religious rites and ceremonies performed without reverence are in vain, whereas the three-fold duties, when revered, bear fruit for that individual.

sloka: varjayetpramadāgāthāmagṛhastho bṛhadvrataḥ | indriyāṇi pramāthīni harantyapi yatermanaḥ || ||
translation: The grhastha, resolute in his vows and having renounced worldly life, should cause others to shun recklessness while keeping his senses in check, as even the wise may have their consciousness swept away by these powerful, unruly forces.

sloka: keśaprasādhanonmardasnapanābhyañjanādikam | gurustrībhiryuvatibhiḥ kārayennātmano yuvā || || nanvagniḥ pramadā nāma ghṛtakumbhasamaḥ pumān | kalpayitvā''tmanā yāvadābhāsamidamīśvaraḥ | dvaitaṃ tāvanna viramettato hyasya viparyayaḥ || ||
translation: A young person should have their gurus, whom they should treat like women in their prime, perform these activities on their behalf: washing the hair, massaging the body, and applying ointments, among other things. Why? Because this individual, named Agni Pramada, is likened to a pot filled with ghee. One must persist in duality until they reach their full potential through their own efforts; such is not easily abandoned for this person. Indeed, for him, it is the opposite of how things usually are.

sloka: śuśrūṣāṃ satataṃ kurvanguroḥ saṃpraṇameta ca| ṣaṭ‌karmasvanivṛttaśca na pravṛttaśca sarvaśaḥ|| nācaratyadhikāreṇa seveta dviṣato na ca| eṣo''śramapadastāta brahmacāriṇa iṣyate||
translation: With unwavering diligence, one should constantly attend to and pay respects to the guru; always established in the six forms of action (i.e., hearing, chanting, remembering, serving, worshipping, and following), yet never engaged in other activities. One should not act beyond their prescribed duties nor serve or associate with an enemy. Such a person is recognized as a brahmacārī, having attained the stage of renunciation.

sloka: varjayenmadhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasānstriyaḥ | śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam | | | | abhyaṅgaṃ añjanaṃ cākṣṇorupānacchatradhāraṇam | kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca lobhaṃ ca nartanaṃ gītavādanam | | | | dyūtaṃ ca janavādaṃ ca parivādaṃ tathānṛtam | strīṇāṃ ca prekṣaṇālambhaṃ upaghātaṃ parasya ca | | | |
translation: He should abstain in this world from consuming meat, alcohol, and garlands with strong fragrances, as well as all substances that harm living beings and sharp weapons. He should also avoid causing harm to others, engaging in gambling, gossiping, or desisting from looking at women lustfully or causing disputes among people. Additionally, he should not eat unwholesome food, nor should he indulge in falsehoods, or willingly slay other living beings. He must remain fearless, mark his eyes, and restrain himself from acting impulsively, while also avoiding greed, wrath, and dancing.

sloka: ekaḥ śayīta sarvatra na retaḥ skandayetkva cit | kāmāddhi skandayanreto hinasti vrataṃ ātmanaḥ | | | | svapne siktvā brahmacārī dvijaḥ śukraṃ akāmataḥ | snātvārkaṃ arcayitvā triḥ punarmāṃ ityṛcaṃ japet | | | |
translation: Let the solitary one lie down everywhere, refraining from ejaculation of sin; for, indulging in desire while leaping upon someone unwillingly will destroy his self-control. Having learned to control his virile semen without desire in a dream, a twice-born practising brahmacari should wash, honor the sun, and thrice repeat the mantra, "May I be protected."

sloka: vedānadhītya vedau vā vedaṃ vāpi yathākramam | aviplutabrahmacaryo gṛhasthāśramaṃ āvaset | | | |
translation: After diligently studying either one or both of the Vedas according to the prescribed order and from their Brāhmaṇa portion having grown two other departments of Vedic literature, a householder should reside in his stage of life, maintaining unbroken celibacy as per tradition.

sloka: brahmavarcasakāmasya kāryo viprasya pañcame | rājño balārthinaḥ ṣaṣṭhe vaiśyasyehārthino'ṣṭame | | | |
translation: For a Brāhman seeking brahmavarcasa, their task is set by the fifth day; for a Yaksha king in need of strength, it is the sixth day; for a vaiśya, eager for wealth, it is the eighth day.

sloka: prativedaṃ brahmacaryaṃ dvādaśābdāni pañca vā | grahaṇāntikaṃ ityeke keśāntaścaiva ṣoḍaśe | | | |
translation: Grasp this discipline known as brahmacarya, defined as follows: after twelve days, during five specific days or in the period leading up to grahaṇa, some observe it until the end of keśānta on the sixteenth day.

sloka: ṣaṭtriṃśadābdikaṃ caryaṃ gurau traivedikaṃ vratam | tadardhikaṃ pādikaṃ vā grahaṇāntikaṃ eva vā | | | |
translation: In the presence of Pāṇḍu-teacher, one should practice the triple-vedic conduct; increase it by a half or a sixth, up to the point of acquiring any science or at the very moment of its completion.

sloka: taṃ pratītaṃ svadharmeṇa brahmadāyaharaṃ pituḥ | sragviṇaṃ talpa āsīnaṃ arhayetprathamaṃ gavā | | | |
translation: Honor that person, who has been recognized and forms the very essence of his dharma, by serving the class of men who are repositories and communicators of sacred knowledge (Brahmins) and giving a gift at the ceremony of initiation to his father. Place the foremost offering in the shape of a cow, adorned with a garland, and provide him with a specially prepared seat.

sloka: na pūrvaṃ gurave kiṃ cidupakurvīta dharmavit | snāsyaṃstu guruṇājñaptaḥ śaktyā gurvarthaṃ āharet | | | | kṣetraṃ hiraṇyaṃ gāṃ aśvaṃ chatropānahaṃ āsanam | dhānyaṃ śākaṃ ca vāsāṃsi gurave prītiṃ āvahet | | | |
translation: Let not a follower of dharma, possessing knowledge, have previously behaved inappropriately towards the wife of a teacher. One should carry out the instructions, utilizing one's strength for the benefit of the teacher personified as the son of Dharma and Buddhi. I will provide the soil of merit, delectable offerings such as a cow and a horse named after a teacher, shelter, a seat, grains, vegetables, clothes, and affection to the teacher.

sloka: dattvā varamanujñāto guroḥ kāmaṃ yadīśvaraḥ | gṛhaṃ vanaṃ vā praviśetpravrajettatra vā vaset || ||
translation: Having granted the reward, if the Lord of Love has approved, he may either choose to dwell in a householder's life or adopt the renunciate path, remaining therein at will.

sloka: caritabrahmacaryasya brāhmaṇasya viśāṃpate| bhaikṣacaryāsvadhīkāraḥ praśasto dehamokṣaṇe||
translation: The brahmin who has practiced self-control and whose past actions are pure has the authorization over practicing austerities by begging, which is praiseworthy for leading to the emancipation of his manifestation. This is commendable for the repositories and communicators of sacred knowledge in the society, as it leads to the liberation of their bodies.

sloka: yadi tvātyantikaṃ vāsaṃ rocayeta guroḥ kule | yuktaḥ paricaredenaṃ ā śarīravimokṣaṇāt | | | | ācārye tu khalu prete guruputre guṇānvite | gurudāre sapiṇḍe vā guruvadvṛttiṃ ācaret | | | | eteṣvavidyamāneṣu sthānāsanavihāravān | prayuñjāno'gniśuśrūṣāṃ sādhayeddehaṃ ātmanaḥ | | | |
translation: If you wish to permanently reside in the abode of the guru or teacher, having been capable, perform service to him for the liberation of his body. When the guru has passed away, if a son or relative endowed with his qualities is present, then revere them as the guru. Towards a wife, kinsman connected by the offering of the Piṇḍa at the Śrāddha, or any other such person acting as a guru, similarly, show devotion. In case these positions are unavailable, engage in religious activities while practicing obedience to the fires, striving to cultivate your own self.

sloka: naiṣṭhiko brahmacārī tu vasedācāryasaṃnidhau | tadabhāve'sya tanaye patnyāṃ vaiśvānare'pi vā | | | |
translation: A perpetual student of sacred knowledge should remain in the vicinity of the teacher, or else, if he has a son or if it's Agni Vaiśvānara, then such an exception may be allowed.

sloka: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryaṃ aviplutaḥ | sa gacchatyuttamasthānaṃ na ceha jāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: Indeed, the Brāhman who consistently observes celibacy in this manner, attains an exalted spiritual state and will not be reborn; for fear that he may not grow or be born again, such is his holy destination.

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: In that month mentioned, the following seven oblations related to cooking sacrifices are established: Aupāsana and Homa, offerings for Viśve Devāḥ, oblations made at new and full moons, tributes for a particular constellation, and tributes for Rīshabha.

sloka: yatho etaddhutaḥ prahuta āhutaśśūlagavo baliharaṇaṃ pratyavarohaṇamaṣṭakāhoma iti sapta pākayajñasaṃsthā iti ||
translation: Just as this is the extraction, invitation, and kindling of the offering, along with the eight-component sapta homa sacrifice, which is a part of the seven pāka yajña rituals.

sloka: āvasathyādhānaṃ dārakāle dāyādyakāla ekeṣām ||
translation: During the phase of raising a child, for certain individuals, this refers to setting up one's own residence or home.

sloka: kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijno matimān ṛjuḥ hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā samidhaḥpāvanāḥ pūjyāḥ carmayuktāḥ parātparāḥ yuṣmān harāmi homārthaṃ asmān rakṣata sarvadā ||
translation: Is there anyone among you who, being absorbed in meditative contemplation and versed in the procedures, possesses a clear mind and discernment, and is always diligent in performing duties? Always aware, they offer at the proper time oblations that are duly prepared. Are such virtuous individuals inclined to accept us as their offerings while we constantly seek their protection and divine regard?

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: Indeed, they are known by the names Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, Atharvana, the fourth; Itihasa-Purana, the fifth Veda. O Pitrya, Rashi-Daiva, you are the treasures. Also referred to as Vakyam Ekayanam, it is the knowledge of deities, Brahman, elements, Kshatra, Nakshatras, serpents, and Jnaana. Indeed, we two have studied it, you two also study it, all of you all should protect and recite it. (Imperative sense in the original)

sloka: vāgvāva nāmno bhūyasī vāgvā ṛgvedaṃ vijñāpayatu yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vāṅnābhaviṣyanna dharmo nādharmo vyajñāpayiṣyanna satyaṃ nānṛtaṃ na sādhu nāsādhu na hṛdayajño nāhṛdayajño vāgevaitatsarvaṃ vijñāpayati vācamupāssveti
translation: Let speech, indeed, proclaim names repeatedly and make known the four Vedas – Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvana (Atharvanaveda) as the fifth; it will reveal what is not dharma but adharma; it will manifest what is neither truth nor falsehood, neither good nor bad, neither one learned in the heart nor one unlearned. Simply through speech, all of this will be revealed. One should meditate on speech.
