sloka: saṃkalpo vāva manaso bhūyānyadā vai saṃkalpatate'tha manasyatyatha vācamīrayati tāmu nāmnīrayati nāmni mantrā ekaṃ bhavanti mantreṣu karmāṇi
translation: A solemn vow, indeed, arises from your conscience at times and is given a name. Similarly, a name is assigned to it in the mind. Multiple obligations become one in the mantra. This is how names are made pre-eminent in mantras.

sloka: tāni ha vā etāni saṃkalpaikāyanāni saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni samklṛpatāṃ dyāvāpṛthivī samakalpetāṃ vāyuścā''kāśaṃ ca samakalpantā''paśca tejaśca teṣā~ samklṛptyai saṃkalpamupāssveti
translation: Indeed, these very thoughts, anchored in a single resolve, are what establish pairs like heaven-earth, air and space. Moreover, they too establish ether. And vice versa, there is a reciprocal relationship - these entities established through resolution also strengthen the resolute determination. Hence, one should persistently contemplate on this resolution.

sloka: cittaṃ vāva saṃkalpādbhūyo yadā vai cetayate'tha saṃkalpayate'tha manasyatyatha vācasīrayati tāsu nāmnīrayati nāmni mantrā ekaṃ bhavanti mantreṣu karmaṇi
translation: When you determine your thinking with regard to that which is to be resolved, then it becomes firmly set. At that time, as you ponder it and direct your thoughts toward it, a single conception arising from the object of meditation occurs in the mind. Similarly, when you assign a distinct designation to those (objects of meditation), one and the same thought becomes manifest in the mantras during the execution of rituals.

sloka: prāṇo hyovaitāni sarvāṇi bhavati sa vā eṣa evaṃ paśyannevaṃ manvāna evaṃ vijānannativādī bhavati
translation: The life-force truly becomes all these—the very embodiment of seeking and going after them—when beholding and deeply contemplating them in such a manner; indeed becoming a modest advocate or adherent of the realized truth.

sloka: aparābādhamakleśaṃ prayatnenārjītaṃ dhanam | svalpaṃ vā vipulaṃ vāpi deyamityabhidīyate ||
translation: Wealth, gained through persistent effort, unmarred by harm or trouble, is referred to as meager or abundant, whether for giving or keeping.

sloka: sāmānyaṃ putradārādhisarvasvanyāsayācitam | pratiśrutaṃ tathānyasya na deyaṃ tvaṣṭadhā smṛtam || ||kuṭumbabhaktavasanāddeyaṃ yadatiricyate | madhvāsvādo viṣaṃ paścāddāturdhamo'nyathā bhavet || ||
translation: The joint wealth of son and wife, established as a permanent endowment, is not to be given away, as has been remembered. Yet, what transcends this, arising from devotion to the family, is to be given. Enjoying honey and curd is beneficial; poison becomes harmful only later.

sloka: bhūdīpāṃś cānnavastrāmbhas tilasarpiḥpratiśrayān | naiveśikaṃ svarṇadhuryaṃ dattvā svarge mahīyate || yāsmṛ || gṛhadhānyābhayopānac chatramālyānulepanam | yānaṃ vṛkṣaṃ priyaṃ śayyāṃ dattvātyantaṃ sukhī bhavet || yāsmṛ ||
translation: By acquiring and bestowing even a portion of lauded wealth, such as luminous items, clothing made from cinnamon leaves, or support from the earth and water, if one gives gold, they will be exalted in Indra's heaven. Similarly, by offering a house, grains, fearlessness, an umbrella, a wreath, anointing the body, a journey, a tree, kind assistance, a place to rest, and ultimate comfort, one will achieve supreme happiness.

sloka: trīṇyāhuratidānāni gāvaḥ pṛthvī sarasvatī | atidānaṃ hi dānānāṃ vidhdānaṃ tato'dhikam||
translation: They declare the "three" offerings as surpassing in munificence: the cows, great cardamoms, and the male deity Sarasvatī. Indeed, the most excellent giving is that which exceeds all others.

sloka: annaṃ dadhi madhu trāṇaṃ gobhūrukmāśvahastinaḥ | dānānyuttamadānāni uttamadravyadānataḥ || vidyādānādanāvāsaparibhogauṣadhāni ca | dānāni madhyamānīha madhyadravyadānataḥ || paribhoga iti paribhogasādhanaṃ khaṭvāsanādi | upānatpreṅkhayānāni chatrapātrāsanāni ca | dīpakāṣṭhaphalādīni caramaṃ bahuvārṣikam || bahutvādarthajātānāṃ saṃkhyā śeṣeṣu neṣyate |adhamānyavaśiṣṭāni sarvvadānānyatī viduḥ ||
translation:
You should offer (food, curd, honey, shelter) associated with cattle, gold, and protection. Additionally, give the greatest gifts, such as excellent possessions. Understand that education and medicinal herbs comprise the middle-class gifts. Also, bestow means of enjoyment such as vehicles, seating, umbrellas, and fans. Lights, wood, fruits, and similar items should be regularly donated.

Among numbered objects, only the remaining quantity is counted at the end. The inferior gifts are always left over.

sloka: sarvadānairgurutaraṃ sarvagānairviśiṣyate | pānīyaṃ naraśārdūla tasmād dātavyameva hi||
translation: Indeed, it is the most valuable fortune that truly stands out when given through all kinds of generosities. Therefore, O eminent man, it must be cherished and protected.

sloka: tasmāt tvaṃ sarvadānāni hitvānnaṃ samprayacchaha na hīdṛśaṃ puṇyaphalaṃ vicitramiha vidyate| annameva viśiṣṭaṃ hi tasmātparataraṃ na ca||
translation: Therefore, you should always abandon (hitvā) material enjoyments (annam) and dedicate (samprayaccha) all your actions (sarvadānāni) to him, for such a rare and meritorious reward (puṇyaphalaṃ vicitram) is not known to exist (vidyate) here. Indeed, nothing is more distinguished (viśiṣṭam) or superior (parataram) than this.

sloka: atidānāni sarvāṇi pṛthavīdānamucyate | acalā hyakṣayā bhūmirdogdhrī kāmānihottamān ||
translation: The act of giving excessively is known as "prthividanam" in all respects. Indeed, the indestructible earth and the desire for rewards that poets have are most exalted.

sloka: yadaṅaga dāśuṣe tvamagne bhadraṃ kariṣyasi | tavet satyamaṅgiraḥ|| so aṅagirobhiraṅagirastamo bhūda vṛṣā vṛṣabhiḥ sakhibhiḥ sakhā san ṛgmibhirṛgmī gātubhirjyeṣṭho marutvāna no bhavatvindra ūtī
translation: On the occasion when you, Agni, shall ensure dāśuṣe's wellbeing in the future, may the true Aṅgiras emerge as the foremost among friends and cattle-lords, acclaimed by ṛgmī and gātubhiḥ. May he, assuming the role of Indra, bestow kindness upon us.

sloka: ta~hāṅgirā udgīthamupāsāṃcakra etamu evā''ṅgirasaṃ manyante'ṅgānāṃ yadrasaḥ
translation: They deem this udgitha, presented to Angiras, as the foremost amongst hymns – such is the conviction of the Angirasa clan.

sloka: yenā naḥ pūrve pitaraḥ padajñāḥ svarvido abhi gā adrimuṣṇan
translation: By what means were our two ancestral fathers, those intelligent discoverers, able to ascend that stony height in the sky?

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: The insightful Brāhmaṇas, knowing full well the terms "tvā Ari" as richly endowed with pious devotion, brought about by a Ṛishi in the third Manv-antara and concealed, do not vocalize their deeper meaning. Humans, however, persist in speaking only the straightforward senses of such words.

sloka: sūtrārtho varṇyate yatra padai: sutrānusāribhiḥ| svapadāni ca varṇyante bhāṣyaṃ bhāṣyavido vidu: ||
translation: In that context where (yatra) the import (arthaḥ) of the sūtras is depicted (varṇyate) through the words (padaiḥ) along with their own explanations (sutrānusāribhiḥ), the commentator (bhāṣyavidaḥ) who understands (viduḥ) such a bhāṣya indeed comprehends both the sūtra and its meaning.

sloka: pratijñāhetūdāharaṇopanayanigamanāni avayavāḥ||||{avayavauddeśasūtram}
translation: The constituents of a pledge include the proposition, cause, method, and result. (This is the axiom regarding the definition of the components of a sentence.)

sloka: vyākhyā api tantrasya guṇaḥ| tābhirapi tantramalaṅikrayate | tāśca pañcadaśa prakārā |
translation: Indeed, explanation is also a merit of the doctrine; it gets adorned with those same fifteen characteristics.

sloka: tatra pradhānakalpanā dvidhā pradhānasya kalpanā pradhānena vā kalpanā pradhānakalpanā |
translation: There, the primary notion is twofold - it can be viewed as the conception of the most important part or as the conception through the most important part.

sloka: saptadaśa tācchīlyādīnītyuktam |
translation: The seventeen primary elements, including the third part of the seven-partite Sāman, along with others, are named.

sloka: buddhimānātmanaḥkāryagurulāghavaṃkarmaphalamanubandhaṃdeśakālaucaviditvāyuktidarśanādbhiṣagbubhūṣuḥśāstramevāditaḥparīkṣeta
translation: The healer wishing to become powerful should skillfully investigate, as a learned man, the ruler of proper time and place for actions, the lightness of intellect in one's own duties, and the teachings from scriptures, including the connection between each action and its result, in a successive manner.

sloka: indro dadhīco asthabhirvṛtrāṇyapratiṣkutaḥ jaghāna navatīrnava
translation: Indra and Dadhichi, remaining unshaken, together slew nine times hundred enemy forces.

sloka: tad vāṃ narā sanaye daṃsa ugramāviṣkarṇomi tanyaturna vṛṣṭim dadhyaṅa ha yanmadhvātharvaṇo vāmaśvasya śīrṣṇā pra yadīmuvāca
translation: I, in association with those two individuals, indeed render that very fortune (of performing a surprise/wonderful deed) potent in this current era. Who else could generate rain like the Atharva hymns of dual form, if not for the one named Vamadeva, who uttered it with the beginning of his breath? (In this context, "na" can be interpreted as an expletive and omitted from the translation.)

sloka: maghavān yāta bhadraṃ vo dadhyāñcamṛṣisattamam vidyāvratatapaḥsāraṃ gātraṃ yācata mā ciram
translation: Maghavan, you have safely arrived. Seek now the most respectable and purest form, obtained through religious austerity, knowledge, and vows, as the seventh degree of Brahmans (ṛṣi) recommends. Don't delay offering or tendering this to the deserving one after a long wait!

sloka: anannadānasya phalaṃ tvayedamupabhujyate | tarhyannadānato nānyaccharīrārogyakārakam || nānyadannādṛte puṃsāṃ kiñcitsañjīvanauṣadham | mahīṃ gatvā mahārāja kuruṣva vacanaṃ mama ||
translation: The failure to provide sustenance brings about enjoyment for you. Thus, O king, after making a food donation, nothing more is required to maintain bodily health, for there is no medicinal herb that can preserve life for one who has not given. Go, convey my message to the earth as Vishnu would treat Kaikeyī.

sloka: prabhāte kālyamutthāya sarastadupacakrame | athāpaśyaṃ śavaṃ tatra supuṣṭamajaraṃ kvacit || ||
translation: After waking up at dawn and performing his ablutions, he saw there an auspiciously denoted, extremely well-nourished and ageless corpse on some occasion with his spiritual vision.

sloka: paśyato me tadā rāma vimānādavaruhya ca | taṃ śavaṃ bhakṣayāmāsa sa svargī raghunandana || || tathā bhuktvā yathākāmaṃ māṃsaṃ bahu supīvaram | avatīrya saraḥ svargī saṃspraṣṭumupacakrame || ||
translation: As Lord Rama, observe there the one, conspicuous with descent from my aerial chariot, consuming that corpse. He is the celestial occupant of heaven, named Raghunandana. After eating to his heart's content, numerous splendid morsels, he descended, readying himself to address the sacred waters.

sloka: tasya me svargabhūtasya kṣutpipāse dvijottama | bādhete paramodāra tato 'haṃ vyathitendriyaḥ ||| ||
translation: For the one born from heaven, the finest among the twice-born, O Uttama, even a minimal feeling of hunger and thirst is unbearable for me. Hence, I am left restless and distressed due to this affliction.

sloka: gatvā tribhuvanaśreṣṭhaṃ pitāmahamuvāca ha | bhagavanbrahmaloko 'yaṃ kṣutpipāsāvivarjitaḥ ||| ||
translation: After having traveled to the most excellent of the three worlds, his father, a Brāhman named Tri-bhuvana, addressed him with certainty: "O Bhagavan Brahmaloka, you are free from hunger and thirst."

sloka: pitāmahastu māmāha tavāhāraḥ sudevaja | svādūni svāni māṃsāni tāni bhakṣaya nityaśaḥ || ||
translation: Indeed, grandparent, you have previously spoken to me about my share and that of the celestial being Sudeva. I beg you, let me eternally consume those very own, second astrological mansion's, sweet-flavored flesh portions.

sloka: svaśarīraṃ tvayā puṣṭaṃ kurvatā tapa uttamam | anuptaṃ rohate śveta na kadācinmahāmate || || dattaṃ na te 'sti sūkṣmo 'pi tapa eva niṣevase | tena svargagato vatsa bādhyase kṣutpipāsayā || ||
translation: By nourishing your own bodily strength through the greatest religious austerity, you make it flourish. May unbroken spiritual growth arise for you. When will there ever be, for you, even the subtlest concession or indulgence? You are solely engaged in practicing that very austerity. Therefore, my dear son of Soma-sharman, due to this, you attain heaven and are bound by the constraints of hunger and thirst.

sloka: pūrvameva mayā sṛṣṭo jāmbavānṛkṣapuṅgava:| jṛmbhamāṇasya sahasā mama vaktrādajāyata||
translation: Previously, I had merely brought forth as a creation Jambavan, the chief of bears named Riksha, who unexpectedly emerged from my face as I was opening it.

sloka: bhadraśca bhadraguptaśca bhadravindrastathaiva ca| saptabāhuśca vikhyātaḥ kanyā bhadrāvatī tathā| sambodhanī ca vikhyātā jñeyā jāmbavatīsutāḥ || ||
translation: Bhadra, the spouse of Meru's daughter and likewise Bhadragupta, the Śākya princess, are celebrated. Bhadravinda, the seven-armed one, and Kanyavati are also renowned. The one known as Sambodhani will be recognized as Jambavati's offspring.

sloka: jāmbavān ṛkṣarājastu bherīśabdairmanojavaḥ | vijayaṃ dikṣu sarvāsu mahotsavamaghoṣayat || ||
translation: Jambavan, the sovereign bear, with his resounding Om-like roars, heralded Krishna's triumph at every noble celebration.

sloka: mayā mahābaleścaiva yajñe viṣṇussanātanaḥ| pradakṣiṇīkṛtaḥ pūrvaṃ kramamāṇastrivikramam||||
translation: Through my and Lord Vishnu's ancient tradition, the rites have been cirumambulated; Trivikrama (Vishnu's three-step form) is currently conducting their execution as per the Krama arrangement.

sloka: sa idānīmahaṃ vṛddhaḥ plavane mandavikramaḥ| yauvane ca tadā'sīnme balamapratimaṃ paraiḥ||||
translation: I have now become advanced in age, possessing tolerant forbearance, but in my youth, I had an incomparable strength, which was recognized by the ancients.

sloka: nīla magnisutaṃ caiva hanumantaṃ ca vānaram| pitāmahasutaṃ caiva jāmbavantaṃ mahābalam||||
translation: "Blue-hued son of Bhuvana-rāja and that particular Vanara named Hanuman, as well as Jāmbavanta, the mighty one who is like a white Bala or elder brother of Vāsudeva - indeed, you are all descendants of powerful ancestors."

sloka: ṛkṣavantaṃ girivaraṃ vindhyaṃ ca girimuttam| anveṣayan pariśrāntaḥ sa dadarśa mahāmanāḥ|| ||
translation: While seeking the foremost mountain, fatigued from looking around, a greatly esteemed individual spotted the outstanding Vindhya range, adorned with a distinctive ridgeline. (Alternate translation: A noble-minded person, wearied from searching, saw during his exploration the excellent mountain Vindhya, which stands out and is graced with a distinct crest.)

sloka: vedānto nāmopaniṣatpramāṇaṃ tadanusārīṇi| śārīrakasūtrāṇi ca |
translation: The named Upanishads, constituting the conclusive part of the Vedas, serve as authoritative evidence. Similarly, one should adhere to the teachings imparted in the Śārīraka Sūtras and other related Śruti works.

sloka: avidyādeḥ saṃsārabījasya viśaraṇād vināśanādityanena arthayogena vidyā upaniṣaducyate |
translation: The Upanishad speaks of knowledge as the means to exit the source of worldly illusion's seed, rooted in ignorance, through the destruction of the refuge provided by avidyā and the goddess Diti, and the yoking of right meaning and understanding, as customary.

sloka: paraṃ brahma vā gamayatoti brahma gamayitṛtvena yogād vidyopaniṣad |
translation: Guiding to the supreme Brahman through the power of knowledge derived from yoga and the Upanishads, indeed.

sloka: garbhavāsajanmajarādyupadravavṛndasya lokāntarepaunapunyena pravṛttasya avasādapitṛtvena upaniṣadityucyate |
translation: In the Upaniṣad scripture, it is stated that the accumulation of hardships from conception, birth, aging, and other causes, impacting someone in another world, is referred to as "avasādapitṛtva." This term denotes a paternal connection (pitṛtva) with badness (avasāda), brought about by past misdeeds (pravṛttasya, previously committed actions) and supervenient diseases (upadrava) in one's existence (janma) and abode (vāsa). This concept is related to the bed (Śayyā) mentioned as ādi.

sloka: mokṣalakṣaṇamityetatparaṃ rahasyam ityevaṃ | saiṣā śāṃbhavī vidyā kādividyeti vā hādividyeti vā sādividyeti vā rahasyam |
translation: This, the mark of moksha, is indeed the supreme mystery. You all have accurately understood this. The Shambhavi knowledge, beginning with "kā" or "ha" or "sādi," is also referred to as a secret. It is being taught (tense unclear without additional context).

sloka: īśakenakaṭhapraśnamuṇḍamāṇḍūkyatittiraḥ | aitareyaṃ ca chāndogyaṃ bṛhadāraṇyakaṃ tathā ||
translation: Indeed, the Upanishads such as Isha, Katha, and Tittiri, as well as the Aitareya, Chandogya, and Brihadaranyaka, which are composed in the Yajurveda, are also included.

sloka: ekamevādvitīyam| sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma |
translation: Indeed, what is truly unique and without a second is this very Brahman; verily, all of this (universe) is nothing but that One Self-existent Spirit.

sloka: sarve vedā yatpadamāmananti tapā~si sarvāṇi ca yadvadanti | yadicchanto brahmacaryaṃ caranti tatte pada~ saṃgraheṇa bravīmyomityetat || ||
translation: I will declare that focal point, which all the Vedas, with a single accord, designate as the goal and describe variably; and the state of brahmacharya, which one resorts to when so desired, in summary.

sloka: etadvai satyakāma paraṃ cāparaṃ ca brahma yadoṅkāraḥ |
translation: Indeed, in this manner, it is declared in the Brāhmaṇas that Satyakāma has realized the ultimate reality – the sacred syllable 'Om'. It is both superior and without rival, as well as the inferior Brahman.

sloka: yo divi tiṣṭhandivo'ntaro yaṃ dyaurna veda yasya dyauḥ śarīraṃ yo divamantaro yamayaty eṣa ta ātmā'ntaryāmyamṛtaḥ || ||
translation: The one who stands in the divine realm, having knowledge of the supreme being for whom the heavens serve as a physical form, governing both what is in heaven and what is between heaven and earth – this immortal self within also controls the inner controller.

sloka: sa ya eṣo'ṇimaitadātmyamida~ sarvaṃ tatsatya~ sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who recognizes this identity of the individual soul and the supreme soul as one and the same - truly, he is the essence, O Shvetaketu.

sloka: sarvaṃ hyetad brahmāyamātmā brahma so'yamātmā catuṣpāt || ||
translation: "Indeed, all of this, referring to the esoteric knowledge being discussed, is Brahman, and this Self, referring to the individual soul, also has the nature of Brahman. This very one, referring to the supreme being, is the four-footed (catuṣpāt) Brahman."

sloka: hṛdayaṃ nirabhidyata hṛdayānmano manasaścandramā |
translation: The heart was fully illuminated, originating from the heart, the mind was revealed, and the moon, too, from the mind.

sloka: tadaikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tattejo'sṛjata | tatteja aikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tadapo'sṛjata |
translation: At that time, they contemplated with foresight, "May there be a great increase in progeny," and from that (contemplation), radiant energy was produced. Then, the radiant energy contemplated, "May there be a considerable growth in offspring," and from it, water burst forth.

sloka: kṣaraṃ pradhānamamṛtākṣaraṃ haraḥ kṣarātmānāvīśate deva ekaḥ | tasyābhidhyānādyojanāttattvabhāvādbhūyaścānte viśvamāyānivṛttiḥ || ||
translation: The preeminent deity, Shiva, pervades both the melting away (perishable) and the imperishable as their very essence. This arises from meditation on him: the emergence of authentic being and, at the end, the abatement of the world's delusion, which is abundantly furnished with one of Vishnu's nine energies.

sloka: chandāṃsi yajñāḥ kratavo vratāni bhūtaṃ bhavyaṃ yacca vedā vadanti | asmānmāyī sṛjate viśvametattasmiṃścānyo māyayā sanniruddhaḥ || ||
translation: The sacred hymns, acts of worship, sacrificial rites, and vows of learning that the Vedas speak of - both what has been and will be; from me emerges this illusionary universe. Here, another entity is ensnared by my illusion and held in bondage.

sloka: māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyānmāyinaṃ ca maheśvaram | tasyāvayavabhūtaistu vyāptaṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat || ||
translation: "Indeed, consider mayā, the personified will in creation and knowledge, as well as maheśvara, the controller; all of this world is pervaded by its constituent parts. That is to say, everything, both animate and inanimate, is possessed by or under the influence of it."

sloka: idaṃ vai tanmadhu dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇo'śvibhyāmuvāca | tadetadṛṣiḥ paśyannavocat | rūparūpaṃ pratirūpo babhūva tadasya rūpaṃ praticakṣaṇāya | indro māyābhiḥ pururūpa īyate yuktā hyasya harayaḥ śatā daśetiy ayaṃ vai harayo 'yaṃ vai daśa ca sahasraṇi bahūni cānantāni ca | tadetadbrahmāpūrvamanaparamanantaramabāhyam ayamātmā brahma sarvānubhūrityanuśāsanam || ||
translation: The sage named Dadhyanga, also known as Atharvan, previously addressed this matter when queried by the Ashvins. Upon seeing such knowledge, he spoke of its similar form for easier comprehension. Indra manifests himself in various forms through his illusions; indeed, these are the very hundreds, tens, and thousands, countless Maruts. This is the original, supreme, infinite Brahman that exists both within and beyond, this is the individual self (Atma), the ultimate teaching.

sloka: yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhṇate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhayaḥ saṃbhavanti | yathā sataḥ puruṣāt keśalomāni tathā'kṣarāt saṃbhavatīha viśvam || ||
translation: Just as from the navel of the cosmic being, one creates and becomes familiar with the pair of wheels, similarly, just as from a man, his body hair and nails arise; in this way, from the indelible mark, everything manifest in the material world originates.

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and verbal testimony, being manifested, encountered, and proved respectively, are the three established forms of right knowledge that lead to the indisputable conclusion of establishing a knowable object, owing to their being manifested through all means of evidence in a consecutive manner.

sloka: tasmācca viparyāsāt siddhaṃ sākṣitvamasya puruṣasya | kaivalyaṃ mādhyasthyaṃ draṣṭṛtvamakartṛbhāvaśca || ||
translation: Hence, due to the reversal (viparyāsāt) of the usual, the realization (siddham) of the witness-consciousness (sākṣitvam) of the individual soul (puruṣasya) occurs; likewise, liberation (kaivalyam), neutrality (mādhyasthyam), observing (draṣṭṛtvam), and non-agentive nature (akartṛbhāvaḥ) arise.

sloka: saṃghātaparārthatvāt triguṇādiviparyādadhiṣṭhānāt | puruṣo'sti bhoktṛbhāvāt kaivalyārthaṃ pravṛtteśca || ||
translation: The being known as Purusha, serving as the locus of the three gunas and their transformations, exists as one who enjoys and experiences; this is placed for the attainment of Kaivalya or eternal happiness and liberation.

sloka: adhyavasāyo buddhirdharmo jñānaṃ virāga aiśvaryam | sāttvikametadrūpaṃ tāmasamasmādviparyastam || ||
translation: Discriminative understanding, righteousness, knowledge, dispassion, and supreme power are manifestations of the pure Sattva guna, while their opposites indicate Tamas' influence.

sloka: abhimāno'haṃkāra: tasmādvividha: pravartate sarga: | ekādaśakaśca gaṇastanmātrapañcakaścaiva || ||
translation: Egoism and self-assertion, manifesting as a high opinion of oneself and determination, are the two origins from which emerge not only creation but also groups of eleven elements and pentad entities that are merely quantitative in nature.

sloka: ubhayātmakamatra mana: saṅkalpamindriyaṃ ca sādharmyāt | guṇapariṇāmaviśeṣānnānātvaṃ bāhyabhedāśca || ||
translation: The mind, together with its conception and the five senses, is of a twofold nature – due to community in the transformation of guṇas and differences in exterior aspects – owing to their similarity and distinctness respectively.

sloka: hetumadanityamavyāpi sakriyamanekamāśritaṃ liṃṅgam | sāvayavaṃ paratantraṃ vyaktaṃ viparītamavyaktam || ||triguṇamaviveki viṣaya: sāmānyamacetanaṃ prasavadharmi | vyaktaṃ tathā pradhānaṃ tadviparītastathā ca pumān || ||
translation: Endowed with causes, transient, associated with the wind-female principle, active, singularly expressed, supported by a sign, composed of parts, dependent and manifest; its opposite as a second-person imperative; one who does not discriminate the three qualities - the common, unconscious, and generative cause - and also what is contrary to it: this is the manifest pradhana (unevolved matter or nature) and the man.

sloka: vatsavivṛddhinimittaṃ kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttirajñasya | puruṣavimokṣanimittaṃ tathā pravṛtti: pradhānasya || ||
translation: The emergence of a dish prepared with milk is due to the maturing of cows, similarly the motive for the liberation of Purusha (name of the Brāhmans of Krauñca-dvīpa) is triggered just like that of Pradhāna (name of a Śakti).

sloka: tasmānna badhyate'ddhā na mucyate nāpi saṃsarati kañcit | saṃsarati badhyate mucyate ca nānāśrayā prakṛti: || ||
translation: Hence, it remains unbound not manifestly, nor does it yield enjoyment or seek final liberation; even so, it is bound and freed according to its diverse inherent natures.

sloka: raṅgastha ityupekṣaka eko dṛṣṭāhamityuparamatyanyā | sati saṃyoge'pi tayo: prayojanaṃ nāsti sargasya || ||
translation: Manifested as an indifferent sole observer named 'raṅgastha,' I remain uninvolved. Even when those two form an alliance, they serve no purpose for me, the ever-observant one. No role or function for creation do they possess in my view.

sloka: tadabhāvavati tatprakārako'nubhavo'yathārthaḥ| yathā śuktāvidaṃ rajatamiti| saiva apramā ityucyate||
translation: The apprehension of that very fortune is accurate when it is present; for instance, knowing a pearl-oyster to contain a pearl. However, the same fortune, when absent, is deemed inaccurate or unreal, similar to perceiving silver in a shell. This misperception is precisely what is referred to as "apramā."

sloka: anyacchreyo'nyadutaiva preyaste ubhe nānārthe puruṣa~ sinītaḥ | tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya sādhu bhavati hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte || ||
translation: When someone prefers one (puruṣa~) over the other (anyat) for a specific purpose (preyasti), they make a choice between two alternatives (ubhe nānārthe). By bestowing favor on the superior option (tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya), they act virtuously (sādhu bhavati); by choosing the lesser one, they forfeit merit and the desired object (hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte).

sloka: brahmacaryyācaraṇasya yaḥ śāstrabodhito'vadhiḥ | tāvadvedamupāsyāsamāptaveda evāśramāntaraṃ gato yaḥ sa vratasnātakaḥ |samāpya vratamasamāpya vedaṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vratasnātakaḥ
translation: The individual dedicated to the practice of brahmacarya, recognized through scriptural knowledge, who has attained the state of a Brāhman for the time being; he who, having undertaken and obtained the knowledge, returns having completed his vow, equivalent to one who has finished the Veda and bathed, without equal in this pursuit.

sloka: vedamadhītyagurusannidhau vedābhyāsaṃ yaḥ karoti sa vidyāsnātakaḥ |samāpya vedamasamāpya vrataṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāsnātakaḥ
translation: The individual who studies the Veda in the guru's presence and gets initiated into knowledge, as well as the one who accomplishes the vow of learning and returns after completing it, are called knowers of philosophy or knowledge.

sloka: pālitasamyagvrataḥ prāptavedo yo dvitīyāśramaṃ gataḥ sa ubhayasnātakaḥ |ubhayaṃ samāpya yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāvratasnātaka iti
translation: The one who, being nurtured in his duties, has acquired forward knowledge of the Vedas, belongs to the second order of life after undergoing the initiation rite, and having completed both stages - he is known as an upanayana-snataka.

sloka: tadya itthaṃ viduḥ | ye ceme'raṇye śraddhā tapa ityupāsate te'rciṣamabhisambhavantyarciṣo'harahna āpūryamāṇapakṣamāpūryamāṇapakṣādyānṣaḍudaṅṅeti māsā~stān || ||
translation: Those who in the everlasting forest revere faith and austerity as their worship, they are capable of filling up what has been diminished and empty themselves when becoming replete; such is the characteristic of the six seasons through the months.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: They declare this to be the divinely appointed vehicle, born of the merging of Agni and the sun during daytime, pure and superior, sovereign, all-pervading, and subtler than the subtle. It is the conscious self in the state of turya (transcendental consciousness), the object of meditation for those seeking self-realization. Identified with the inner offering, it brings about pacification and stillness within one's own self. The self-established one does not regress from this path.

sloka: atha ya ime grāma iṣṭāpūrte dattamityupāsate te dhūmamabhisambhavanti dhūmādrātri~ rātreraparapakṣamaparapakṣādyānṣaḍdakṣiṇaiti māsā~stānnaite saṃvatsaramabhiprāpnuvanti || ||
translation: Once people who revere the village's benefactor, named Iṣṭāpurta, as divine beings begin to worship him, they acquire the smoke (of fame) arising during both day and night, spanning across the subsequent six-month period and the ensuing year.

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: The subtle transformations of substances, the subtle spirit, and smoke, night and waning moon, the southern course (of the sun), Soma, New Moon plants, blooming herbs, sustenance, and seminal flow - all these, O Lord of the earth, are repeatedly reborn in succession, each assuming its own new form in this existence.

sloka: athaitayoḥ pathorna katareṇa ca na tānīmāni kṣudrāṇyasakṛdāvartīni bhūtāni bhavanti jāyasva mriyasvetyetattṛtīya~sthānaṃ tenāsau loko na sampūryate tasmājjugupseta tadeṣa ślokaḥ || ||
translation: "So, which of the two paths does not, through either of them, allow for the proliferation of these insignificant beings who keep revolving as 'be born and die' in every cycle? Therefore, one should detest this verse."

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: In ascertaining that interior perception, he speaks and illuminates through judicial inquiry and thorough investigation.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation: The two pathways in the white of the eye (day) and darkness (night) are perpetual in this world. Through the same one, there is progression to a fixed destination, while by another, repeated regression occurs, influenced by some force.

sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: Agni, invite the gods to this spot and bestow your favor on the three origins. Adorn yourself and partake of the elixir of life.

sloka: ā vakṣi devā~ iha vipra yakṣi cośan hotarni ṣadā yoniṣu triṣu ||
translation: You, seer, who are the protector gods – consistently in these three realms, as providers of nourishment and sustenance, point out to me!

sloka: yajñasya ketuṃ prathamaṃ purohitamagniṃ narastriṣadhasthe samīdhire ||
translation: The premier sign of the sacrifice is the one who has been made the initial igniter of the sacrificial fire, the officiant.

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: Indeed, the southern direction is recognized as primary. This is the father of the fires – the son known as Dakshinaagni (the south fire), Gharapatya, and Aahavaniiya. Therefore, he should indeed be honored with due reverence.

sloka: gārhapatyena santya ṛtunā yajñanīrasi | devān devayate yaja ||
translation: Using the household fire, conducting the ritual at the appropriate time, you ought to invite and bring satisfaction to the goddesses (wives of the gods) through the sacrificial rite.

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: Indeed, these two (referring to the worlds) are those very three (in number), and these three stages of life are likewise. Similarly, the Ṛig-veda and the other two Vedas are referred to as the triple fires.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: Having resolved to perform this task of hospitality towards the guest, he should be welcomed in advance. One should give alms to the religious mendicant in the prescribed manner and as is customary for a follower of Brahma.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: In the flourishing of knowledge and religious austerities, the domestic priest tends to the sacrificial fires, while facilitating the crossing of challenges and rescuing from significant sins as well as minor transgressions, arising not only from Durgā but also sacred knowledge.

sloka: bhikṣāṃ apyudapātraṃ vā satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | vedatattvārthaviduṣe brāhmaṇāyopapādayet | | | |
translation: Even to a mendicant, one should properly and according to rules cause to be given any boon obtained by begging, either directly or through a vessel; such giving should be made to a Brahmin who is wise, versed in the true meaning of the Vedas, and possesses sacred knowledge or doctrine.

sloka: yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī | | | |
translation: By giving away a cow in accordance with rule to the guru and partaking in the resulting meritorious fruit, a dvija also attains similar merit by respectfully offering alms.

sloka: na mṛ॒tyu: āsīt amṛta॒ṃ na tarhi॒
translation: Death had not come to be, nor immortality, during that time in the past.

sloka: ānī̭t avā॒taṃ sva॒dhayā॒ tat ekamtasmāddhānyanna paraḥ kiñcanāsa
translation: Derived through one's inherent nature, only that very entity should be sought after; there is no need for anything else or any other thing.

sloka: tapasa॒: tatmahi॒naajāya॒taekam
translation: Through dedicated meditation, we truly realize the one, unchanging reality.

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: The divinely sovereign being, formless and unaging, untouched from within or without, devoid of desires and wants, self-contained, pure and radiant, transcending the physical world, originating from a source beyond the material realm.

sloka: sahasraśīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ sahasrapāt
translation: The primeval entity, the source of the universe, is depicted with a thousand heads (representing the diversity of creation), a thousand eyes (symbolizing omniscience), and a thousand feet (signifying all-pervasiveness).

sloka: puruṣa evedaṃ sarvaṃ yadbhūtaṃ yacca bhavyam
translation: The Supreme Being, the soul of the universe, is merely everything that has been and will be in its entirety.

sloka: tasmādvirāl̤ajāyata virājo adhi pūruṣaḥsa jāto atyaricyata paścādbhūmimatho puraḥ
translation: From him then emerged the valiant Viraj, and before and behind, the Purusha expansively so, both above and below.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the bygone era, the divine ancestors of the gods took birth from this genuine existence. At the outset of the age, the gods themselves emerged from this. It was then that desires arose and extended in their direction.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: The pre-eminent truth, a wise and learned theologian speaks of in various ways.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: At first, what was not existent emerged as existence. Then, spontaneously, the Self became the very manifestation of this existence. Thus, it is called 'the created' because of this manifestation. Indeed, that manifestation is the essence itself.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: Was it once only the case of two entities? At that time, did the seers question, "What could that have been?" or had Diti and the Ṛishis existed before? You all certainly are aware (of the truth).

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation: Indeed, have not two been here before, uncovered by the god of disease, desiring to see and seek each other's essence through religious meditation? Like this, the god of disease does not touch those who engage in my worship. Thus, the waters of life arise for one who performs my worship, just as I once became manifest for your benefit.

sloka: sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam | taddhaika āhurasadevedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyaṃ tasmādasataḥ sajjāyata || || sattveva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam || ||
translation: Indeed, my dear, was there in the beginning solely one preeminent Being, uniquely existing; they declare (perfect-indicative active third-person plural) that He alone, as the unparalleled One, existed (aorist-injunctive iz-aorist active third-person singular). And from His (masculine ablative singular) presence, all these (masculine accusative plural) have come to be (passive past participle). This reference is to the Absolute Reality, signified by 'tattva' and characterized by 'sattva'.

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The book, whether in prose or verse, that reveals the supernatural method of obtaining the revered power of gaining everything and abandoning the unwelcome, and which considers it as such, is known as a treatise.

sloka: ekaviṃśatiśākhātmaka ṛk śataśākhātmaka yajuḥ sahasraśākhāmayasāma navaśākhāmayātharvva iti purāṇam api ca śrīmārkaṇḍeya uvāca |
translation: The sage Mārkaṇḍeya, after invoking the one-by-one-branched Ṛk collection, the hundred-branched Yajus text, and the thousand-branched Sāma, mentioned the ancient Atharva Veda with its nine branches.

sloka: tebhyastaptebhyastrayo vedā ajāyanta | agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurvedaḥ sūryāt sāmavedaḥ |
translation: The three Vedas took their origin through being heated by them: from Agni arose the Ṛgveda, from Vāyu the Yajurveda, and from the radiant sun the Sāmaveda.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Therefore, the sacred verses (RC), the Sāmans, and the Yajus sacrificial words; this is the dedication (initiation).

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: Would it not be the exhalation of this supreme entity - the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvangirasa, either referring to its intellectual principle or a descendant of Aṅgiras?

sloka: upa tvāgne divedive doṣāvastardhiyā vayaṃ namo bharanta emasi
translation: In your presence, we offer reverential salutations, you being consistently free from flaws, whereas we two have succumbed to imperfections.

sloka: vedaśāstrārthatattvajño yatra tatrāśrame vasan | ihaiva loke tiṣṭhansa brahmabhūyāya kalpate | | |
translation: The scholar well-versed in the true meaning of the Veda and scriptural teachings dwells in that very ashram, becoming qualified for spiritual eminence here in this world.

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The Vedanta Shastra is defined as the impersonally spoken teachings, serving to establish both dharma and Brahman, and representing the concluding portion of the Vedas.

sloka: sanātanaṃ niteyam | vedāpauruṣeyatvapakṣa eva manorabhimataḥ| pūrvakalpe ye vedāsta eva paramātmamūrterbrahmaṇaḥ sarvajñasya smṛtyārūḍhāḥ | tāneva kalpādau agnivāyuravibhya ācakarṣa|
translation: The eternal object of mental consideration is held to be the indestructible nature of the Vedas, undoubtedly pertaining to the Brāhmaṇa portion and manifesting the highest personal principle of life. In an ancient tradition, the omniscient Brahman, through reminiscence, had established fire, wind, and the sun, drawn from their respective abodes.

sloka: yathā ca śrutiḥ agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurveda ādityātsāmaveda ||
translation: Like the sacred knowledge transmitted orally by the Brāhmans that appears, for instance, in the Ṛgveda regarding Agni, in the Yajurveda concerning Vayu, and in the Sāmaveda from Āditya.

sloka: anantā vai vedāḥ |
translation: As expressed in the Brāhmaṇas, the Vedas (Atharva-veda), referring to the collection of sacred texts, are undoubtedly infinite.

sloka: pitṛdevamanuṣyāṇāṃ vedaścakṣuḥ sanātanam | aśakyaṃ cāprameyaṃ ca vedaśāstraṃ iti sthitiḥ | |
translation: The eternal knowledge of the Vedas, regarded as the divine eye of humanity, is considered an unspeakable and immeasurable body of teaching. This is the widely accepted view.

sloka: vedo'khilo dharmamūlaṃ smṛtiśīle ca tadvidām | ācāraścaiva sādhūnāṃ ātmanastuṣṭireva ca | | | |
translation: The Veda, encompassing all knowledge, is the foundation of dharma (ethical precepts), as is smrti (the whole body of sacred tradition) for those who know (the truth). Similarly, established conduct is that of the noble-minded, while contentment, the highest personal principle of life, is the supreme state of the self.

sloka: bibharti sarvabhūtāni vedaśāstraṃ sanātanam | tasmādetatparaṃ manye yajjantorasya sādhanam | | | |
translation: "The one who lets grow and protects all beings, wearing the eternal teachings of the Veda as her own, I deem this to be the ultimate means for the living being's adoration."

sloka: ārṣaṃ dharmopadeśaṃ ca vedaśāstrāvirodhinā | yastarkeṇānusaṃdhatte sa dharmaṃ veda netaraḥ | | | |
translation: The one who currently strengthens the traditional teachings of dharma through logical reasoning, in harmony with the Vedic scriptures and instrumental in guiding others, is none other than the embodiment of dharma itself. This truth remains unknown to others.

sloka: yānīhāgamaśāstrāṇi yāśca kāścitpravṛttayaḥ| tāni vedaṃ puraskṛtya pravṛttāni yathākramam||
translation: Having mastered those treatises and practices, some of which are religious and scientific, as well as their conduct, with regard to that, one should, in the presence of true knowledge, study and follow them sequentially in the appropriate manner.

sloka: parābhidhyānātu tirohitaṃ tato hyasya bandhaviparyayau
translation: Then, what is concealed beyond profound meditation is, in this context, the reversal of his bonds and loyalties.

sloka: ata eva copamā sūryakādivat
translation: Hence, compare yourself merely to such greatness as the sun embodies.

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: The six auxiliary disciplines of the Vedas are: phonetics (śikṣā), sacred ritual science (kalpa), language grammar (vyākaraṇam), word etymology (nirukta), meter studies (chandasām), and astronomical/chronological calculations (jyotiṣām), all accompanied by their respective textual traditions.

sloka: atha śikṣāṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ | varṇaḥ svaraḥ | mātrā balam | sāma santāna| ityuktaḥ śikṣādhyāyaḥ ||
translation: Now we will explain the following: the science of articulation and pronunciation (śikṣā), phonemes (varṇaḥ), names of various Sāmans (svaraḥ), the upper limb of Nāgarī characters (mātrā), the strength (balam), wealth (sāma), lineage of sāman (santānaḥ), and a lesson (adhyāyaḥ) as declared.

sloka: mantro hīnaḥ svarato varṇato vā mithyā prayukto na tamarthamāha | sa vāgvajro yajamānaṃ hinasti yathendraśatruḥ svarato'parādhāt ||
translation: If a Vedic hymn (mantraḥ) is improperly used, either due to its incorrect pronunciation (svarataḥ) or misinterpretation (varṇataḥ vā), it fails to achieve its purpose (tam artham āha). Such a person's speech (sa vāk) becomes as destructive as a thunderbolt (vajraḥ) to the one who sacrifices (yajamānaṃ hinasti). This is because, just like Prahlāda (indraśatruḥ), when acting with hostility (aparādhāt) towards it, can harm the mantra.

sloka: tattvaṣṭāhavanīyamupa prāvartayatsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti yadavartayattadvṛtrasya vṛtratvaṃ yadabravītsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti tasmādasyendraḥ śatrurabhavat
translation: You (plural) had instituted the ritualistic observance of Tattvastha-avanīyam, which had been duly established by the rite "svāhā." When you (singular) were causing Vardhasva, identified as the enemy of Indra, to engage in his vṛtra-tva (hostile actions) towards Vrtrasya (Indra), he declared, "Vardhasva is my enemy." Therefore, Indra became his adversary.

sloka: vyākriyante śabdāḥ anena iti vyākaraṇam | vyākriyante vyutpādyante sādhuśabdā asmin aneneti vā iti durgādāsaḥ
translation: Words, including the sacred syllable Om and names of various personages, are analyzed by this; hence, this is called vyākaraṇa. Additionally, good or virtuous words are generated in this context through this. Furthermore, Durgādāsa, possibly referring to the author or an adverbial compound, aligns with this perspective as well.

sloka: indraścandraḥ kāśakṛtsnāpiśalī śākaṭāyanaḥ | pāṇinyamarajainendrāḥ jayantyaṣṭau ca śābdikāḥ ||
translation: Indra and Chandra, along with Kaashakritsnapishalii, Shaakatayana, Paṇini, Amarajaina, and additionally eight others known as Śābdikas, are widely renowned.

sloka: arthāvabodhe nirapekṣatayā padajātaṃ yatroktaṃ tanniruktam |
translation: In the investigation of word meaning, 'artha' (as son of Dharma and Buddhi) has been explained without partiality in the spoken form of 'pada-jātam' (name of a son of Brahmā). Similarly, the etymology, referred to as 'niruktam', is also stated there.

sloka: samāmnāyaḥ samāmnātaḥ sa vyākhyātavyaḥ | idamantareṇa mantreṣvarthapratyayo na vidyate iti |
translation: This explanation, previously designated and highly praised, is to be clarified. Specifically, in this context, there is no recognition of a fundamental notion or idea as the meaning of the term "artha" in the hymns or sacrificial formulas.

sloka: udāharaṇasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ|| {hetulakṣaṇam} tathā vaidharmyāt|| {hetulakṣaṇam}
translation: The means of demonstrating or mastering something is caused by its similarity to a given instance, as well as by its distinction from it.

sloka: udāharaṇena sāmānyātsādhyasya dharmasya sādhanaṃ prajñāpanaṃ hetuḥ | sādhye pratisaṃdhāya dharmamudāharaṇe ca pratisaṃdhāya tasya sādhanatāvacanaṃ hetuḥ utpattidharmakatvāditi | utpattidharmakamanityaṃ dṛṣṭamiti | udāharaṇavaidharmyācca sādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ | katham anityaḥ śabdaḥ utpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ yathā ātmādidravyaniti ||
translation: The exposition of the means to achieve the general duty: Inquiring into it reveals the cause; in establishing both the means and the general duty regarding the object, stating its being the means is the causative factor due to its nature as an attribute. This has been observed to be the case with attributes and their respective means. The question arises, how can the transient 'anitya' (attribute) serve as the means for the eternal 'śabda' (word), just as it does for ātma and other objects?

sloka: sādhyasādharmyāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta udāharaṇam || {udāharaṇalakṣaṇam} tadviparyayādvā viparītam||{udāharaṇalakṣaṇam}
translation: The instance exemplifying what becomes characterized by difference from the inherent nature of the objective (sādhya) is referred to as a dṛṣṭānte. Its opposite is described as its reverse. Here, tat dharma bhāvī, 'becoming characterized by this and that peculiar condition or essential quality', is contrasted with asadharmyāt, 'from unlawful difference'.

sloka: sādhyena sādharmyaṃ samānadharmatā sādhyasādharmyātkāraṇāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta iti | tasya dharmastaddharmaḥ | tasya sādhyasya | sādhyaṃ ca dvividhaṃ dharmiviśiṣṭo vā dharmaḥ śabdasyānityatvaṃ dharmaviśiṣṭo vā dharmī anityaḥ śabda iti| ihettaraṃ tadgrahaṇena gṛhyate|
translation: The quality of being akin to the goal (sādhyena) is comprehended through the instrument of a similar quality (sādharmyam) due to the existence of such a quality (dharma) in it (tat), leading to the manifestation of the accomplishment (sādhyasādhamyātkāraṇāt). This is because of the reason that there is a distinction between the eternal nature of the term "property" (dharmaviśiṣṭaḥ śabdaḥ) and the transient nature of the property characterized by it (dharmaviśiṣṭaḥ dharmaḥ anityaḥ). This distinction is grasped through this very means (tadgrahaṇena). The property of that which is to be accomplished (sādhyasya) is twofold: a property characterized by the word "property" (dharmī), and a transient property (anityatvam). This illustrates that the term "property" has different meanings in different contexts, just like how the term 'light' can refer to both sunlight and the light of a lamp. Similarly, 'dharma' can refer to an eternal quality or a transient one based on the context (ihetaraṃ tadgrahaṇena gṛhyate).

sloka: udāharaṇāpekṣaḥ tathā iti upasaṃhāraḥ na tathā iti vā sādhyasya upanayaḥ || {upanayalakṣaṇam}
translation: The illustrative example, referring a general rule to a specific case and its connection with the overall context or species, and the summary statement – these are not necessarily the introduction of the conclusion; rather, it could be the conclusion itself being introduced.

sloka: sādhyāsādharmyayukte udāharaṇe sthālyādi dravyamutyatidharmakatvamupasaṃhriyate sādhyavaidarmyayukte punarudāharaṇe ātmādi dravyamanutpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ na ca tathā śabda iti anutpattidharmakatvasyopasaṃhārapratiṣedhena utpattidharmakatvamupasaṃhiyate |
translation: In illustrating a comparison with the issue at hand, a substance like sthālī is presented; its bearing attributes different from those of the probandum is subsumed. Conversely, when illustrated with dissimilarity to the probandum, the constant manifestation of substances starting from ātman is observed, unlike sound, as established by negating the attribute of non-manifestation and affirming the attribute of manifestation.

sloka: hetvapadeśātpratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ nigamanam||{nigamanalakṣaṇam}
translation: Following the presentation of the logical reason, affirmation, and subsequently, moreover; what ensues is the declaration of the summation of the argument or conclusion in a syllogism.

sloka: sādharmyokte vaidharmyokte vā yathodāharaṇamupasaṃhriyate tasmādutpattidharmakatvādanityaḥ śabda iti nigamanam |
translation: When similarity or dissimilarity is described in a subordinate and inferior manner as an instance, it is referred to as the technical term indicating the characteristic of origination.

sloka: brahma vai mantraḥ | ḥ saptākṣaraṃ vai brahmargityekamakṣaraṃ yajuritidve sāmeti dve atha yadato'nyadbrahmaiva taddvyakṣaraṃ vai brahma tadetatsarvaṃsaptākṣaraṃ brahma |
translation: The Vedic hymn truly is Brahman, comprising of seven syllables; the one-syllabled Brahma is referred to as the Brahma-path. In the Yajurveda, there are two types of Brahmas known as "same" and "ti." Besides these, any other claimed Brahma is not the genuine Brahman. This entire seven-syllabled Brahman indeed represents the actual Brahman.

sloka: mantrabrāhmaṇe yajñasya pramāṇam mantrabrāhmaṇayorvedanāmadheyam karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The standard of a sacrificial ritual (yajña) is the mantra-brAhmaṇa, and the mantra-brAhmaṇa is what is identified as the Vedic portion. The brAhmaṇas serve as the impetus for religious acts or rites.

sloka: śeṣe brāhmaṇa śabdaḥ
translation: At the conclusion, O Brahmin, refers the sacred syllable Om.

sloka: dvividham brāhmaṇam vidhiḥ arthavādaśca
translation: The rule and exhortation pertain to two categories of Brahmans – one, the divine entity named Brahmā; and two, individuals who embody the qualities of Dharma, Artha, and Buddhi, representing the second stage of a Brāhman's life.

sloka: heturnirvacanaṃ nindā praśaṃsā saṃśayo vidhiḥ| parakriyā purākalpo vyavadhāraṇakalpanā|| upamānaṃ daśaite tu vidhayo brāhmaṇasya tu| etadvai sarvavedeṣu niyataṃ vidhilakṣaṇam||
translation: The impulse, designations as commendation or defamation, doubt, and rules associated with the brahmin are indeed established as symbols in all Vedas. They include: the final beatitude, past actions, subsequent ritual implementation, and the decree regarding the states of life, referred to as "upamana" in the two other departments of Vedic literature that grew out of the Brāhmaṇa portion.

sloka: itthaṃ vākyaistadarthānusandhānaṃ śravaṇaṃ bhavet yuktyā saṃbhāvitatvānusaṃdhānaṃ mannantu tat
translation: By contemplating the meanings through such aphorisms and acquiring knowledge by hearing them, and through deduction from circumstances, one should understand it according to its true nature. Thus, let that explanation be established as true.

sloka: yat saṃbaddhaṃ sat tadākārollekhi vijñānaṃ tat pratyakṣaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: That which is truly existent and logically coherent, being surrounded by many glorious waters, is directly and distinctly perceivable. This is the doctrine expounded in the Sāṃkhya Sūtras.

sloka: pratibandhadṛśaḥ pratibaddhajñānamanumānaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: Similar to the Sāṃkhya philosophical system, which serves as a guide for discerning the uninterrupted consciousness and comparing it to the previously bound state, the higher knowledge is identified, along with inferring its current bound or unbound state.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The term, designated as 'Sāṃkhya sūtra', is the one that has been expounded by the deserving (āpta). It is an eternal verity in the Mīmāṃsā tradition and refers to a distinct class of writings. The vocative singular form of sūtra also indicates its use as a textual reference, possibly implying a set of rules or teachings from the Sāṃkhya doctrine.

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and verbal testimony, being manifested in an orderly manner, are the three types of valid means of right understanding, as they establish the manifold object of knowledge through their own established certainty and understanding.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Derived from keeping in view as immediate means, and one of the means of obtaining true knowledge through inference, along with acquisition of knowledge through scriptural testimony collectively constitute the means of acquiring certain knowledge.

sloka: āptena dṛṣṭo'numitaḥ vā arthaḥ paratra svabodhasaṅkrāntaye śabdenopadiśyate | śabdāttadarthaviṣayā vṛttiḥ śroturāgamaḥ | yasyāśraddheyārtho vaktā na dṛṣṭānumitārthaḥ sa āgamaḥ plavate |
translation: "A reliable source's personally witnessed and verified truth is proclaimed through verbal communication. The application of such words pertains to the object of that knowledge, while the acquisition of such understanding comes from hearing. If the speaker, expressing unperceived or unverified meaning, lacks credibility, then that very communication becomes unreliable."

sloka: tadvacanādāmnāyasya prāmāṇyam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: By the instruction of this scriptural passage, the authoritativeness of the Vaiśeṣika doctrine becomes established. (A follower of the Vaiśeṣika doctrine, pay heed!)

sloka: asyedaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ saṃyogi virodhi samavāyi ceti laiṅgikam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Of this Vaiseshika doctrine, what are the motive (kāryam), cause of creation (kāraṇaṃ), one of the consonants in a combination of consonants (saṃyogi), contradictory (virodhi), and closely connected or united (samavāyi) aspects that are to be accomplished?

sloka: asyedaṃ kārya kāraṇasambandhaścāvayavādbhavati | vaiśeṣika |
translation: In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy, the relationship between cause and effect as an occurrence to the mind, and this being its fundamental principle, arises from distinct components.

sloka: etena śābdaṃ vyākhyātam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Using this very term, you two (learned ones) presently expound on the Vaiseshika philosophy, emphasized as it is by this word.

sloka: heturapadeśo liṅgaṃ pramāṇaṃ karaṇamityanarthāntaram | vaiśeṣika |
translation: In the Vaiseshika school, cause, pretense, gender signifier, means of acquiring valid knowledge, and instrumental cause are distinguished as having distinct meanings.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Derived from Pramāṇauddeśasūtra, the means of valid knowledge are perception, inference, and reliable testimony, which are comparable to each other in their significance and authority.

sloka: indriyārthasannikarṣotpannaṃ jñānaṃ avyapadeśyaṃ avyabhicāri vyavasāyātmakaṃ pratyakṣam|||| {pratyakṣalakṣaṇam} atha tatpūrvakaṃ trividhaṃ anumānaṃ pūrvavatśeṣavatsāmānyatodṛṣṭaṃ ca|||| {anumānalakṣaṇam} prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam |||| {upamānalakṣaṇam} āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ |||| {śabdalakṣaṇam}
translation: Knowledge originating from the connection between sense organs and objects is innate, consistent, definitive, and constitutes direct perception (pratyakṣa-lakṣaṇam). Preceding this, there are three types of inference: based on prior occurrence (pūrvavat-śeṣa-sāmānya), effect (śeṣa), and similarity (sāmānya); also known as sādharmya-based inference. Furthermore, there are two forms of authoritative testimony: verbal testimony (śabda-lakṣaṇam) and expert testimony (āptopadeśa).

sloka: satsaṃprayoge puruṣasyendriyāṇāṃ buddhijanma tatpratyakṣam
translation: During the convergence of a person's senses, the emergence of perception becomes immediately apprehensible through one's entire life.

sloka: autpattikas tu śabdasyārthena saṃbandhas tasya jñānam upadeśo'vyatirekaś cārthe'nupalabdhe tatpramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt
translation: The inherent connection of a word's meaning is sometimes referred to through the enunciation of its relating object, while the means of knowing that unobtained relation is called upadeśa. In Badarayana's view, irrespective of whether the object is directly perceivable or not, it serves as an independent pramāṇa (source of knowledge).

sloka: api vā kartṛsāmānyāt pramāṇam anumānaṃ syāt
translation: As an interrogative sentence, might it not be that inferential knowledge serves as a means of acquiring certain knowledge through the connection of different agents by their common properties?

sloka: anumānaṃ jñātasambandhasyaikadeśadarśanādekadeśāntare'sannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhiḥ| tattu dvividhaṃ pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandham ca| pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā dhūmākṛtidarśanādagnyākṛtivijñānam| sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā devadattasya gatipūrvikāṃ deśāntaraprāptimupalabhyādityagatismaraṇam|
translation: Inferring the interconnection occurs when one entity is directly perceived and the other, though nearby, awaits recognition. Indeed, such connections are twofold - one founded on direct perception, the other on analogy. A case in point for the former is recognizing smoke as originating from fire; while a memory of Devadatta traveling to another region serves as an example for the latter, since his unique footprints were discovered there.

sloka: śāstraṃ śabdavijñānādasannikṛṣṭe'rthe vijñānam||
translation: Knowledge, deriving from verbal communication/testimony and the act of discerning, should be acquired through closely related matters from the body of teaching (shastra). This is in reference to the notion of distinguishing or discering.

sloka: upamānamapi sādṛśyam asannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhimutpādayati| yathā gavayadarśanaṃ gosmaraṇasya|
translation: Even a mere example can evoke resemblance in a nearby context, just as seeing a gavay (monkey-chief) does for sparking a comparison with the sight of a cow being offered (in a ritual), or recollection of a cow, in the same way.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā ||
translation: Even if the notion's calamity is observed or heard about in a different manner, it should not be accepted. Just as Devadatta, in the form of external experience, lives through the non-vision of his habitation's similitude and the unseen becomes known through mental constructs.

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇābhāvo nāsti ityasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasya||
translation: Even non-existence is not considered equivalent to the truth for something so closely and definitively established, is the meaning.

sloka: śabdād eva pramitaḥ |
translation: Derived solely from sound, it has been established to an excessive degree.

sloka: api saṃrādhanepratyakṣānumānābhyām |
translation: Notwithstanding through direct observation and inferential reasoning.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: They make you witness it directly and infer it as well.

sloka: phalamata upapatteḥ |
translation: The fruit of something's occurrence or outcome.

sloka: athocyeta mā bhūtkarmānantaraṃ phalotpādaḥ karmakāryādapūrvātphalamutpatsyata iti tadapi nopapadyate apūrvasyācetanasya kāṣṭhaloṣṭasamasya cetanenāpravartitasya pravṛttyanupapatteḥ tadastitve eva pramāṇābhāvāt arthāpattiḥ pramāṇamiti cet na īśvarasiddherarthāpattikṣayāt||
translation: "Indeed, should it be declared that the result immediately arises from an action? No, it is not fitting. Even if there is no consciousness akin to a piece of wood or straw, activity cannot occur without a sentient being. The very establishment of this serves as an inference of the thing, which becomes the evidence. But if this inference is negated by the adjudication of the Lord's existence, what then?"

sloka: idānīmarthāpattirnirūpyate| tatropapadyajñānenopapādakakalpanamarthāpattiḥ| tatropapadyajñānaṃ karaṇam upapādakajñānaṃ phalam|
translation: The emergence of the intended meaning is being ascertained here. At that point, the emergence of the intended meaning arises from your causing it to occur, which is based on the higher knowledge, and the creation of this in the mind. Here, the lack of knowledge is the making agent, and the resulting manifestation of the intended meaning is the reward.

sloka: samyagarthe ca saṃśabdo duṣprayoganivāraṇaḥ | prayoga indriyāṇāṃ ca vyāpāro'rtheṣu kaththate ||duṣṭatvācchuktikāyogo vāryate rajatekṣaṇāt | evaṃ satyanuvādatvaṃ lakṣaṇasyāpi saṃbhavet ||
translation: Correctly, for the purpose and saṃśabda is said to be the remover of improper usage. The ceremonial use or application fitting for the senses is referred to as prayoga, while its deployment in relation to objects of the senses is spoken of as artheṣu. When defilement and the unnatural union (here indicating something against the proper order) like that of impurity and oyster are avoided, then truthful assertion becomes possible in the context of lakṣaṇa. Hence, you (singular, informal) become established in that totality.

sloka: pramāṇaṣaṭkavijñāto yatrā'rtho nā'nyathā bhavet | adṛṣṭaṃ kalpayedanyaṃ sā 'rthāpattirudāhṛtā ||
translation: In the context where the object adheres to correct perception, comprising of six means of valid knowledge, and does not behave differently, its emergence can be inferred therein. One should posit what remains unseen; such is the manifestation of the object.

sloka: ānumānikam apy ekeṣām iti cen na śarīrarūpakavinyastagṛhīterdarśayati ca |
translation: Even if some claim to have individually fixed their symptoms of bodily perception, if it is argued that way, it is not evident before us; such a demonstration does not occur.

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: May selfless assistance to the oppressed mother, heat-weary father, refreshing teacher, and companion apart, as well as to the fatherless distressed and those most excellent among them, result in fruitful outcomes; may it be accomplished.

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: Offering riches as sale to those fraudulent, deceitful, and dull-witted individuals, who are occasionally so disjunctively great, is utterly unfruitful for the gambler praising them.

sloka: ārūḍhapatite dattamanyāyopahṛtaṃ ca yat| vyarthaṃ tu patite dānaṃ brāhmaṇe taskare tathā||
translation: Granted and accepted through injustice, yet giving to a deserving Brahman is not rendered futile, but taking such a gift away is certainly so.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation: From the undeveloped (avyakta), all manifestations (vyaktayaḥ) emerge in this cyclical existence of day (ahaḥ) and night (rātrī), and they dissolve back into the undeveloped at the end of the night. The inherent nature is distinct from this undeveloped; it is eternal (sanātanaḥ) and remains unaltered in all beings, unaffected by their destruction or disappearance. It is referred to as the indestructible (akṣaraḥ) and considered the ultimate destination.

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: In the same way that one speaks to a cherished woman, so should one speak to a woman.

sloka: sattvasaktamatiḥ kṛṣṇe dahyamano mahārogaiḥ na vivedātmano gatram tartatyalhada saṃstitaḥ
translation: With a perception anchored in righteousness, why do you not comprehend that the living soul is being offered up as a sacrifice and consumed by severe tribulations in Kṛishṇa's presence? You have failed to recognize your own self.

sloka: pañcaiva mahāyajñāḥ| tānyeva mahāsattrāṇi bhūtayajño manuṣyayajñaḥ pitṛyajño devayajño brahmayajña iti
translation: The five great sacrifices, indeed, are those that I personally undertake: the grand ritual for beings, for humans, for ancestors, for deities, and for the divine Brahman, the repositories of sacred knowledge.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: The five implements of a householder - the woven wicker-work basket, the hand-mill, the utensil, the wooden bowl or mortar, and the small water-jar - are what get constructed; specifically, those that administer are bound to the moving ones.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti
translation: Then, the five sacrificial acts include: deva-yajna for the gods, bhuta-yajna devoted to living beings, pitri-yajna for ancestors, brahma-yajna as the worship of sacred knowledge, and manushya-yajna, referring to the act of worship or devotion towards humans.

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: By devoutly following prescribed rites, he carries out the five major sacrificial duties.

sloka: pitṛyajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatpitṛbhyaḥ svadhā karotyapyapastatpitṛyajñaḥ saṃtiṣṭhateiti | tatra piṇḍadānāsaṃbhave jalamātramapi pitṛbhyaḥ svadhā'stviti svadhāśabdena yaddadāti so'yaṃ pitṛyajñaḥ
translation: The definition of the pitṛyajña sacrifice is given: through 'svadhā,' offerings are made to the pitṛs, and the pitṛyajña is established, even with just a water offering to the pitṛs if a pindadaana has not taken place. The term "svadhā" denotes what is offered in the pitryajña.

sloka: vaiśvadevānuṣṭhānādūrdhvaṃ bahirdeśe vāyasādibhyo bhūtebhyo yadbalipradānaṃ so'yaṃ bhūtayajña:
translation: The Brāhmaṇas mention that the religious practice of Vaishvadeva, when carried out impeccably, surpasses other offerings made to various beings such as cows and so on, either outside or in a designated place. This flawless observance is indeed the unconscious sacrifice to the priest of the gods, who is symbolized by "that spot," as well as a donation of one's own self to all creatures.

sloka: yajñaḥ kasmāt | prakhyātaṃ yajatikarma iti nairuktāḥ | yācñaḥ bhavati iti vā | yajurunnaḥ bhavati iti vā | bahukṛṣṇājinaḥ iti aupamanyavaḥ | yajūṃṣi enaṃ nayanti iti vā |
translation: Why is the sacrifice known as the act of sacrificing derived from something, or why is it called "yajuḥ-unna" (derived from the Yajurveda), or how does it become a request, or why do the aupamanyavas (scholars of etymology) lead the yajūṃṣi (verses of Yajurveda) to this? (The implied "it" refers to the sacrifice.)

sloka: yajati codanādravyadevatākriyaṃ samudāye kṛtārthatvāt
translation: The one who currently performs the ritual of inviting the deity through the sacrificial materials and objects, having completed the intended purpose, does so in the religious ceremony associated with the particular Nakshatra.

sloka: yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ| yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ dravyaṃ devatā tyāgaḥ
translation: We will explain the act of worship, indicating its nature as the surrender of possessions to the divinity and the image of the deity.

sloka: yajñaḥ |
translation: The very essence of sacrifice.

sloka: suvṛttasya śarīrantu vyadhamanmukhavāyunā | svayameva jagatmraṣṭā dakṣiṇāgnistato'bhavat ||kanakasya śarīrantu dhmāpayāmāsa keśavaḥ | tato'bhūdgārhapatyāgniḥ pañcavaitānabhojanaḥ ||ghorasya tu vapuḥ śambhurdhmāpayāmāsa vai svayam | tata āhavanīyo'gnistatkṣaṇāt samajāyata ||etaistribhirjagat vyāptaṃ trimūlaṃ sakalaṃ jagat | etat yatra trayaṃ nityaṃ tiṣṭhati dbijasattamāḥ |
translation: For the virtuous-acting one, the lord of the universe has, through the western breath, become the degrader of the physical form. Keśava himself has made the household fire arise from the oblation of the golden body. Śambhu has personally made the āhavanīya fire arise from the degradation of the dreadful form. With these three, the entire universe is pervaded, its triple root established; where the best of the seeds always reside.

sloka: evaṃ yajñavarāhasya śarīraṃ yajñatāmagāt | yajñarūpeṇa sakalamāpyāyitumidaṃ jagat ||
translation: Indeed, in such a manner, the entire universe is filled by assimilating into the organized body of Varahasya, the son of the temple guardian, as a sacrifice personified, and in the form of all-encompassing sustenance for both heaven and the lower world.

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: The ceremony of offering material possessions, referred to as dravyatyāga, motivated by the image of a deity, is described as the act of casting the abandoned spirituous liquor into the fire. It is also said that this very fortune which is being relinquished is what is thrown into the fire during the homa (act of making an oblation).

sloka: upaviṣṭahomā svāhākārapradānā juhotayaḥ
translation: The oblation, having been offered according to prescribed rites, is addressed as "svaha" and concluded.

sloka: savaṣaṭkārāsu tiṣṭhandakṣiṇata udaṅprāṅ vaṣaṭkṛte
translation: In the rites consisting of six offerings, specifically at the son of Ghṛita-pṛishṭha's location, stay focused when invited with the Vaṣaṭ exclamation toward the house of relics.

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four priests - Adhvaryu, Brahmā, Hotā, and Agnīdhra, who are responsible for performing the darśa and pūrṇamāsa rituals, have completed them successfully.

sloka: pākayajñānyajennityaṃ haviryajñāṃśca nityaśaḥ | somāṃśca vidhipūrveṇa ya iccheddharmamavyayam|
translation: One should consistently offer oblations in the domestic fire sacrifice (pākayajña) and in the haviryajña, as well as regularly in other fires. Moreover, if one aspires to follow the eternal, unchanging dharmic path, they should also offer soma according to ancient tradition.

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛksāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The alliance of sacrificial materials such as ingredients from animals, plants, and others, along with the oblations, Ṛic verses, Sāmans, and sacrificial formulas, is similarly referred to as a yajña (sacrifice). Likewise, the union of ṛtvijs (officiants) is known as such. It is also called dakṣiṇā, referring to the fee or reward given to the Brāhman or placed near a river in some instances.

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: "Yes, this individual is characterized by the non-performance of a sacrifice or being unsociable."

sloka: vrīhīnyavānvā haviṣi
translation: Where are the barley and grains for the oblation?

sloka: pāṇigrahaṇādiragnistamaupāsanamityācakṣate tasmingṛhyāṇi karmāṇi kriyante tasyaupāsanenāhitāgnitvaṃ
translation: The scripture designates the rituals from 'seizing' the sun or moon to 'Agni' as 'upāsana'. When performed, these domestic rites result in the subsiding of that inner fire.

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: In that context, the following are established: thrice seven acts of worship through domestic fires, Aupāsana and Homa rituals, the initial Parvan of Cāturmāsya, offerings made during new and full moons, as well as those dedicated to one of the eleven Rudras named Sarpa and Indra, known as Baliriti in the eighth Manv-antara.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: Then, one should perform the five sacrifices: the deva yajna, offering into the fire; bhuta yajna, giving alms; pitr yajna, making offerings to ancestors; brahma yajna, studying and teaching the Vedas; manushya yajna, giving to people.

sloka: vidārite varāhasya kāye bhargeṇa tatkṣaṇāt | brahmaviṣṇuśivā devāḥ sarvaiśca pramathaiḥ saha | ninyurjalāt samuddhṛtya tat śarīraṃ nabhaḥ prati | tadvibhejuḥ śarīrantu viṣṇoścakreṇa khaṇḍaśaḥ | tasyāṅga sandhito yajñājātāste vai pṛthakpṛthak | yasmād yasmācca ye yajñāstat śṛṇvantu maharṣayaḥ| bhrūnāsāsandhinā jāto jyotiṣṭomo mahādhvaraḥ | hanuśravaṇasandhyostu vahniṣṭomo vyajāyata | cakṣurbhruvoḥ sandhinā tu vrātyastomo vyajāyata | āyuḥ paugarbhavastomastasya potroṣṭha sandhinā | vṛddhastoma vṛhatstomau jihvāmūlādvyajāyata | atirātraṃ savairājamadhojihvāntarādabhūt | adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pidvayajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo valibhauto nṛyajño'tidhipajatam | snānaṃ tarpaṇaparvyantaṃ nityayajñāśca sāṃśaḥ | kaṇṭhasandheḥ samutpannā jihvāto vidhayastathā | yavājimedho mahāmedho naramedhastathaiva ca | prāṇihiṃsākarā ye'nye te kṣātāḥ pādasandhitaḥ | rājasūyo'tha kārīrī vājapeyastathaivaca | pṛṣṭhasandhau samutpannā grahayajñāstathaiva ca |
translation:
In this manner, the deities Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, along with all the ghosts, have simultaneously extracted the body of Varaha from the water. They trembled in fear of its limbs, as they were torn apart by Viṣṇu’s discus. The yajnas (sacrificial rites) that originated from his limbs are well-known to the great sages. Jyotiṣṭoma and other Ājā sacrifices emerged from his nasal area; Vahniṣṭoma arose from the union of the speech and ear regions; Vṛātyastoma was born from the eye and eyebrow region; Āyustoma originated from the throat region; and Vṛddhastoma, Vṛhatstoma emerged from the root of the tongue. The great Adhyāpana sacrifice arose from between the two rows of teeth, while other sacrifices such as Atirātra were born in various parts of his body.

The Brahmayajña is performed with knowledge, Pidvayajña for offspring, Tarpaṇa for ancestors, Homa to please deities, and Valibhauta sacrifice for all beings. The Nṛyajñas are dedicated to human needs. Snāna (bath) and other rites related to Tarpaṇa constitute the daily sacrifices.

The Yavājimedha is a great horse-sacrifice, Naramedha a still greater one, while Prāṇihiṃsākarā and others are performed in various ways, including harming living beings for sacrificial offerings. The Rājasūya is dedicated to royal consecration; Kārīrī denotes the Vājapeya rite; Grahayajñas are related to planets; and sacrifices are also performed during eclipses and other celestial phenomena, as well as in various seasons.

sloka: evaṃ yaḥ sarvabhūtāni brāhmaṇo nityaṃ arcati | sa gacchati paraṃ sthānaṃ tejomūrtiḥ pathā rjunā | | | |
translation: In this manner, the constant worshiper of all beings, a Brāhmaṇa in the second stage of life, who adorns (singing his praises), attains the radiant fiery energy incarnation and the holy supreme abode.

sloka: agnau gurāvātmani ca sarvabhūteṣvadhokṣajam | bhūtaiḥ svadhāmabhiḥ paśyedapraviṣṭaṃ praviṣṭavat || || evaṃ vidho brahmacārī vānaprastho yatirgṛhī | caran viditavijñānaḥ paraṃ brahmādhigacchati || ||
translation: In the spiritual fires and in the revered self, as well as in all beings, one should perceive the imperishable Atman. The embodied being sees it associating and disassociating (with bodies) through the vital breaths. Thus, a student who has understood this and is pure becomes a forest-dweller, ascetic, or householder; such a person, with knowledge gained from experience, reaches the ultimate Brahman.

sloka: ya॒masya̭ mā ya॒myaṃ kāma॒ āga̭ntsamā॒ne yonaṷ saha॒śeyyā̭ya | jā॒yeva॒ patyḙ ta॒nva̭ṃ riricyā॒ṃ vi ci̭dvṛheva॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: In the struggle of existence, who wouldn't confront hostility toward death, aspiring to be reborn with their partner, similar to during a sacrificial ritual or a fierce chariot race?

sloka: na ti̭ṣṭhanti॒ na ni mi̭ṣantye॒te de॒vānā॒ṃ spaśa̭ i॒ha ye cara̭nti | a॒nyena॒ madā̭hano yāhi॒ tūya॒ṃ tena॒ vi vṛ̭ha॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: "Those who, behaving in an ungenerous manner, wander here, are neither welcomed nor recognized by the gods. With a sacrificial offering, approach the divine assembly; through that very means, you will be exalted and granted respect."

sloka: ā ghā॒ tā ga̭cchā॒nutta̭rā yu॒gāni॒ yatra̭ jā॒maya̭: kṛ॒ṇava॒nnajā̭mi | upa̭ barbṛhi vṛṣa॒bhāya̭ bā॒huma॒nyami̭cchasva subhage॒ pati॒ṃ mat ||
translation: Oh fortunate one, become eager to perform the yugas' sacrifices at the very location where the churning of the ocean of milk transpired. Approach Bhumi, Vishnu's consort, as a groom, O attractive one.

sloka: na vā ṷ te ta॒nvā̭ ta॒nvaṃ saṃ pa̭pṛcyāṃ pā॒pamā̭hu॒ryaḥ svasā̭raṃ ni॒gacchā̭t | a॒nyena॒ matpra॒muda̭: kalpayasva॒ na te॒ bhrātā̭ subhage vaṣṭye॒tat ||
translation: You, joy of companions, should not attempt to acquire your brother's wealth through deceitful methods. Instead, skillfully manage the situation. Undoubtedly, such behavior is unbefitting of you.

sloka: ayane viṣuve caiva ṣaḍaśītimukheṣu ca| candrasūryoparāge ca dattamakṣayamucyate||
translation: During the sacrificial rites known as ayane and viṣu, on the sixteenth day-parts of the lunar month, and at the convergence of the sun and moon, it is declared to have been granted and made imperishable. This refers to the 7th Vāsudeva's gift, named akṣayam, which is proclaimed during these specific occasions.

sloka: śatamindukṣaye dānaṃ sahasrantu dinakṣaye | viṣuve śatasahasraṃ vyatīpātetvantakam ||
