translation: A hundred oblations offered to the waning moon, a thousand at the setting of the sun, during a dual ekāha (twice a month), a hundred thousand times to avert disaster.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Offering payasam to the Kritikas, the fortune favored one should appease noble Brahmins with it, having satisfied them they can attain the highest abode (supreme world).

sloka: āhāraṃ maithunaṃ nidrāṃ sandhyākāle tu varjjayet | karma cādhyayanañcaiva tathā dānapratigrahau |
translation: During the sandhyā periods, one should abstain from taking food, sexual union, and sleep. Likewise, one is obliged to avoid engaging in any actions or studies, as well as giving or accepting anything, each in its own measure.

sloka: tato'bhūttrivṛdaoṃkāro yo'vyaktaprabhavaḥ svarāṭyattalliṅgaṃ bhagavato brahmaṇaḥ paramātmanaḥ ||
translation: The one who emerged as the distinctive sound "Om" before the creation, being self-existent and having an ineffable form, is indeed the venerable paramatman (supreme soul) of the brahman.

sloka: svadhāmno brāhmaṇaḥ sākṣādvācakaḥ paramātmanaḥ sa sarvamantropaniṣadvedabījaṃ sanātanam ||
translation: The brahmin, making visible the domain of the Self, is truly the eternal seed of all mantras and Upanishads, belonging to the highest personal principle of life, as well as the mystical letter or syllable forming the essential part of any deity's mantra.

sloka: tenāsau caturo vedāṃścaturbhirvadanairvibhuḥ savyāhṛtikānsaoṃkārāṃścāturhotravivakṣayā || ||
translation: Through him (the Sun god), conspicuous as the one who reveals, the four Vedas are made manifest by his four radiant mouths.

sloka: te paramparayā prāptāstattacchiṣyairdhṛtavrataiḥ caturyugeṣvatha vyastā dvāparādau maharṣibhiḥ || ||
translation: These (te), inherited via continuous tradition, are the ancient religious meditations (parampara) that have been directly received by the disciples (śiṣyaiḥ) in each of the four yugas, having been upheld by great sages (mahāṛṣibhiḥ) through sacred knowledge (mahā) during the dvāpara age, which is the third part (ādau) of the 7-partite Sāman.

sloka: parāśarātsatyavatyāmaṃśāṃśakalayā vibhuḥ avatīrṇo mahābhāga vedaṃ cakre caturvidham || asmin yuge kṛto vyāsaḥ pārāśaryaḥ parantapaḥ| dvaipāyana iti khyāto viṣṇoraṃśaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||
translation: Born in the lineage of Parāśara and Satyavatī, the all-powerful one assumed a physical form, creating the fourfold Veda in this age and this era's appointed time. You, Vyāsa, also known as Dvaipāyana and born into Viṣṇu's lineage, were given the task of compilation, becoming notorious as such.

sloka: tatrargvedadharaḥ pailaḥ sāmago jaiminiḥ kaviḥ | vaiśaṃpāyana evaiko niṣṇāto yajuṣāmuta || || atharvāṅ‌girasāmāsīt sumanturdāruṇo muniḥ |
translation: Among them, Paila, the upholder of the Ṛigveda, and Jaimini, the scholar of the Sāmaveda, are prominent; Vaiśampāyana is uniquely knowledgeable in the Yajurveda; Sumantu, a sage, has thoroughly mastered the Atharvangirasa.

sloka: pādenārthena copetā vṛttabaddhā mantrā ṛcaḥ| gītirūpā mantrāḥ sāmāni| vṛttagītivarjitatvena praśliṣṭapaṭhitā mantrā yajūṃṣi|
translation: Oh ārtha, together with the caesura of a verse, you should recite the mantras and sacred verses that are bound by vṛtta. The dreamy or phantom-like gīti and rūpā mantras belong to the sāmāni class. The mantras, when not connected with yajūṃṣi, are specially established through the instrumental singular mantrā, being those that have been causally separated from other sacrificial formulae.

sloka: śabdātirikta śabdopajīvipramāṇātiriktaṃ ca yatpramāṇaṃ tajjanyapramitiviṣayānatiriktārthako yo yastadanyatve sati āmuṣmikasukhajanakoccāraṇakatve sati janyajñānājanyo yo pramāṇaśabdastattvaṃ vedatvam iti ca prācīnastallakṣaṇamuktam |
translation: That which serves as a means of valid knowledge, distinct from words and yet dependent on them, such a means is referred to as "jnyana-pramana" in the context of examining the object of cognition of hetu (reason) in inference. This definition has been classically articulated in ancient texts. The term that represents this means of valid knowledge becomes "veda" or true knowledge when it results in the realization of the self, which is separate from other objects and associated with happiness, cognizance, and experience.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: You, who have previously nurtured the sacred hymns and metrical language, now cause the Śakvarīs (a group of songs) to thrive and prosper. Brahmā, in his lifetime, speaks about the knowledge you have acquired. You also establish the measure for the worship in the sacrifice.

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda ātharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśirdaivo
translation: Indeed, by name it's referred to as Rigveda, Yajurveda as the second, Samaveda as the third, and Atharvana as the fourth; the fifth, deeply rooted in tradition, is recognized as Itihasa-Purana, akin to the ancestral one among the Vedas, and also known as Dvaivo (possibly indicating two gods or sacred texts).

sloka: purāṇaṃ pañcamo veda iti brahmānuśāsanam
translation: The fifteenth Purana, known as the fifth Veda, is the Brahmana portion of the Vedic scriptures.

sloka: ṛgyajuḥsāmātharvākhyā vedāścatvāra uddhṛtāḥ | itihāsapurāṇaṃ ca pañcamo veda ucyate || ||
translation: The four Vedas - Ṛig, Yajuḥ, Sāma, and Atharva, known by name, have been revealed. The fifth entity referred to as Veda is the collection of itihāsa (legendary heroic history) and purāṇa (chiefly eighteen in number). This is so declared.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca | taṃ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭamaśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇam | viṣīdantamidaṃ vākyamuvāca madhusūdanaḥ || ||
translation: Sanjaya, overwhelmed by compassion, addressed him in this way. Madhusudana, with tears streaming down and in a state of distress, spoke these words.

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | kutastvā kaśmalamidaṃ viṣame samupasthitam | anāryajuṣṭamasvargyamakīrtikaramarjuna || ||
translation: The Blessed One said, "How has this impurity arisen for you, Arjuna, in this dire predicament? It is unworthy of an Ārya and brings ill repute instead of heavenly realms."

sloka: kla‍aibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate | kṣudraṃ hṛdayadaurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa || ||
translation: Partha, do not adopt cowardice; it is inappropriate for you. Abandoning petty hearted weakness, stir yourself, vanquisher of adversaries.

sloka: arjuna uvāca | kathaṃ bhīṣmamahaṃ saṃkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana | iṣubhiḥ prati yotsyāmi pūjārhāvarisūdana || ||
translation: Arjuna asked, “How am I to oppose Bhīshma and Drona in this war with arrows, as a faithful devotee deserving homage, O Madhusudana, since they are extremely brave and worthy of worship?”

sloka: gurūnahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyamapīha loke | hatvārthakāmāṃstu gurūnihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhirapradigdhān || ||
translation: By depriving highly prized masters, abounding in dignity, of their wealth, one may only enjoy a meager living in this world. But by indulging in desires resulting from the possession of a thing based on one's own free will, one should consume to enjoy pleasures stained with blood herein, only after becoming a consumer of alms himself, passively partaking in such acts.

sloka: na caitadvidmaḥ kataranno garīyo yadvā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ | yāneva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ || ||
translation: Out of fear, we don't know whether we can surpass the Dhārtarāṣṭras or they will conquer us. Nor do we know which is more valuable. Even if we manage to wound and kill them, we wouldn't desire to live, being stationed in front of them.

sloka: kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasammūḍhacetāḥ | yacchreyaḥ syānniścitaṃ brūhi tanme śiṣyaste'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam || ||
translation: Overwhelmed by greed and confused about my duty, I ask you to tell me decisively what is most beneficial for me. I am your disciple; restrain me, who has sought refuge in you.

sloka: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyādya cchokamucchoṣaṇamindriyāṇām | avāpya bhūmāvasapatnamṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇāmapi cādhipatyam || ||
translation: Indeed, I don't see anyone in the present who can surpass me in controlling their senses from their objects, for, having acquired an unrivaled, prosperous kingdom and sovereignty over even the gods, it is as if I am invincible.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca evamuktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ parantapa | na yotsya iti govindamuktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha || ||
translation: Sanjaya, after saying this to Hrishikesa, and having read out loud the hero Arjuna's declaration of "I will not fight," became silently attentive, assuredly, O Govinda.

sloka: tamuvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasanniva bhārata | senayorubhayormadhye viṣīdantamidaṃ vacaḥ || ||
translation: The ruler Hrsikesa, with a smiling countenance like Brahma, addressed him amidst the two armies, saying these words...

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | aśocyānanvaśocastvaṃ prajñāvādāṃśca bhāṣase | gatāsūnagatāsūṃśca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ || ||
translation: The dignified lord spoke, "Why do you lament for the inappropriate and express wisdom? The learned do not mourn for those who have left or are yet to leave."

sloka: na tvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ | na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayamataḥ param || ||
translation: Certainly not in the past have I, you, or any of these rulers existed separately, and none of us will exist as distinct beings in the future either.

sloka: dehino'sminyathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā | tathā dehāntaraprāptirdhīrastatra na muhyati || ||
translation: The being who inhabits the body experiences maidenhood, youthfulness, and aging, as well as the arrival at a new body in the same way; nonetheless, possessing clear intentions, they do not become confused or go astray regarding the enduring consciousness therein.

sloka: mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ | āgamāpāyino'nityāstāṃstitikṣasva bhārata || ||
translation: "O Kaunteya, the material world's sense of touch, such as cold and heat, happiness and (un)ease, are sometimes referred to as transient gifts. They are perishable and fleeting. You must strive to endure them, O inhabitant of Bharata-varsha."

sloka: yaṃ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha | samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ so'mṛtatvāya kalpate || ||
translation: Indeed, for fear of being unsettled or made unhappy, the one who remains indifferent to both pleasure and pain, steadfast and even-tempered, is considered by such behavior to be moving toward eternal life.

sloka: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ | ubhayorapi dṛṣṭo'ntastvanayostattvadarśibhiḥ || ||
translation: For those who truly see, there is no emergence from the unreal nor disappearance in the real; the seers have realized the true nature of both as lying beyond these extremes.

sloka: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ | anāśino'prameyasya tasmādyudhyasva bhārata || ||
translation: These perishable bodies, named as the manifestations of the eternal divine being, are indeed transient for the embodied one. Hence, as the inhabitant of Bharata-varsha, strive to defend and be a match for the immeasurable and imperishable, referring to the goddess Manasā.

sloka: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaścainaṃ manyate hatam | ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate || ||
translation: The one who truly knows the slayer or regards/considers someone as already slain, neither of them understand correctly. Indeed, he does not commit violence nor is he harmed.

sloka: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācinnāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato'yaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre || ||
translation: Out of fear, one may ask: "Does it ever grow or get born, or will it cease to be, becoming something or nothing in the future? Is it transient, subject to decay and destruction? Nevertheless, this enduring entity, remaining unchanged and constant throughout time, is eternal, ancient, and perpetual. Even when the body is destroyed, it does not meet its demise."

sloka: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enamajamavyayam |kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam || ||
translation: How, O Partha, can someone cause injury to or destroy the continually imperishable one, an unchanging entity, who is called by the later name of Atharva-veda, and whom this (Brahma) wounds/hurls upon, and who is born of immortal nature?

sloka: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇānyanyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī || ||
translation: In admiration, just as a person discards decayed clothes and takes fresh ones, in the same way, the primeval Spirit within us discards old, worn-out bodies, consuming them utterly by burning, and enters into new ones.

sloka: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ | na cainaṃ kledayantyāpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ || || acchedyo'yamadāhyo'yamakledyo'śoṣya eva ca | nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇuracalo'yaṃ sanātanaḥ || ||
translation:
For fear that it may be divided by sharp weapons, burned by fire,
wetted by water, or dried by the wind,
it is indeed incombustible, not to be wetted, and undestroyable,
ever-present, all-pervading, motionless, and immovable.
Such is this eternal entity.

sloka: avyakto'yamacintyo'yamavikāryo'yamucyate | tasmādevaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitumarhasi || ||
translation: This undeveloped, unfathomable, and unchanging reality is referred to. Hence, as a knower of it, you ought not to harbor grief toward what is spoken of in this way.

sloka: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyurdhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca | tasmādaparihārye'rthe na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: Indeed, assuredly for one brought into existence by

sloka: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata | avyaktanidhanānyeva tatra kā paridevanā || ||
translation: Bharata, why this lamentation, then, over the unmanifest and manifest entities that have taken the form of their subtle abodes?

sloka: āścaryavatpaśyati kaścidena māścaryavadvadati tathaiva cānyaḥ | āścaryavaccainamanyaḥ śa‍ṛṇoti śrutvāpyenaṃ veda na caiva kaścit || ||
translation: Some perceive the extraordinary as extraordinary, and some describe it as such, while others hear it as something extraordinary; still, not all of them come to know it as such, even after hearing.

sloka: dehī nityamavadhyo'yaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata| tasmātsarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: Indeed, O inhabitant of Bharata-varsha (India), this manifestation having the appearance of the eternal Durgā, who is not to be killed, inherent in all Kṛishṇa, should be honored. Therefore, for fear of lest you mistakenly consider otherwise, you should not grieve over any living beings.

sloka: svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na vikampitumarhasi | dharmyāddhi yuddhācchreyo'nyatkṣatriyasya na vidyate || ||
translation: Even after contemplating what constitutes your inherent ethical precepts, you shouldn't waver. Indeed, for a kshatriya, the most virtuous path lies in engaging in a righteous battle, rather than pursuing any other course of action.

sloka: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam | sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddhamīdṛśam || ||
translation: Through chance, you wish for the door to Indra's heaven to be unobstructed, O Partha. Such a battle is what Kshatriyas, filled with joy and endowed with such qualities, obtain.

sloka: atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi | tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: If you refrain from participating in this virtuous combat, you will indeed abandon both your religious duty and fame. As a result, you will incur sin.

sloka: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te'vyayām | sambhāvitasya cākīrtirmaraṇādatiricyate || ||
translation: Even ordinary people will speak of your ill-fame, but for one who is esteemed, their undying fame is spoken of as extending beyond the very moment of their passing.

sloka: bhayādraṇāduparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ | yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam || ||
translation: The mighty charioteers who have retreated out of fear of battle will hold you in high esteem if, having become highly valued yourself, you decide to approach them lightly (without pomp or seriousness). This is because they will think highly of you due to your greatness that arises from not being intimidated by battle and your ability to maintain composure.

sloka: avācyavādāṃśca bahūnvadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ | nindantastava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim || ||
translation: "Your associates will soon voice numerous unclear reproaches and, more distressingly, belittle your capabilities. What could be more painful than this?"

sloka: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm | tasmāduttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ || ||
translation: Even supposing you are killed, you will still gain Indra's heaven, and if victorious, you will enjoy sovereignty over the earth. Hence, resolved to fight, rise up, O Kaunteya, as your reign and conquest await.

sloka: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: Regarding gains and losses, pleasures and pains, as well as victory and defeat with equanimity, now prepare yourself for battle. By doing so, you will not incur sin in the future.

sloka: eṣā te'bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu | buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi || ||
translation: This insight, revealed in the Sāṃkhya branch as applicable to Yoga, is what you ought to understand, Partha. Listen to the discipline that, when absorbed in abstract meditation with it, will allow you to cast off the mundane bondage of action through the power of this very thoughtful insight.

sloka: nehābhikramanāśo'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpamapyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt || ||
translation: For fear of backsliding, there is no annihilation here, nor any regret; indeed, even the slightest observance of religious merit protects one from great danger.

sloka: vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana | bahuśākhā hyanantāśca buddhayo'vyavasāyinām || ||
translation: O prince of the Kurus, named Kurunandana, the intellect endowed with a resolute nature is singular, while the intellects of those devoid of decisiveness have countless ramifications and are infinite in number.

sloka: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām | kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati || || bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām | vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate || ||
translation: Those with desires as their very essence, seeking paradise and the results of actions as their objective, such a multitude of expedient deeds leading to material enjoyment and lordship does not lead to steadfastness of intellect in samadhi. For those who are attached and whose consciousnesses are stolen by that (i.e., enjoyment and power), an intellect characterized by resoluteness is not established in samadhi.

sloka: traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna | nirdvandvo nityasattvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān || || yāvānartha udapāne sarvataḥ saṃplutodake | tāvānsarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ || || karmaṇyevādhikāraste mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karmaphalaheturbhūrmā te saṅgo'stvakarmaṇi || ||
translation:
Arjuna, the Vedas pertain to the three gunas, but one who is free from these gunas, transcending duality and material endeavor, is truly established in pure consciousness, unattached and unwavering. 

For what purpose are extensive scriptural discussions for one who sees the essence of all as the same? Just as a pool of water on a boat serves no purpose, so his needs are already fulfilled. For the self-realized scholar, all the Vedas are only as useful as a small well in a floodplain.

Action is your right, never its fruits; let not your attachment be to inaction or to the results of action, Arjuna. O Dhananjaya, be steadfast in yoga, unattached to success or failure. Such evenness of mind is called yoga.

sloka: arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim‌ || ||
translation: Arjuna asked: What is the speech of one established in wisdom, O Keśava? How does he act, and in what way should he conduct himself, remain still, or move about?

sloka: bhagavañjāyate tīvraṃ cintayānasya suvrata || karmapākaphalaṃ yasminmānuṣairupabhujyate|||| ñāē īṁ ā || āṁ āṣē||||
translation: The exalted one is generated from profound meditation; recognize, the outcome of actions that people partake in him.

sloka: ṛṣiruddālakirdīkṣāmupagamya tataḥ sutam| tvaṃ māmupacarasveti nāciketamabhāṣata||
translation: Upon approaching the seer and undergoing the initiation rites, you are commanded to serve me, as was spoken (by) Nāciketam.

sloka: tadā kṣamasveti prārthayamānasyaiva tasya nāciketasya deho gatasatvo bhūmau nyapatat patitaṃ sutaṃ dṛṣṭvā pitāpi kiṃ mayānuṣṭhitaṃ pāpeneti bruvan bhūmau nipapāta
translation: Then, as he was being invoked for forgiveness, the true essence of Naciketas, having disappeared, left his body. Seeing his son fallen on the ground, the father, now seated there, pondered aloud, "What evil have I brought upon myself through my actions to deserve this calamity?"

sloka: na dṛṣyate mānuṣaṃ te vapuḥ
translation: For fear that his human form might be seen, (it is) not visible.

sloka: yasminvṛkṣe supalāśe devaiḥ sampibate yamaḥ | atrā no viśpati: pitā purāṇā~ anu venati ||
translation: In the sacred fig tree, Supalasha, that Yama offers oblations to the gods, our ancestral lord, the ancient one, performs his worship even now.

sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
translation: Who is that vṛtra (enemy), known as megha in the Nairuktas' tradition and as Tvāṣṭra or Asura in the itihāsa texts? From the mixture of water and light, the very act of rainfall is produced. Then, drawing comparisons with this, warlike activities are named.

sloka: jaṭādhīstīvratapā brahmavādisabhāpatiḥ aṅkīkṛtya sriyaṃ cāste gatahrīḥ prākṛte yathā prāyaśaḥ prākṛtāścāpi sriyaṃ rahasi bibhrati | ayaṃ mahāvratadharo bibhrarti sadasi sriyam
translation: The president of the Brahma-vādi sabha, endowed with matted hair and rigorous austerities, adorns himself with his innate radiance in the same way an ordinary person does; indeed, this great vow-upholder dons his natural splendor even in public places.

sloka: nāyamarhati vaikuṇṭha pādamūlopasarpaṇam sambhāvitamatiḥ stabdhaḥ sādhubhiḥ paryupāsitam ataḥ pāpīyasīṃ yonimāsurīṃ yāhi durmate yatheha bhūyo na kartā putra kilbiṣamjajñe tvaṣṭurdakṣiṇādnau dānavīṃ yonimāśritaḥ vṛtra ityabhivikhyāto jñānavijñānasaṃyutaḥ
translation: I fear that my fame as a scholar may reach children, but I do not consider it appropriate to approach the divine abode of Vaikuṇṭha, nor did you instruct me to approach the base of its pillar. Yet, established in your resolute counsel, you stood mute while being worshiped by the virtuous. Therefore, why are you now, O wicked one, going toward the sinful and demonic womb? Haven't you remembered that you were born from the purifying union of Tvaṣṭu and his sister Dakṣiṇā, and have been known as Vṛtra, endowed with knowledge and consciousness?

sloka: atṛpṇuvantaṃ viyatamabudhyamabudhyamānaṃ suṣupāṇamindra sapta prati pravata āśayānamahiṃ vajreṇa vi riṇā aparvan
translation: Noticing the wind stirring in the sky, Indra, armed with his thunderbolt, strikes the still unperceived demon Vritra, taking thrice seven mystical steps toward it as lightning flashes all around.

sloka: samudrajyeṣṭhāḥ salilasya madhyātpunānā yantyaniviśamānāḥ indro yā vajrī vṛṣabho rarāda tā āpo devīrihamāmavantu
translation: Preeminent rulers of the ocean, engaged in purifying the flood from its midst and all around, may Indra, the wife of Indra (or thunderbolt-wielder), the most excellent bull, having roared once, protect those waters and the female deity Devi for us in this world.

sloka: i॒damasmi॒ tatte॒ pra dāsyā॒mīti॒ tvī
translation: I indeed am the one before whom you will offer this.

sloka: āhāranidrābhayamaithunaṃ ca samānametatpaśubhirnarāṇām | dharmo hi teṣāmadhiko viśeṣo dharmeṇa hīnāḥ paśubhiḥ samānāḥ ||
translation: The shared activities of acquiring food, sleeping, experiencing fear, and sexual union for both humans and animals; yet, the distinctive feature among them is their varying levels of adherence to dharmic principles. Those lacking in dharma are comparable to animals.

sloka: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye'bravīnmanuḥ | | | |
translation: Manu, the progenitor and lawgiver, expounded to the dual aspects of the four social orders (cāturvarṇye) this constituent duty of dharma in its entirety (sāmāsikaṃ): non-violence (ahiṃsā), truthfulness (satyaṃ), honesty (asteyaṃ), purity (śaucam), and self-restraint (indriyanigrahaḥ).

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyam akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: Resolution, forbearance, self-restraint, non-stealing, integrity, control of the senses, meditation, knowledge, truthfulness, and freedom from anger – these ten symbolize religious merit or moral virtue.

sloka: na rājyaṃ na rājā'sīnna daṇḍayo na ca dāṇḍika: dharmeṇaiva prajāssarvā rakṣanti sma parasparam
translation: Out of fear that a future royal authority or military caste member wielding a sword might not protect (or govern) people, nor the executioners; indeed, it is only through adherence to dharma that all subjects collectively ensure mutual protection.

sloka: prajanārthaṃ striyaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ saṃtānārthaṃ ca mānavaḥ | tasmātsādhāraṇo dharmaḥ śrutau patnyā sahoditaḥ | | | |
translation: Women were created for the purpose of progeny and men for the continuation of the lineage. Hence, the general dharma for both, as orally transmitted by the Brahmans from generation to generation, is established concurrently with a wife.

sloka: dharme cārthe ca kāme ca nāticaritavyā tvayeyam |
translation: In the realms of customary observance, advantage, and desire, one should not deviate from undertaking this path, nor overstep the bounds.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ brahmakarma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Self-control, restraint, religious austerity, integrity, endurance, propriety, conscience, discernment, and faithfulness are indeed the inherent duties of the self-existent Spirit, manifesting as one's own natural disposition.

sloka: śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam | dānamīśvarabhāvaśca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Heroism, spiritual power, offering dedication, cleverness in fighting, holding one's ground in battle without fleeing, generous giving, and being a lordly figure - all these are the warrior class's inherent obligations, stemming from their natural disposition, including both martial duties and nurturing qualities.

sloka: kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāvajam || ||
translation: The inherent obligations of a vaishya consist of cultivating soil, caring for cattle, and conducting trade, while attending to and serving others is the very nature of a shudra's duties.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucaṃ indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyaṃ akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten attributes of Dharma are: resolution or satisfaction (personified), forgiveness, self-restraint, abstention from theft, integrity, mastery of the five sense organs, wisdom, truthfulness, and freedom from anger.

sloka: īśā vāsyamidaṃ sarvaṃ yatkiṃ ca jagatyāṃ jagat | tena tyaktena bhuñjīthā mā gṛdhaḥ kasya sviddhanam || ||
translation: With the supreme spirit as the settler, may you enjoy everything in this moving and non-moving world, obtained through renunciation. Do not be greedy for what belongs to others, nor should you doubt about their valued objects.

sloka: paropakārāya phalanti vṛkṣāḥ paropakārāya vahanti nadyaḥ | paropakārāya duhanti gāvaḥ paropakārārthamidaṃ śarīram || satyaṃ vada | dharmañcara | svādhyāyānmā pramadaḥ | ācāryāya priyaṃ dhanamāhṛtya prajātantuṃ mā vyavacchetsīḥ | satyānna pramaditavyam | dharmānna pramaditavyam | kuśalānna pramaditavyam | bhūtyai na pramaditavyam | svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam || ||
translation: Trees yield fruits and are fruitful for others' assistance, rivers flow and carry along for others' benefit, cattle graze and provide milk for assisting others - similarly, this very body also has a purpose of benefiting others. Speak the truth, follow dharma, and do not be negligent in your Vedic studies. Give wealth to the deserving teacher as an act of kindness, but do not neglect your progeny's propagation. Do not fail to uphold truth, religious merit, auspiciousness, and means of helping or promoting through your sacred writings and teachings.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam | mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava | yānyanavadyāni karmāṇi tāni sevitavyāni | no itarāṇi | yānyasmākaṃ sucaritāni | tāni tvayopāsyāni | no itarāṇi || || sukhārthinaḥ kuto vidyā nāsti vidyārthinaḥ sukham | sukhārthī vā tyajedvidyāṃ vidyārthī vā tyajet sukham ||
translation: Neglect not the observances due to gods and ancestors, which, when performed with good conduct, yield rewards. Regard your mother as a goddess, your father as a deity, the teacher as a revered figure, and guests as divine manifestations. Pursue blameless actions and serve these beings. Set aside other things. Undertake actions that are agreeable to us. Those seeking happiness should not forsake learning; those valuing knowledge should not abandon the pursuit of happiness.

sloka: vivītasthalakedāraṣaṇḍakhalaveśmavāhanakoṣṭhānāṃ pūrvaṃpūrvaṃ ābādhaṃ saheta || || samāhartṛvannāgariko nagaraṃ cintayet || || daśakulīṃ gopo viṃśatikulīṃ catvāriṃśatkulīṃ vā || || sa tasyāṃ strīpuruṣāṇāṃ jātigotranāmakarmabhiḥ jaṅghaagraṃ āyavyayau ca vidyāt || || evaṃ durgacaturbhāgaṃ sthānikaścintayet || ||
translation: While inspecting the beginning stages of buildings and courtyards, a city-dweller should endure even the slightest damage conjunctively. They should reflect on settlements of ten clans, twenty clans, or even thirty clans. In such a setting, one should be aware of the starting points of the positions, castes, names, and actions of both men and women. Similarly, one should attentively consider the foundation of a four-part fortress, which is known as 'Durg'.

sloka: bhūtapūrvaṃ abhūtapūrvaṃ vā janapadaṃ paradeśaapavāhanena svadeśaabhiṣyandavamanena vā niveśayet || ||
translation: Should he assume control of a territory, either by having previously undertaken journeys to foreign lands or, through imposing taxes on his own people, making himself renowned, and settle them therein?

sloka: anyonyaārakṣaṃ niveśayet || ||
translation: Let one cause others to be established in mutual defense.

sloka: aṣṭaśatagrāmyā madhye sthānīyam | catuhśatagrāmyā droṇamukham | dviśatagrāmyāḥ kārvaṭikam | daśagrāmīsaṃgraheṇa saṃgrahaṃ sthāpayet || ||
translation: In a group of eight hundred dialects, two should be established as the points of focus; in a group of four hundred dialects, Droṇamukha should be made the central point; in a collection of twenty Indigo plant dialects, there should be a consolidation; and in ten villages, a gathering should be caused.

sloka: niveśasamakālaṃ yathāāgatakaṃ vā parihāraṃ dadyāt || ||
translation: Just as one should offer, at the appropriate time, either suitable help or the handing over (of something) for the performance of Śrāddha.

sloka: hradasya vā aviśoṣasyāṅke |
translation: Of a large body of water and the act of drying up, on its surface/location?

sloka: vṛttaṃ dīrghaṃ caturaśraṃ vā
translation: Was the hermitage made in the form of a round temple with a long and sharp entrance, or in some other way?

sloka: ṣaḍdaṇḍaucchritaṃ avaruddhaṃ taddviguṇaviṣkambham |
translation: Having been made firm by six strikes of the rod, now unobstructed, featuring twice the original characteristics.

sloka: tasya parikhāstisro daṇḍaantarāḥ kārayetcaturdaśa dvādaśa daśaiti daṇḍānvistīrṇāḥ |
translation: Of the rods within Brahma's body, three are known as parikhās, while fourteen are daṇḍas, measuring fourteen, twelve, and ten angulas respectively in their extended form.

sloka: trayaḥ prācīnā rājamārgāstraya udīcīnā iti vāstuvibhāgaḥ || ||
translation: The three eastern royal pathways and the three northern ones, referring to the designated routes, are recognized as divisions of the named track (vāstu).

sloka: daśakulīvāṭaṃ kūpasthānaṃ || ||
translation: a settlement of ten noble families, or an enclosure used by the lower classes; designated as the object.

sloka: pitṝṇāṃ māsikaṃ śrāddhaṃ anvāhāryaṃ vidurbudhāḥ || ||
translation: The monthly Śrāddha oblation presented to the Pitṛis or deceased ancestors, performed by learned and wise individuals.

sloka: ṛṣayaḥ pitaro devā bhūtānyatithayastathā | āśāsate kuṭumbibhyastebhyaḥ kāryaṃ vijānatā || ||
translation: Rishis, forefathers, and deities, as well as past beings, exhort: "Having understood your responsibilities towards family members and others who you ought to serve, you should perform (your duties)."

sloka: daivakāryāddvijātīnāṃ pitṛkāryaṃ viśiṣyate | daivaṃ hi pitṛkāryasya pūrvaṃ āpyāyanaṃ smṛtam
translation: The religious rite is the foremost duty for the dvijatins, as the nourishment of the pitr-karya is remembered to have been previously established according to traditional law; indeed, it is so ordained.

sloka: pitṛyajñaṃ tu nirvartya vipraścandrakṣaye'gnimān | piṇḍānvāhāryakaṃ śrāddhaṃ kuryānmāsānumāsikam || ||
translation: Having conducted the ritual of pitṛyajña and caused the fire to be extinguished during the lunar eclipse, a brāhman should perform the offering of rice balls (piṇḍas), the āhārya portion, and the śrāddha ceremony monthly, as well as using the appropriate vessel (āryaka) in sacrificial rites for the deceased ancestors.

sloka: kṛṣṇapakṣe daśamyādau varjayitvā caturdaśīm | śrāddhe praśastāstithayo yathaitā na tathetarāḥ
translation: In the purity of the night portion of the lunar fortnight, after setting aside the tenth and fourteenth days, when they establish the fifteen tithis at the rite in honor of the departed ancestors, they should do so with due reverence. However, those who fail to do so will not be similarly regarded.

sloka: yukṣu kurvandinarkṣeṣu sarvānkāmānsamaśnute | ayukṣu tu pitṝnsarvānprajāṃ prāpnoti puṣkalām
translation: While a sage devoted to abstract contemplation partakes in all his desired objectives in auspicious star-based periods, he fully consumes the actions of serving others. Conversely, under inauspicious conditions, one begets plentiful offspring from fathers.

sloka: yathā caivāparaḥ pakṣaḥ pūrvapakṣādviśiṣyate | tathā śrāddhasya pūrvāhṇādaparāhṇo viśiṣyate
translation: Indeed, just as the later view stands out from the one stated previously, similarly, the pre- and post-rites of the shraddha ceremony are distinctly established in their own right.

sloka: rātrau śrāddhaṃ na kurvīta rākṣasī kīrtitā hi sā | sandhyayorubhayoścaiva sūrye caivācirodite
translation: During the night, specifically on the festival of the 11th day of the first half of the month Āshāḍha, one should not perform the śrāddha ritual, for it is said to be associated with a Rākshasī (female demon). The same applies to both sandhyas (twilights) and when the sun has risen shortly before. This injunction is made out of caution, lest one incurs the unfavorable influence of such a demonic act.

sloka: anena vidhinā śrāddhaṃ trirabdasyeha nirvapet | hemantagrīṣmavarṣāsu pāñcayajñikamanvaham
translation: According to this scriptural rule, one should offer the Śrāddha ritual three times in the course of one's life: during the Hemanta (cold) and Grīṣma (hot) seasons, as well as on each of the five sacred days.

sloka: kuryād āparapakṣīyaṃ māsi prauṣṭhapade dvijaḥ | śrāddhaṃ pitroryathāvittaṃ tad‍bandhūnāṃ ca vittavān || ||
translation: A dvija should conduct a springtime sacrifice on the full moon day in the opposite camp. Similarly, he should perform ancestral rites as prescribed and bestow wealth upon his kin.

sloka: saṃskārakālo jāyāyā apatyasyātmanastathā | pretasaṃsthā mṛtāhaśca karmaṇyabhyudaye nṛpa || ||
translation: The time for sacred ceremonies, O king, pertains to the wife and her offspring's very essence, as well as to the deceased and those who have left (at the end of their life). This also applies to the manifestation of actions, referring to the dual nature of such events.

sloka: kuryādaharahaḥ śrāddhaṃ annādyenodakena vā | payomūlaphalairvāpi pitṛbhyaḥ prītimāvahan || ||
translation: Should one perform a daily rite for the ancestors, offering them foodstuffs, beginning with semen and hereditary servants, or simply water, for their enjoyment and delight, or even fruits, as a pleasurable sensation for the Pitrs?

sloka: tilairvrīhiyavairmāṣairadbhirmūlaphalena vā | dattena māsaṃ tṛpyanti vidhivatpitaro nṛnām
translation: By offering sesame seeds, rice, barley grains, and beans along with water in the prescribed manner, fathers of people are satisfied or find contentment.

sloka: yadeva tarpayatyadbhiḥ pitṝnsnātvā dvijottamaḥ | tenaiva kṛtsnaṃ āpnoti pitṛyajñakriyāphalam rājatairbhājanaireṣāṃ atho vā rajatānvitaiḥ | vāryapi śraddhayā dattaṃ akṣayāyopakalpate
translation: When the most excellent of the twice-born, by satisfying the forefathers with ablutions and partaking of them, attains complete fulfillment of the ritual offering's fruit. Moreover, what is donated with sincere faith, be it small, becomes inexhaustible for him. Here, 'satisfying the forefathers with ablutions' implies performing the ritualistic bathing of Pitrs during shraddha ceremony. The phrase 'partakes of them' indicates consuming sacred food (naivedya) offered to the ancestors. The text further highlights that even a small donation made with unwavering faith becomes boundless in its benefits for the giver.

sloka: aparāhṇastathā darbhā vāstusaṃpādanaṃ tilāḥ | sṛṣṭirmṛṣṭirdvijāścāgryāḥ śrāddhakarmasu saṃpadaḥ
translation: At dusk, procuring darbha grass and preparing the rākshasa's abode, as well as Gmelina Arborea and a savory repast, are indeed the prime duties of the virtuous and brave twice-born. Such is their attainment in fulfilling Sraddha rituals.

sloka: api naḥ sa kule bhūyādyo no dadyāttrayodaśīm | pāyasaṃ madhusarpirbhyāṃ prākchāye kuñjarasya ca yatkiṃ cinmadhunā miśraṃ pradadyāttu trayodaśīm | tadapyakṣayaṃ eva syādvarṣāsu ca maghāsu ca
translation: Even if someone from our clan were to become more prominent and give us, on the eleventh day's offering, a rice pudding mixed with honey and sesame seeds or any other sweet concoction, it would merely amount to its consumption. Such an act would not increase our prosperity during the Magha lunar month or any other time. You, however, are instructed to perform the rite of sprinkling (of water) at that time.

sloka: yadyaddadāti vidhivatsamyakśraddhāsamanvitaḥ | tattatpitṝṇāṃ bhavati paratrānantamakṣayam
translation: When one duly offers the Śrāddha, endowed with firm faith, then that very fortune of infinite, undecaying recompense ensues for the Pitṛis or deceased ancestors.

sloka: teṣāmārakṣabhūtaṃ tu pūrvaṃ daivaṃ niyojayet | rakṣāṃsi hi vipralumpanti śrāddhamārakṣavarjitam daivādyantaṃ tadīheta pitrādyantaṃ na tadbhavet | pitrādyantaṃ tvīhamānaḥ kṣipraṃ naśyati sānvayaḥ
translation: For those protected in the past by the divine ordinance, it ought to be reestablished as their protector. Indeed, when the shraddha-ritual is neglected, protectors may become confused and abandon their duties. This protection, extending from divinity to ancestors, should never cease; otherwise, one who disregards it will soon perish along with their lineage.

sloka: śuciṃ deśaṃ viviktaṃ ca gomayenopalepayet | dakṣināpravaṇaṃ caiva prayatnenopapādayet avakāśeṣu cokṣeṣu jalatīreṣu caiva hi | vivikteṣu ca tuṣyanti dattena pitaraḥ sadā
translation: You should cause a place to be sprinkled with the impure (defiled by cow-dung) and secluded, as well as make it disposed towards the south with deliberate effort. Furthermore, one finds pleasure in making generous donations in all open spaces, on riverbanks, etc., for such actions bring satisfaction in solitary places. Indeed, fathers are always delighted with such thoughtful gifts.

sloka: āsaneṣūpaklpteṣu barhiṣmatsu pṛthakpṛthak | upaspṛṣṭodakānsamyagviprāṃstānupaveśayet upaveśya tu tānviprānāsaneṣvajugupsitān | gandhamālyaiḥ surabhibhirarcayeddaivapūrvakam
translation: On distinct, unevenly arranged sacrificial seats, one should cause the domestic priests to be seated after offering water that has been properly touched. Similarly, on separately prepared, immaculate seats, he should seat those same priests. He ought to honor them with fragrant garlands, pleasing scents, and fire lit for the sacrificial post, in accordance with divine ancestral tradition.

sloka: yeṣāmudakamānīya sapavitrāṃstilānapi | agnau kuryādanujñāto brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaiḥ saha
translation: Of those (neut. gen. pl.), whose water offering ceremony is to be performed, even their impure stone platforms, a Brahmin, having been authorized by other Brahmins, should conjointly make libations in the fire.

sloka: agneḥ somayamābhyāṃ ca kṛtvāpyāyanamāditaḥ | havirdānena vidhivatpaścātsaṃtarpayetpitṝn agnyabhāve tu viprasya pāṇāvevopapādayet | yo hyagniḥ sa dvijo viprairmantradarśibhirucyate na paitṛyajñiyo homo laukike'gnau vidhīyate | na darśena vinā śrāddhamāhitāgnerdvijanmanaḥ
translation: Once the Soma sacrifice is conducted in conjunction with Agni, one should offer oblations and duly satisfy ancestors as prescribed by scriptural rules. In the absence of fire, a priest's life depends on it, and no ritual is performed without Darshapurnamasa. Revered by priests as Dvija, the fire isn't utilized for domestic or Paitryajna rituals. Akin to how life relies on breath, so does a priest's existence depend on the fire.

sloka: apasavyamagnau kṛtvā sarvamāvṛtya vikramam | apasavyena hastena nirvapedudakaṃ bhuvi trīṃstu tasmāddhaviḥśeṣātpiṇḍānkṛtvā samāhitaḥ | audakenaiva vidhinā nirvapeddakṣiṇāmukhaḥ
translation: Having turned to the left side towards the fire and offered a libation of water to the dead using all forces, one should offer water three times on the ground with the left hand. Then, after making the remnants of the offering while being fully focused, one should offer the concluding portion of the ritual facing south with the audaka (a specific type of water) as per the prescribed method, which is in front or before the eyes, and is like a town surrounded by water. This very fortune which is an oblation or burnt offering accompanied by a kind of perfume should be offered.

sloka: nyupya piṇḍāṃstatastāṃstu prayato vidhipūrvakam | teṣu darbheṣu taṃ hastaṃ nirmṛjyāllepabhāginām
translation: After preparing himself, one should place the rice balls in those specified locations in a proper manner. Having cleansed his hands using those grass blades, he should then offer them to the participants.

sloka: ācamyodakparāvṛtya trirāyamya śanairasūn | ṣaḍṛtūṃśca namaskuryātpitṝneva ca mantravat
translation: Twice-born individuals, including cowherds, having gently controlled their breath thrice, and sipped water respectfully, should offer reverential salutation to their ancestors, as if leading or bringing them pleasure, in a manner similar to chanting a mantra.

sloka: udakaṃ ninayeccheṣaṃ śanaiḥ piṇḍāntike punaḥ | avajighrecca tānpiṇḍānyathānyuptānsamāhitaḥ piṇḍebhyastvalpikāṃ mātrāṃ samādāyānupūrvaśaḥ | tāneva viprānāsīnānvidhivatpūrvamāśayet
translation: Desiring to purify the water used in the funeral rites, one should gently, in measured amounts and repeatedly at the edge, cause the impure water to be abandoned in the same manner as before. Then, ensuring it is fit for the domestic priests by making it scarce and following ancient traditions, you should establish it.

sloka: dhriyamāṇe tu pitari pūrveṣāṃ eva nirvapet | vipravadvāpi taṃ śrāddhe svakaṃ pitaramāśayet pitā yasya nivṛttaḥ syājjīveccāpi pitāmahaḥ | pituḥ sa nāma saṅkīrtya kīrtayetprapitāmaham pitāmaho vā tacchrāddhaṃ bhuñjītetyabravīnmanuḥ | kāmaṃ vā samanujñātaḥ svayaṃ eva samācaret
translation: Once your father enters his elderly phase, you ought to perform the funeral rites for the ancestors who preceded him. A domestic priest should inspire and encourage him, having fulfilled his duties, to cherish his own father as dear. Manu proclaimed, "After invoking the name of the father, cause him to be extolled; whether it's your grandfather or great-grandfather, both should partake in that funeral rite." If permitted, one may personally carry out the preferred rites.

sloka: teṣāṃ dattvā tu hasteṣu sapavitraṃ tilodakam | tatpiṇḍāgraṃ prayaccheta svadhaiṣāmastviti bruvan
translation: After giving the sacred water for them to touch their hands, one should offer this sesame-water mixture, while uttering 'may this be your svadha' as a purifying prayer. This is the stipulated rite.

sloka: pāṇibhyāṃ tūpasaṃgṛhya svayamannasya vardhitam | viprāntike pitṝndhyāyanśanakairupanikṣipet ubhayorhastayormuktaṃ yadannamupanīyate | tadvipralumpantyasurāḥ sahasā duṣṭacetasaḥ
translation: By using your two hands to personally take and present the self-generated sustenance near the domestic priest during the pitr-tarpanam ritual, you then release both of your hands from the food offering. However, beware! The impure demons with defiled consciousness will swiftly steal such offerings without hesitation.

sloka: guṇāṃśca sūpaśākādyānpayo dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu | vinyasetprayataḥ pūrvaṃ bhūmāveva samāhitaḥ
translation: He should first and foremost prepare with a focused mind, setting out in front of him as cook, curds, milk, ghee, and honey, as well as vegetable and herb juices, to consume utterly by burning.

sloka: upanīya tu tatsarvaṃ śanakaiḥ susamāhitaḥ | pariveṣayeta prayato guṇānsarvānpracodayan
translation: Undertaking to carefully gather all of Krishna's teachings with gentle absorption, one should cause (someone) to be established in them; activating and arousing all excellent qualities, let him diligently attend to it in a high degree.

sloka: nāsramāpātayejjātu na kupyennānṛtaṃ vadet | na pādena spṛśedannaṃ na caitadavadhūnayet asraṃ gamayati pretānkopo'rīnanṛtaṃ śunaḥ | pādasparśastu rakṣāṃsi duṣkṛtīnavadhūnanam
translation: Out of fear, let him not cause a spiritual guide to fall through arrogance, nor let him become angry or speak untruths. Let him not use his foot to touch anything animate or inanimate, and nor should he bring distress to the spirit of the departed. His foot-touch is protective for those who are sinful and troubled, an evil-doer's harmful actions towards the pious and devoted.

sloka: yadyadroceta viprebhyastattaddadyādamatsaraḥ | brahmodyāśca kathāḥ kuryātpitṝṇāṃ etadīpsitam svādhyāyaṃ śrāvayetpitrye dharmaśāstrāṇi caiva hi | ākhyānānītihāsāṃśca purāṇāni khilāni ca harṣayedbrāhmaṇāṃstuṣṭo bhojayecca śanaiḥśanaiḥ | annādyenāsakṛccaitānguṇaiśca paricodayet
translation: Whatever a domestic priest (vipra) perceives or finds splendid, he should impart without delay to his servants; this is the desired reflection on religion or duty (svādhyāyaṃ) and hearing of the scriptures for the ancestors. He should make the subjects of discourse, such as narratives, precepts, history, and legends, as well as wholesome texts, delightful to the brahmins, satisfying them gradually. With food in a mystical sense (anna) and other primary means that are not obtained casually, he should uplift these qualities (guṇaiḥ) in himself, expressing fulness or high degree.

sloka: vratasthamapi dauhitraṃ śrāddhe yatnena bhojayet | kutapaṃ cāsanaṃ dadyāttilaiśca vikirenmahīm trīṇi śrāddhe pavitrāṇi dauhitraḥ kutapastilāḥ | trīṇi cātra praśaṃsanti śaucamakrodhamatvarām
translation: Indeed, at the Śrāddha ritual, one should diligently offer food to the established daughter's son. Who should provide a seat and where it should be arranged along with the lifted tilas (sesame seeds) is questioned. Here, three attributes are extolled as pure for the daughter's son during the Śrāddha: integrity, freedom from anger, and enthusiasm.

sloka: brāhmaṇaṃ bhikṣukaṃ vāpi bhojanārthamupasthitam | brāhmaṇairabhyanujñātaḥ śaktitaḥ pratipūjayet
translation: When a mendicant of the Brahman order, having been invited by an assembly of Brahmans and arriving for a meal, is presented with food, they should be respectfully honored in their presence and according to one's abilities.

sloka: sārvavarṇikamannādyaṃ saṃnīyāplāvya vāriṇā | samutsṛjedbhuktavatāmagrato vikiranbhuvi
translation: Let the one who is entirely virtuous and fills (the hearts) with noises and cries, having caused to be swamped (by the water), subsequently release (it) forward, beginning from what has been consumed and made use of; for he is scattering his glorious virtues and attributes on the earth.

sloka: āsapiṇḍakriyākarma dvijāteḥ saṃsthitasya tu | adaivaṃ bhojayecchrāddhaṃ piṇḍam ekaṃ ca nirvapet sahapiṇḍakriyāyāṃ tu kṛtāyāmasya dharmataḥ | anayaivāvṛtā kāryaṃ piṇḍanirvapanaṃ sutaiḥ
translation: Even for a steadfast dvija, the religious rite of providing food and a single pinda should be performed right away. The duty of performing this rite oneself leads to being bound to it. This same duty is to be accomplished by the sons for offering pinda. The act of making offerings in the ritual, indicated by the past participle, connects one to its completion. The expressed Soma juice is also a part of this ritual.

sloka: pṛṣṭvā svaditam ityevaṃ tṛptānācāmayettataḥ | ācāntāṃścānujānīyādabhito ramyatam iti
translation: After inquiring, once one has tasted the delight (of spiritual realization), they should be satisfied themselves and cause others to be content as well. Having made them tranquil, one should then humbly approach and respectfully order those men (to act accordingly). This is the recommended way to proceed.

sloka: svadhāstvityeva taṃ brūyurbrāhmaṇāstadanantaram | svadhākāraḥ parā hyāṣīḥ sarveṣu pitṛkarmasu
translation: Indeed, they should declare that one who embodies the qualities of "svadhā" (a ritual action dedicated to ancestors). Immediately thereafter, Brahmans should declare the form of "svadhā," which is supreme in all religious rites for the ancestors.

sloka: tato bhuktavatāṃ teṣāmannaśeṣaṃ nivedayet | yathā brūyustathā kuryādanujñātastato dvijaiḥ
translation: Upon their consummation, with regard to that food in a mystical sense, they should cause the remains to be offered, as is rightly prescribed, spoken of, and judged by trustworthy brahmins, who breathe the flute (i.e., perform their duties) in accordance with proper authorization.

sloka: pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi
translation: In the ritual for offerings to the Pitrs, it should be referred to as 'svaditam' (the oblation fully consumed by fire); in the herd gathering, it is called 'suśṛtam' (well-reputed). At the conclusion of rites, 'sampannam' (completed) is considered fitting; even in the ritual for Pitrs, it should be referred to as 'svaditam'; in the divine assembly, 'rucitam' (pleasing to the mind) is appreciated.

sloka: visṛjya brāhmaṇāṃstāṃstu niyato vāgyataḥ śuciḥ | dakṣiṇāṃ diśamākāṅkṣanyācetemānvarānpitṝn dātāro no'bhivardhantāṃ vedāḥ saṃtatireva ca | śraddhā ca no mā vyagamadbahudeyaṃ ca no'stviti
translation: Having released the brahmans from their duties, resolute and pure, he should desire to approach the southern quarter, seeking alms. May those givers of alms increase for us! May the sacred teachings endure perpetually! And may our faith not leave us, but instead abound in many places.

sloka: evaṃ nirvapaṇaṃ kṛtvā piṇḍāṃstāṃstadanantaram | gāṃ vipramajamagniṃ vā prāśayedapsu vā kṣipet piṇḍanirvapaṇaṃ ke citparastādeva kurvate | vayobhiḥ khādayantyanye prakṣipantyanale'psu vā
translation: Having arranged the offerings in such a manner, one should then cause the domestic priest, who is the son of a nobleman or the leader of a flock (fire), to partake in them immediately. Some, breathing the flute, consume the remains of the offerings, while others, engaging in enjoyment, hastily put or place anything on or in the fountain of digestive power or scatter them elsewhere.

sloka: pativratā dharmapatnī pitṛpūjanatatparā | madhyamaṃ tu tataḥ piṇḍamadyātsamyaksutārthinī āyuṣmantaṃ sutaṃ sūte yaśomedhāsamanvitam | dhanavantaṃ prajāvantaṃ sāttvikaṃ dhārmikaṃ tathā prakṣālya hastāvācāmya jñātiprāyaṃ prakalpayet | jñātibhyaḥ satkṛtaṃ dattvā bāndhavānapi bhojayet
translation: Designate as the obedient mistress of duty, devoted to her husband, focused on honoring father, ancestors, and tradition. Offer a middle portion, fully realizing the purpose of the rite, endowed with progeny, strength, righteousness, and virtue. After properly honoring kinfolk and feasting relatives, prepare to serve with joined hands and speech, an instruction indicating knowledge. Offer the prepared food to the guest as sacred knowledge incarnate, a merchant or king deserving of honor.

sloka: uccheṣaṇaṃ tu tattiṣṭhedyāvadviprā visarjitāḥ | tato gṛhabaliṃ kuryāditi dharmo vyavasthitaḥ
translation: "He should assume the role of an arbiter, as long as ascetics and seers are departed from society. Then, he should carry out the rite of establishing a household, with regard to that being firmly grounded. This is how customary conduct becomes established."

sloka: prācīnāvītinā samyagapasavyamatandriṇā | pitryam ā nidhanātkāryaṃ vidhivaddarbhapāṇinā
translation: Conducting the ancestral ritual, initiated in the prescribed manner using a fire lit at the time of death and preceded by ancient customs, while holding steadfastly to focused attention and sacred darbha grass, is the designated duty.

sloka: dvau daive pitṛkārye trīnekaikamubhayatra vā | bhojayetsusamṛddho'pi na prasajjeta vistare || || satkriyāṃ deśakālau ca śaucaṃ brāhmaṇasaṃpadaḥ | pañcaitānvistaro hanti tasmānneheta vistaram || ||
translation: In sacred rites for the divine, offer to three deities with one handful; in rituals for ancestors, to two with one. The prosperous should also do likewise, without being excessively lavish. Proper conduct, place and time, and cleanliness are crucial in both cases. These five factors, when observed, lead to the destruction of obstacles. Therefore, never be overly elaborate in your actions.

sloka: ekamapyāśayedvipraṃ pitrarthe pāñcayajñike || ||
translation: Even in the case of a single domestic priest, should one cause (him) to stay as a guest during the five sacrificial rituals, for the welfare of a father personified as the son of Dharma and Buddhi?

sloka: atyuṣṇaṃ sarvamannaṃ syādbhuñjīraṃste ca vāgyatāḥ | na ca dvijātayo brūyurdātrā pṛṣṭā havirguṇān yāvaduṣmā bhavatyannaṃ yāvadaśnanti vāgyatāḥ | pitarastāvadaśnanti yāvannoktā havirguṇāḥ yadveṣṭitaśirā bhuṅkte yadbhuṅkte dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ | sopānatkaśca yadbhuṅkte tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate | | | |
translation: Let all partake of the heated food. Those who are self-restrained and desire to eat should do so. Lest they become overheated, let them eat. The qualities of the oblation should not be discussed here. The ancestors will partake if its qualities have been declared. If one eats with a veiled face or consumes the southern portion, that act is protective. Indeed, you have eaten and thus will protect (them).

sloka: jñānotkṛṣṭāya deyāni kavyāni ca havīṃṣi ca || || sahasraṃ hi sahasrāṇāmanṛcāṃ yatra bhuñjate | ekastānmantravitprītaḥ sarvānarhati dharmataḥ || || yatnena bhojayecchrāddhe bahvṛcaṃ vedapāragam | śākhāntagamathādhvaryuṃ chandogaṃ tu samāptikam || || eṣāmanyatamo yasya bhuñjīta śrāddhamarcitaḥ | pitṝṇāṃ tasya tṛptiḥ syācchāśvatī sāptapauruṣī || ||
translation: Offer superior poetry and oblations to the distinguished one, as thousands of hymns are enjoyed there. A single individual, adept in mantras, finds delight and fulfills all religious obligations accordingly. With effort, feed and offer copious Vedic recitations to the one who has reached the end of the branches and concluding hymns - Adhvaryu and Chandogas. This is the minimal duty for the one whose Śrāddha ceremony is being conducted, ensuring their ancestors' eternal satisfaction.

sloka: mātāmahaṃ mātulaṃ ca svasrīyaṃ śvaśuraṃ gurum | dauhitraṃ viṭpatiṃ bandhuṃ ṛtvigyājyau ca bhojayet || ||
translation: He should honor as a mother his mother's father, along with his maternal uncle, his sister's son, his father-in-law, teacher, son-in-law, his sister, those who officiate at rituals, and those who are to be feasted, and also consider them with the same respect as his own kin.

sloka: jñānaniṣṭhā dvijāḥ ke cittaponiṣṭhāstathāpare | tapaḥsvādhyāyaniṣṭhāśca karmaniṣṭhāstathāpare || || jñānaniṣṭheṣu kavyāni pratiṣṭhāpyāni yatnataḥ | havyāni tu yathānyāyaṃ sarveṣveva caturṣvapi || || dūrādeva parīkṣeta brāhmaṇaṃ vedapāragam | tīrthaṃ taddhavyakavyānāṃ pradāne so'tithiḥ smṛtaḥ || ||
translation:
Among the dvijas, who are established in the higher knowledge and, respectively, in intellect, religious austerity, studying the Veda, and action? One should carefully establish poetic compositions for those devoted to knowledge; however, sacrifices should be offered as prescribed for all, across all four classes.

A brahmana who has mastered the Vedas, an observer of rites, should be regarded as a revered guest from afar, for presenting such a one at a tirtha is remembered as an act of hospitality.

sloka: na brāhmaṇaṃ parīkṣeta daive karmaṇi dharmavit | pitrye karmaṇi tu prāpte parīkṣeta prayatnataḥ || || aśrotriyaḥ pitā yasya putraḥ syādvedapāragaḥ | aśrotriyo vā putraḥ syātpitā syādvedapāragaḥ || || jyāyāṃsamanayorvidyādyasya syācchrotriyaḥ pitā | mantrasaṃpūjanārthaṃ tu satkāram itaro'rhati || ||
translation: A knower of dharma should not scrutinize a brahmin's divine duties, but should carefully examine his conduct in familial duties. The father of an uneducated son who engages in forbidden actions is impure, and similarly, such a son becomes impure if his father is uneducated. In terms of superior or equivalent knowledge, one who is conversant with the Vedas is preferable for performing Vedic rituals; others are merely suitable for menial tasks.

sloka: na śrāddhe bhojayenmitraṃ dhanaiḥ kāryo'sya saṃgrahaḥ | nāriṃ na mitraṃ yaṃ vidyāttaṃ śrāddhe bhojayeddvijam || || yasya mitrapradhānāni śrāddhāni ca havīṃṣi ca | tasya pretya phalaṃ nāsti śrāddheṣu ca haviḥṣu ca || || yaḥ saṃgatāni kurute mohācchrāddhena mānavaḥ | sa svargāccyavate lokācchrāddhamitro dvijādhamaḥ || || saṃbhojāni sābhihitā paiśācī dakṣiṇā dvijaiḥ | ihaivāste tu sā loke gaurandhevaikaveśmani || ||
translation: One should not feed a friend with riches during a śrāddha, that is his proper duty. One should not feast a woman or a companion at a Brahmin's śrāddha, for such actions are to be avoided. For one who partakes in such gatherings for false śrāddhas and offerings, there is no spiritual benefit after death. A person who gathers people under the pretense of a false śrāddha will fall from divine existence; this fate befalls the degraded Brahmin who consumes the offerings at a false śrāddha. The gifts given during a false śrāddha are impure, considered as such by the knowledgeable. These exist in this very world, confined like a cow in a pen.

sloka: etānvigarhitācārānapāṅkteyāndvijādhamān | dvijātipravaro vidvānubhayatra vivarjayet brāhmaṇo tvanadhīyānastṛṇāgniriva śāmyati | tasmai havyaṃ na dātavyaṃ na hi bhasmani hūyate
translation: The enlightened brahmin should keep away from these reprehensible conducts of the socially degraded and morally corrupt twice-born ones, similar to how one avoids burning waste. One should not offer sacrificial gifts to such a person, for they do not achieve purification through sacred ashes; indeed, it is not customary for them to be consecrated in this manner.

sloka: avratairyaddvijairbhuktaṃ parivetrādibhistathā | apāṅkteyairyadanyaiśca tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate
translation: The impious among the twice-born partake of that very protection, having previously consumed what is offered by those not their proper food givers, as well as by outcastes and others, through undertaking such acts.

sloka: somavikrayiṇe viṣṭhā bhiṣaje pūyaśoṇitam | naṣṭaṃ devalake dattamapratiṣṭhaṃ tu vārdhuṣau
translation: To the seller of the moon-related object, offer the uncorrupted blood for healing; what has been given at the sacred site, restore to its rightful owner, and likewise, make firm what is unestablished.

sloka: yattu vāṇijake dattaṃ neha nāmutra tadbhavet |
translation: Whatever is given in mercantile activity does not occur as one's own here or in the other world.

sloka: prathitā pretakṛtyaiṣā pitryaṃ nāma vidhukṣaye | tasminyuktasyaiti nityaṃ pretakṛtyaiva laukikī || ||
translation: This ritual for the dead, famously known as pitrya nama and performed in the case of a vidhu's (deceased person's) ksaya (demise), is continuously carried out in an ordinary, worldly manner. It is designated as eti (this is called) for the one who is yuktasya (connected with it), being the pretakrtya of a pupil of Hiraṇya-nābha and the house of Yama according to Brahma and Manu Bhautya.

sloka: śrotriyāyaiva deyāni havyakavyāni dātṛbhiḥ | arhattamāya viprāya tasmai dattaṃ mahāphalam || || ekaikamapi vidvāṃsaṃ daive pitrye ca bhojayet | puṣkalaṃ phalamapnoti nāmantrajñānbahūnapi || || yatheriṇe bījamuptvā na vaptā labhate phalam | tathānṛce havirdattvā na dātā labhate phalam || || dātṝnpratigrahītṝṃśca kurute phalabhāginaḥ | viduṣe dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā vidhivatpretya ceha ca || ||
translation: The offerings should be made to the conversant with sacred knowledge; such is the highest duty to the worthy domestic priest. Even presenting to a single knowing one brings abundant rewards, not to mention many consecrated by mantra formulas. Like a seed neglected, it bears no fruit; similarly, he who fails to give makes no gain. Giver and recipient share in the reward; after death, giving to the deserving wise man brings merit.

sloka: kāmaṃ śrāddhe'rcayenmitraṃ nābhirūpamapi tvarim | dviṣatā hi havirbhuktaṃ bhavati pretya niṣphalam || ||
translation: During the sacrificial rite, one should make a friend reverently honor (the oblation) with desire, even if he seems inappropriate. Indeed, consumed by an enemy, it becomes fruitless after death.

sloka: ta ete śreyasaḥ kālā nṝṇāṃ śreyovivardhanāḥ | kuryāt sarvātmanaiteṣu śreyo'moghaṃ tadāyuṣaḥ || || eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram || ||
translation: These two advantageous moments, conducive to the welfare of mankind and promoting their prosperity, should one utilize completely for the ultimate benefit at the present time. Then, offerings made in the form of bathing in sacred waters, recitation, fire rituals, vows, and worshiping gods, twice-borns, pitrs, and other beings become permanently efficacious.

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: Let one elect to live either by truth personified or falsehood, but never through deceptive existence. The unsolicited truth, praised and akin to elixir, is to be identified as pure thought, while that sought as alms is known as fatiguing falsehood. The former is remembered as cultivated land, and the latter, trade; one thrives through both. Worship is designated by the name of livelihood based on deceit; thus, one ought to abandon it completely.

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: The Brāhman and the crowned prince should perpetually cause to avoid that which is abhorrent; a Brāhman who is composed of all sacred knowledge, and a king who is composed of all deities.

sloka: vṛttiḥ saṅkarajātīnāṃ tattatkulakṛtā bhavet | acaurāṇāmapāpānāmantyajāntevasāyinām || ||
translation: The means of subsistence for those defined by birth into mixed caste groups becomes determined according to their respective tribal customs. This falls as the inevitable property of those who perpetrate unrighteous deeds and are thoroughly immersed in them.

sloka: vṛttyā svabhāvakṛtayā vartamānaḥ svakarmakṛt | hitvā svabhāvajaṃ karma śanairnirguṇatāmiyāt || ||
translation: Engaged in performing one's own duty, and acting according to one's inherent nature, one should abandon their natural inclinations. Gently moving towards a condition devoid of qualities, they will attain this state free from good qualities.

sloka: jaghanyo nottamāṃ vṛttimanāpadi bhajennaraḥ | ṛte rājanyamāpatsu sarveṣāmapi sarvaśaḥ || ||
translation: A man of the lowest class must not adopt a reprehensible conduct, but ought to cultivate devotion to the uttamā mode of life. Apart from in discharging royal duties, he should universally show respect to all men, even a Muni, in every way.

sloka: kuśūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā caturṇām api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyām ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati
translation: Is he a collector of coriander seeds or their distributor, or maybe one who uses firewood? Or is he content with merely enough for himself? Among these four householders partaking in the gṛhamedha ritual, the one possessing dharmic knowledge is the most excellent, distinguished, and supreme. For them, six obligations must be fulfilled: three involve action, one requires abandonment, while two lead to liberation through brahma-knowledge.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ
translation: A household priest should not present food with the intention of personal consumption within his lineage, for such food is characterized as leftovers by the wise.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam
translation: By showing liberality toward beings, even to those causing minor offenses or even to those with greater animosity, a virtuous man should conduct himself, directing his activities solely towards maintaining his livelihood through actions that earn praise and esteem. He should amass wealth effortlessly by properly caring for his bodily health.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ
translation: Surely it is proper to follow righteousness by being dedicated to agnihotra rituals, performing the final libations of the pārvāyaṇī fire, and abstaining from worldly pursuits. How could one, while living in the purest form of brahminical existence, not choose to remain alive in an ascetic manner, fully satisfied and devoted to attaining ultimate happiness? Indeed, satisfaction is the foundation of happiness, whereas its opposite brings about unhappiness.

sloka: edhodakaṃ mūlaphalaṃ annaṃ abhyudyataṃ ca yat | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānmadhvathābhayadakṣiṇām āhṛtābhyudyatāṃ bhikṣāṃ purastādapracoditām | mene prajāpatirgrāhyāṃ api duṣkṛtakarmaṇaḥ nāśnanti pitarastasya daśavarṣāṇi pañca ca | na ca havyaṃ vahatyagniryastāṃ abhyavamanyate
translation: In the present world, one should accept with reverence the water ceremony and edible fruits, food offerings that are readied and set to be presented. This includes receiving gifts of cows and gold from all sides. Even for those committing misdeeds, Prajapati considers it appropriate to partake of this meal. For ten and five more years, the father abstains from consuming these offerings made to him. And Agni does not reject what has been properly prepared for sacrifice.

sloka: śayyāṃ gṛhānkuśāngandhānapaḥ puṣpaṃ maṇīndadhi | dhānā matsyānpayo māṃsaṃ śākaṃ caiva na nirṇudet
translation: Let not the bed, plants, sacred grass, scents of any sacrifice, Kubera's vehicle, Skanda's companion's minerals, curd, grains, specific fish species, fluids or juices, flesh, and vegetables be excluded.

sloka: gurūnbhṛtyāṃścojjihīrṣannarciṣyandevatātithīn | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānna tu tṛpyetsvayaṃ tataḥ guruṣu tvabhyatīteṣu vinā vā tairgṛhe vasan | ātmano vṛttiṃ anvicchangṛhṇīyātsādhutaḥ sadā
translation: Eager to serve esteemed teachers and intending to do the same for disciples, one should welcome gods, guests, and offerings from all sides. Always striving to fulfill these duties, one should seek to understand the conduct of the venerable teachers, whether they are still present or have passed on, by attending to their responsibilities oneself or not. Never becoming self-satisfied, one should constantly make an effort to become familiar with and emulate the ways of a holy person.

sloka: imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave'bravīt
translation: I taught this imperishable yoga, exhibited in the Vedas with various irregular formations, to Vivasvan, the seventh or present Manu, in his manifestation as a follower of the Yoga system. He, being endowed with virtuous qualities and extremely brave, passed it on to Manu, his son Avyayam, who is also known as Raivata. Manu, in turn, spoke of it to Kṛiśâśva, identified here as a descendant of Ikshvāku.

sloka: bhagavo kasmin vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati
translation: Upon coming to know what or how or whence or wherefore or why of the all-comprehensive one, everything here becomes understood.

sloka: yattadadreśyamagrāhyamagotramavarṇaṃmacakṣuḥśrotraṃ tadapāṇipādam nityaṃ vibhuṃ sarvagataṃ susūkṣmaṃ tadavyayaṃ yadbhūtayoniṃ paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ
translation: The sagacious perceive the indiscernible, untouchable, unborn, without distinctive characteristics, yet manifesting through senses and movement, constantly present, omnipresent, extremely difficult to comprehend, immutable, and the source of all existent beings.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati amataṃ mataṃ avijñātaṃ vijñātaṃ iti
translation: By which (*

sloka: yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syātvācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyam”
translation: "Indeed, Somya, through understanding a single mass of clay, all that is composed of clay becomes known; the very origin and transformation are merely names, 'clay' truly being the reality."

sloka: annamayaṃ hi mana āpomayaḥ prāṇaḥ tejomayī vāk
translation: Surely, the mind, gaining its essence, is made of nourishment, while speech, consisting of splendor, is made of energy. The spirit, identified with the totality of dreaming spirits, is also essentially of the same nature as nourishment.

sloka: svaṃ apīto bhavati tasmāt enamsva pitītyācakṣate
translation: Therefore, it may be referred to as 'thy father' instead of 'thy own,' with regard to that one becoming like one's own.

sloka: sa ya eṣoഽṇimā aitadātmyamidam sarvaṃ tat satyam sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who correctly recognizes this Self of everything as "you are that," indeed you are the very nature of that reality, O Svetaketu.

sloka: ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yadyad bhavanti tadābhavanti’
translation: Here, is it a tiger (vyāghra), a lion (siṃha), a wolf (vṛka), a boar (varāha), a bug (kīṭa), a fly (pataṅga), a tooth/fang (daṃṣa), or a mosquito (maśaka) that presently exists? Whatever it is, when it ceases to exist, something else will take its place.

sloka: śṛṇu nāmāni lokānāṃ mātṝṇāṃ śaṅkarāṇi ca || atha kaśyapapatnīnāṃ yatprasūtamidaṃ jagat | aditirditirdanuḥ kāṣṭhā ariṣṭā surasā ilā || muniḥ krodhavaśā tāmrā surabhiḥ saramā timiḥ | timeryādogaṇā āsanśvāpadāḥ saramāsutāḥ
translation: Listen to the names of the feminine powers and consorts in the world, as well as the origin of this world, brought forth by the wives of Kaśyapa: Aditi, Diti, Danu, Kāṣṭhā, Ariṣṭā, Surasā, Ilā, Muni wrathful, Tāmrā, Surabhi, Saramā, and Timi. The offspring of Timi are Timeryādogaṇā, Āsanśvāpadāḥ, and Saramāsutāḥ.

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: Learned Brahmans, the thinkers, understand these words, namely 'ari-vāka' (faithful or devoted sounding) and 'pari-mitā-pada' (richly expressed inflected word), as having a limited scope and leading to liberation. They cause them to be spoken in the fourth degree of speech, which is hidden in humans and denotes the 4th state of spirit.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Keeping in view perception, inference through recognition of likeness, and verbal communication as means, one acquires valid knowledge.

sloka: indriyasyārthena sannikarṣād utpadyate yat jñānaṃ tat pratyakṣam ||
translation: The knowledge that is brought into being by the connection of a sense faculty with its related object through direct contact is referred to as sensory perception.

sloka: tatpūrvakamityanena liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbandhadarśanaṃ liṅgadarśanaṃ cābhisaṃbadhyate | liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbadhdyordarśanena liṅgasmṛtirabhisaṃbadhyate | smṛtyā liṅgadarśanena cā'pratyakṣaḥ arthaḥ anumīyate |
translation:
Through the ocular perception of that mark and what it marks,
the sacred tradition associated with it is firmly established;
with such perception, the object of the senses becomes clear,
and through remembrance, it is grasped in a linear progression.

sloka: pūrvavaditi yatra kāraṇena kāryyamanumīyate| yathā medhonnatyā bhaviṣyati vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: In the same way that future rainfall will occur based on prior causes, there also it is decided according to what is right and proper, just as a conclusion is drawn from previous causes to inevitable effect.

sloka: athavā pūrvavaditi yatra yathā pūrvvaṃ pratyakṣabhūtayoḥ anyataradarśanena anyatarasya apratyakṣasya anumānam | yathā dhūmenāgniriti |
translation: Rather, like the inference of a sacrificial fire (agniḥ) through smoke (dhūmena), it is the apprehension of what is not present to the sight (apratyakṣasya) based on previous causes (yathā pūrvvaṃ) or different apprehensions (anyataradarśanena). For instance, it is the drawing of a conclusion (anumānam) about something having a different significance (anyatara) through observation (darśanena).

sloka: śeṣavat yatra kāryyeṇa kāraṇamanumīyate | pūrvvodakaviparītamudakaṃ nadyāḥ pūrṇatvamaṃ śīdhratvañca dṛṣṭvā srotaso'numīyate bhūtā vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: Only when observing the onset of the rainy season, where the rivers' currents are seen to change their course and the effect of a task is attributed to a non-instrumental agent, can one infer that real rain has indeed occurred.

sloka: śeṣavat nāma pariśeṣaḥ sa ca prasaktapratiṣedhe'nyatra aprasāṅgāt śiṣyamāṇe sampratyayaḥ | yathā sadanityamityevamādinā dravyaguṇakarmaṇāmaviśeṣeṇa sāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyebhyo vibhaktasya śabdasya tasmin dravyakarmaguṇasaṃśaye na dravyamekadravyatvāt na karma śabdāntarahetutvāt yastu śiṣyate so'yamiti śabdasya guṇatvapratipattiḥ |
translation: The remainder is referred to as 'sesa' and it, being firmly established, becomes recognized in cases of uncertainty regarding the nature of substances, qualities, and actions. Just as with things, qualities, and actions, when there is no singularity in a substance, nor is there a cause for the word to refer to something other than an action, then one who perceives the connection between generalities and specifics becomes known as 'sesavat.' This is the teaching.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ vrajyāpūrvakam anyatra dṛṣṭasya anyatra darśanamiti tathā cā''dityasya | tasmāt asti apratyakṣā api āpyādityasya vrajyeti|
translation: The visible course of the sun is generally observed, while its presence in another manner is not. Notwithstanding, the unseen aspects of the sun, known as Āpyā, are indeed accessible. This is because the sun's true nature, as perceived by Brahma, exists beyond mere sensory perception.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ nāma yatrāpratyakṣe liṅgaliṅginoḥ sambandhe kenacidarthena liṅgasya sāmānyādapratyakṣo liṅgī gamyate | yathecchādibhirātmā | icchādayo guṇāḥ | guṇāśca dravyasaṃsthānāḥ | tadyadeṣāṃ sthānaṃ sa ātmeti |
translation: According to general analogy, a named entity is observed where there is no irresistible distinction between marked and unmarked aspects in some connection through a specific meaning or reason. The marked aspect is understood as the self, based on desires and other qualities, which are the states of substances. This self is referred to as that which is the location of those states.

sloka: prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam || || {upamānalakṣaṇam}
translation: The means of realizing widely recognized universal qualities is through analogy or comparison, which serves as the definition of upamana in Indian philosophical thought.

sloka: prajñātena sāmānyātprajñāpanīyasya prajñāpanamupamānamiti | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya iti | yadā khalvayaṃ gavā samānadharmaṃ pratipadyate tadā pratyakṣatastamarthaṃ pratipadyata iti | samākhyāsambandhapratipattiḥ rūpamānārtha ityāha | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamāne prayukte gavā samānadharmamarthamindriyārthasannikarṣādupalabhamāno asya gavayaśabdaḥ saṃjñeti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyataiti | yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇi yathā māṣastathā māṣapaṇi ityupamāne prayukte upamānāt saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyamānastāmoṣadhīṃ bhaiṣajyāyāharati | evamanyo apyupamānasya loke viṣayo bubhutsitavya iti |
translation: The indication of the general concept through a specific example (prajñātena sāmānyāt upamānena) is comprehended as something that cannot be completely described (prajñāpanīyasya). Just as when one understands the common qualities of cows using the term "gauḥ" (cow), it becomes immediately clear what is meant by a cow. Likewise, once the shared attribute of beans is realized through comparison between "mudga" (bean) and "parni" (its leaf), this recognition enables one to refer to black gram ("tamasah") appropriately. Similarly, when the properties of "māṣa" (lentil) and its accompanying objects are understood through comparison, it allows for proper reference to similar things. In this context, "gavayah" is used as an example; its meaning becomes clear through the illustration, as its individual qualities are recognized by the observer. This same principle applies to other objects of comparison in this world.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ||||{śabdalakṣaṇam} saḥ dvividhaḥ dṛṣṭādṛṣṭārthatvāt||||{śabdabhedaḥ}
translation: The speech (śabdaḥ) as instructional (āptopadeśaḥ), characterized by two forms (dvividhaḥ) due to the distinction between what is directly perceived (dṛṣṭa) and what is not (adṛṣṭa).

sloka: yasyāmutra pratīyate so'dṛṣṭārthaḥ | evamṛṣi laukikavākyānāṃ vibhāga iti |
translation: Of him, it is later perceived as something previously unseen, according to the division of mundane statements. Such is the partitioning of statements that occur in ordinary life, as declared by the sage.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni || ||
